definition: The long-tailed duck. See Old Squaw.
The art of employment of an historiographer.
Same as Hæmatoplastic.
To hie. [Obs.]Men must high them apace, and make haste. Holland.
Serving to discover or find out.
Sick at heart; extremely depressed in spirits; very despondent.
One skilled in the knowledge of plants; a collector of, ordealer in, herbs, especially medicinal herbs.
So as to heal or cure.
An hypogynous plant.
Of or relating to worms, or Helminthes; expelling worms.-- n.
One who is versed or skilled in hydrostatics. [R.]
A hydrous silicate of alumina and baryta, occurring usually inwhite cruciform crystals; cross-stone.
An apparatus for separating the threads of warps into sets, asthey are wound upon the reel from the bobbins, in a warping machine.
A harmless snake (Farancia abacura), found in the SouthernUnited States. The color is bluish black above, red below.
A herbalist. [Obs.]
Appearing as if one side, or one half, were cut away;dimidiate.
A blue isometric mineral, characteristic of some volcani
Destitute of hair. Shak.
Hateful; detestable. [Obs.]
Lame in the hip. [R.] Gower.
Developing, in the case of multicellular organisms, from thesame embryonic systems into which the secondary unit (gastrula orplant enbryo) differentiates.
A hygienist.
That part of the architrave which is over a door or window.
Emerging from the light of the sun, or passing into it; risingor setting at the same, or nearly the same, time as the sun. Sir T.Browne.
One versed in hygiene.
A ruffian; one who hounds, or spies upon, another; app. esp. tothe members of certain alleged societies among the Chinese. [U. S.]
Happening or done every hour; occurring hour by hour; frequent;often repeated; renewed hour by hour; continual.In hourly expectation of a martyrdom. Sharp.
Combined with hydrogen sulphide.
Same as Hydriodide.

An order of marsipobranchs including the lampreys. Thesuckerlike moth contains numerous teeth; the nasal opening is in themiddle of the head above, but it does not connect with the mouth. SeeCyclostoma, and Lamprey.

Pertaining to, or containing, sulphur in a lower state ofoxidation than in the sulphuric compounds; as, hyposulphuric acid.Hyposulphuric acid, an acid, H2S2O6, obtained by the action ofmanganese dioxide on sulphur dioxide, and known only in a waterysolution and in its salts; -- called also dithionic acid. SeeDithionic.
A government by seven persons; also, a country under sevenrulers.
The state or quality of being homogeneous in elements or firstprinciples; likeness or identity of parts.
Beneath the endoskeleton; hypaxial; as, the hyposkeletalmuscles; -- opposed to episkeletal.

Having half of the similar parts of a crystals, instead of all;consisting of half the planes which full symmetry would require, aswhen a cube has planes only on half of its eight solid angles, or oneplane out of a pair on each of its edges; or as in the case of atetrahedron, which is hemihedral to an octahedron, it being containedunder four of the planes of an octahedron.-- Hem`i*he"dral*ly, adv.
High flavor; strong scent. [Obs.] Halliwell.
A hydride. [Obs.]
A large lump or piece; a hunch; as, a hunk of bread. [Colloq.]
Same as Homotaxis.
Pertaining to, or derived from, hexane; as, hexoic acid.
A book of reference, to be carried in the hand; a manual; aguidebook.
A pin, usually forked, or of bent wire, for fastening the hairin place, -- used by women.
A significant shake of the head, commonly as a signal ofdenial. Shak.
Originating in the blood.
Inflated; boastful.
To persist in staying or visiting.I've charged thee not to haunt about my doors. Shak.
The Cæsarean section. See under Cæsarean.
Same as 3d Hesperian.
A division of phyllopod Crustacea, including those that areentirely covered by a bivalve shell.
In periods of seven days; weekly. Lowell.
See Jeronymite.

Having seven angles or sides. Heptagonal numbers (Arith.), thenumbers of the series 1, 7, 18, 34, 55, etc., being figurate numbersformed by adding successively the terms of the arithmetical series 1,6, 11, 16, 21, etc.
The edible viscera, as the heart, liver, etc., of a beast, esp.of a hog. [Written also harslet.]
Hence. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who halts or limps

A member of an ancient people (or perhaps group of peoples)whose settlements extended from Armenia westward into Asia Minor andsouthward into Palestine. They are known to have been met along theOrontes as early as 1500 b. c., and were often at war with theEgyptians and Assyrians. Especially in the north they developed aconsiderable civilization, of which numerous monuments andinscriptions are extant. Authorities are not agreed as to their race.While several attempts have been made to decipher the Hittitecharacters, little progress has yet been made.
One who robs on the public road; a highway robber.
Pompous; noisy; ostentatious; as, high-sounding words ortitles.
Confined to a hamlet. Feltham.
Of or pertaining to to hyetography.
The god of the sun; in the later mythology identified withApollo, and distinguished for his beauty.So excellent a king; that was, to this, Hyperion to a satyr. Shak.
A hinge. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The state of being houseless.
See Alcyonoid.
One of those, in the 4th century, who accepted the Nicenecreed, and maintained that the Son had the same essence or substancewith the Father; -- opposed to homoiousian.
The art or practices of haruspices. See Aruspicy.

A bluish black, amorphous substance containing iron andobtained from blood. It exists the red blood corpuscles united withglobulin, and the form of hemoglobin or oxyhemoglobin gives to theblood its red color.
Relating to that kind of homology or symmetry, the mathematicalconception of organic form, in which all axes are equal. See underPromorphology.
Blusteringly; arrogantly. [R.]And huffingly doth this bonny Scot ride. Old Ballad.
A chain of small cells in certain algæ, by which the plant ispropogated.
Stuff or cloth made wholly or in part of hair.
Hypogeous. [Written also hypogæan.]

A small European insectivore (Erinaceus Europæus), and otherallied species of Asia and Africa, having the hair on the upper partof its body mixed with prickles or spines. It is able to roll itselfinto a ball so as to present the spines outwardly in every direction.It is nocturnal in its habits, feeding chiefly upon insects.
An intimate companion.Hail-fellow well met. Lyly.
By inheritance. W. Tooke.
Conferring honor; tending to honor. London. Spectator.
Same as Hemorrhoidal.
Employing the same letters to represent different sounds indifferent words or syllables; -- said of methods of spelling; as, theordinary English orthography is heterographic.
A hawk used in hunting the heron. "Heroner and falcon."Chaucer.
One who makes, or deals in, hardware.
Wearing heavy or complete armor; carrying heavy arms.

Composed of hydrogen and bromine; as, hydrobromic acid.Hydrobromic acid (Chem.), a colorless, pungent, corrosive gas, HBr,usually collected as a solution in water. It resembles hydrochloricacid, but is weaker and less stable. Called also hydrogen bromide.
One who hauls.
One who uses hyperboles.
Hush; be silent; -- a signal for silence. Milton.
A writer of hierograms; also, one skilled in hieroglyphics.Greenhill.
The process of forming hummocks in the collision of Arctic ice.Kane.
Same as Hemadynamics.
A salt of hyposulphuric acid.
Having a hilt; -- used in composition; as, basket-hilted,cross-hilted.
A half spherule.
Warm-blooded; hematothermal. [R]
The measurement of the velocity of the blood.
In human form. [Obs.] Cudworth.
A huckster. Gladstone.Those hucksterers or money-jobbers. Swift.
A wood. See Hurst.
Maize hulled and broken, and prepared for food by being boiledin water. [U.S.] [Written also homony.]
The brainpan. [Obs.]
The afterbirth or secundines of a beast.
An unidentified plant mentioned by Shakespeare, perhapsequivalent to burdock.
Having seven leaves.
Spontaneous generation, so called.
That branch of physics which relates to the determination ofthe humidity of bodies, particularly of the atmosphere, with thetheory and use of the instruments constructed for this purpose.
A house or shelter for fowls.
A large piece of woolen or cotton cloth worn by Arabs as anouter garment. [Written also hyke.] Heyse.
A hyena. [Obs.] Shak.
Haughty. [Obs.] "Nations proud and haut." Milton.
Hooked, or set with hooks; hamate. Swift.
See Hordock.
Bred in high life; of pure blood. Byron.
Relating to Holland; Dutch.
See Honeyed.
A crystalline, nitrogenous substance, closely related toxanthin and uric acid, widely distributed through the animal body,but especially in muscle tissue; -- called also sarcin, sarkin.
That part of a deed which follows the part called the premises,and determines the extent of the interest or estate granted; -- socalled because it begins with the word Habendum. Kent.
A staith or framework from which coal is discharged from carsinto vessels.
Having hard hands, as a manual laborer.Hard-handed men that work in Athens here. Shak.
A vessel whose deck consists almost wholly of movable hatches;-- used mostly in the fisheries.
Causing a discharge of water or phlegm.-- n. (Med.)
To humor. Marston.
Mental labor.
A small house, hivel, or cabin; a mean lodge or dwelling; aslightly built or temporary structure.Death comes on with equal footsteps To the hall and hut. Bp. Coxe.

Any moth of the family Sphingidæ, of which there are numerousgenera and species. They are large, handsome moths, which fly mostlyat twilight and hover about flowers like a humming bird, sucking thehoney by means of a long, slender proboscis. The larvæ are large,hairless caterpillars ornamented with green and other bright colors,and often with a caudal spine. See Sphinx, also Tobacco worm, andTomato worm. Tobacco Hawk Moth (Macrosila Carolina), and its Larva,the Tobacco Worm.
Hardihood; boldness; courage; energetic action. [Obs.]Changing hardiment with great Glendower. Shak.
Preying on the heart.
To surround with earth; to heap or draw earth around or upon;as, to hill corn.Showing them how to plant and hill it. Palfrey.
The European green woodpecker. See Yaffle.
Holing a ball, whether the object ball (winning hazard) or theplayer's ball (losing hazard).
The American larch (Larix Americana), a coniferous tree withslender deciduous leaves; also, its heavy, close-grained timber.Called also tamarack.
A holothurian.
Pertaining to, or derived from, hydantoin. See Glycoluric.
See Dun crow, under Dun, a.

An atom which has a valence of seven, and which can betheoretically combined with, substituted for, or replaced by, sevenmonad atoms or radicals; as, iodine is a heptad in iodic acid. Alsoused as an adjective.
Haunted by devils; hellish. Dryden.
Destitute of color. Hudibras.
A fine wide wooled fabric much used for women's dresses.
To convert into something human or belonging to man; as, tohumanize vaccine lymph.
To press; to drive or urge forward; to push on; to precipitate;to accelerate the movement of; to expedite; to hurry.I would hasten my escape from the windy storm. Ps. lv. 8.
Haired. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A kind of low-hung cab.
Presenting hemihedral forms, in which half the sectants havethe full number of planes.
The distinctive tenet of the humanitarians in denying thedivinity of Christ; also, the whole system of doctrine based uponthis view of Christ.
A discharge pipe with a valve and spout at which water may bedrawn from the mains of waterworks; a water plug.
A loft or scaffold for hay.
A compound of hydriodic acid with a base; -- distinguished froman iodide, in which only the iodine combines with the base.
Made hard, or compact; made unfeeling or callous; madeobstinate or obdurate; confirmed in error or vice.

A fountain on Mount Helicon in Boeotia, fabled to have burstforth when the ground was struck by the hoof of Pegasus. Also, itswaters, which were supposed to impart poetic inspiration. Keats.Nor maddening draughts of Hippocrene. Longfellow.
To shake together in confusion; to push, jostle, or crowdrudely; to handle roughly; as, to hustle a person out of a room.Macaulay.
One who hoaxes.
A small mortar on a gun carriage, in use before the howitzer.
Tending or serving to heal; healing. [Obs.] Ecclus. xv. 3.
Having a redundant syllable; exceeding the common measure.Hypermetrical verse (Gr. & Lat. Pros.), a verse which contains asyllable more than the ordinary measure.
Any one of a series of unsaturated metameric hydrocarbons,C7H12, of the acetylene series.
Hotchpot. [Obs.] Chaucer.

The pursuit of game or of wild animals. A. Smith. Happy huntinggrounds, the region to which, according to the belief of AmericanIndians, the souls of warriors and hunters pass after death, to behappy in hunting and feasting. Tylor.-- Hunting box. Same As Hunting lodge (below).-- Hunting cat (Zoöl.), the cheetah.-- Hunting cog (Mach.), a tooth in the larger of two geared wheelswhich makes its number of teeth prime to the number in the smallerwheel, thus preventing the frequent meeting of the same pairs ofteeth.-- Hunting dog (Zoöl.), the hyena dog.-- Hunting ground, a region or district abounding in game; esp.(pl.), the regions roamed over by the North American Indians insearch of game.-- Hunting horn, a bulge; a horn used in the chase. See Horn, andBulge.-- Hunting leopard (Zoöl.), the cheetah.-- Hunting lodge, a temporary residence for the purpose of hunting.-- Hunting seat, a hunting lodge. Gray.-- Hunting shirt, a coarse shirt for hunting, often of leather.-- Hunting spider (Zoöl.), a spider which hunts its prey, instead ofcatching it in a web; a wolf spider.-- Hunting watch. See Hunter, 6.
Possessing the same number of factors of a given kind; as, ahomogeneous polynomial.
Resembling blood.
Same as Hagbut.
A prefix signifying half.
An isomeric variety of terpene from orange oil.
See Hyoplastron.
Heteroclitic. [Obs.]
An usher. [Obs.] Spenser.
The hip of the dog-rose. [Obs.]
A foolish; a dolt; a blockhead; a dunce. Dryden.
One who hides or conceals.
Related in history.
A female harper. [R.] Sir W. Scott.
The same as Hectogram.
Work done by the hands; hence, any work done personally.The firmament showeth his handiwork. Ps. xix. 1.
To reap or gather, as any crop.
A leather case for a pistol, carried by a horseman at the bowof his saddle.
A species (Polygonum Hydropiper) of knotweed with acridfoliage; water pepper; smartweed.
Same as Hemoglobin.
To harden, as a metal, by hammering it in the cold state.
Swollen; gibbous. [Obs.]
Resembling water; watery; aqueous; hyaloid.
The fluid portion of the cell protoplasm, in opposition tostereoplasm, the solid or insoluble portion. The latter is supposedto be partly nutritive and partly composed of idioplasm.
Small shot which scatter like hailstones. [Obs.] Hayward.
The liberty or right of pasture in the forest or in the groundsof another man. Blount.
Helped. [Obs.]
The state or quality of being heavenly. Sir J. Davies.
To place in huts; to live in huts; as, to hut troops in winterquarters.The troops hutted among the heights of Morristown. W. Irving.
One of the calicles which, in some Hydroidea (Thecaphora),protect the hydrants. See Illust. of Hydroidea, and Campanularian.
An instrument used for the purpose of obtaining specimens ofwater from any desired depth, as in a river, a lake, or the ocean.
See Hag, 4.

A famous Greek physician and medical writer, born in Cos, about460 B. C. Hippocrates' sleeve, a conical strainer, made by stitchingtogether two adjacent sides of a square piece of cloth, esp. flannelof linen.
The act or process of repairing lesions made by ulcers,especially by a plastic operation.
A term applied by Kant to those laws which are imposed on usfrom without, or the violence done to us by our passions, wants, ordesires. Krauth-Fleming.
The line at the head or top of a page.
Meteoric iron; a meteorite consisting of metallic iron withoutstony matter.
To praise; to worship. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Of a boat, to plane (see Plane, below).
The warm-blooded vertebrates, comprising the mammals and birds;-- the antithesis to hematocrya.
Of the same type of structure; pertaining to a homotype; as,homotypal parts.
Same as Hylotheist.
See Dodman. Bacon.
A water jar; esp., one with a large rounded body, a small neck,and three handles. Some of the most beautiful Greek vases are of thisform.
One versed in herpetology, or the natural history of reptiles.
Having a strongly curved bill.
A place set apart for equestrian and chariot races.
Fiery; violent; rash; hasty; impetuous; vehement. Macaulay.
One versed in hieroglyphics. Gliddon.
In a hypercritical manner.
Having such a structure as to be diaphanous when moist, andopaque when dry.
A subdivision of the Devonian system of America; -- so namedfrom Hamilton, Madison Co., New York. It includes the Marcellus,Hamilton, and Genesee epochs or groups. See the Chart of Geology.
A condition characterized by a tendency to profuse anduncontrollable hemorrhage from the slightest wounds.

One who has entered upon a portion of the public land with thepurpose of acquiring ownership of it under provisions of thehomestead law, so called; one who has acquired a homestead in thismanner. [Local, U.S.]
A chain or tie rod, in a boat or barge, to prevent the vesselfrom hogging.
The act of habituating, or accustoming; the state of beinghabituated.
Of or pert. to the arctic regions collectively; specif.(Zoögeography),
A Linnæan order of plants having six pistils.
A back with a hunch or hump; also, a hunchbacked person.
A title, denoting a Spanish nobleman of the lower class.
Hymns, considered collectively; hymnology.
The art of producing photographs in color.
Same as Hylæosaur.

from Hide. Concealed; put out of view; secret; not known;mysterious. Hidden fifths or octaves (Mus.), consecutive fifths oroctaves, not sounded, but suggested or implied in the parallel motionof two parts towards a fifth or an octave.
To accompany with harmony; to provide with parts, as an air, ormelody.
Having the hands horny and callous from labor.
Of or pertaining to hydrology.
A week; a period of seven days. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Hasty. [Obs.] Chaucer.-- Has"tif*ly, adv. [Obs.]
1. A person hired to murder or physically attack another; a hitman.
Like a home; comfortable; cheerful; cozy; friendly.
Of or pertaining to Hungary or to the people of Hungary.-- n.
Hornless. See Hummel. [Scot.]
To tire or worry; -- out. [Obs.] Dryden.
To cheat. [Colloq.] L'Estrange.
See Hylotheism.
Having the form or structure of a hydra.
The act or state of hibernating. Evelyn.
Pertaining to Ham or his descendants. Hamitic languages, thegroup of languages spoken mainly in the Sahara, Egypt, Galla, andSomâli Land, and supposed to be allied to the Semitic. Keith Johnson.
An abnormal formation foreign to the economy, and composed ofelements different from those are found in it in its normalcondition. Dunglison.
Having the main artery of the leg parallel with the sciaticnerve; -- said of certain birds.
The process of photographic engraving.
Shelter; entertainment.[R.]Where can I get me harborage for the night Tennyson.
Like a hag; lean; ugly. [R.]
Containing water of hydration or crystallization.
To speak or write with exaggeration. Bp. Montagu.
See Halloo.
One of a hundred equal parts into which one whole is, or maybe, divided; the quotient of a unit divided by a hundred.
Capable of being inhabited; that may be inhabited or dwelt in;as, the habitable world.-- Hab"it*a*ble*ness, n.-- Hab"it*a*bly, adv.
Goddess of the seasons, or of the hours of the day.Lo! where the rosy-blosomed Hours, Fair Venus' train, appear. Gray.
The sacred baboon of Egypt (Cynocephalus Hamadryas).
The goddess of youth, daughter of Jupiter and Juno. She wasbelieved to have the power of restoring youth and beauty to those whohad lost them.
See Honey eater, under Honey.
Unsympathetic; inexorable; cruel; pitiless.-- Hard"-heart`ed*ness, n.
A contrivance for multiple copying, by means of a surface ofgelatin softened with glycerin. [Written also hectograph.]
Fountain; source.The headspring of our belief. Stapleton.

To seize; to lay hold on; to catch; to get. [Obs.] PiersPlowman. Spenser.This cursed Jew him hente and held him fast. Chaucer.But all that he might of his friendes hente On bookes and on learninghe it spente. Chaucer.
Half drunk. [Slang: used only predicatively.] Spectator.
Subject to the law of another. Krauth-Fleming.

A hydrate; a substance containing hydrogen and oxygen, made bycombining water with an oxide, and yielding water by elimination. Thehydroxides are regarded as compounds of hydroxyl, united usually withbasic element or radical; as, calcium hydroxide ethyl hydroxide.
The top of a hill.

A variety of potash mica containing water. It is less elasticthan ordinary muscovite. Hydromica schist (Min.), a mica schistcharacterized by the presence of hydromica. It often has a silkyluster and almost soapy feel.
To hide. See Hele. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Any sea snake of the genus Hydrophys and allied genera. Thesesnakes are venomous, live upon fishes, and have a flattened tail forswimming.
A genus of dipterous insects including the horsefly or horsetick.-- Hip`po*bos"can, a.
See Halse.
A solid figure with seven sides.
A rare element said to be contained in gadolinite.-- Hol"mic, a.
A grappling iron. [Obs.]
The coarse part of flax or hemp; hards.

A genus of large, extinct, wingless birds from the Cretaceousdeposits of Kansas, belonging to the Odontornithes. They had teeth,and were essentially carnivorous swimming ostriches. Several speciesare known. See Illust. in Append.
Hæmatoxylin.
A heart-shaped bulbous root, about the size of a finger,brought from Turkey, formerly used as a cathartic.
Pertaining to, or written in, hemistichs; also, by, oraccording to, hemistichs; as, a hemistichal division of a verse.
Hypochondriasis.
A case for sewing materials. See Housewife. Cowper.
Doing no injury; harmless; also, unhurt; without injury orharm.Gentle dame so hurtless and so true. Spenser.-- Hurt"less*ly, adv.-- Hurt"less*ness, n.
Abnormal breathing, due to slightly deficient arterializationof the blood; -- in distinction from eupnoea. See Eupnoea, andDispnoea.
One who proposes or supports an hypothesis. [R.]

Without heed or care; inattentive; careless; thoughtless;unobservant.O, negligent and heedless discipline! Shak.The heedless lover does not know Whose eyes they are that wound himso. Waller.-- Heed"less*ly, adv.-- Heed"less*ness, n.
Same as Hæmachrome.
A meteor or atmospheric phenomenon dependent upon the vapor ofwater; -- in the pl., a general term for the whole aqueous phenomenaof the atmosphere, as rain, snow, hail, etc. Nichol.
Weekly; hebdomadal. [Obs.]
In harmonical progression.
A beautiful South American motmot. Waterton.
A bully; a blustering, turbulent, insolent, fellow; one whovexes or provokes.
Of or relating to stagnation of the blood.
A method of transferring pictures from photographic negativesto hardened gelatin plates from which impressions are produced onpaper as by lithography.
Winter. Shak.
In a healthy manner.
Humming bird.
Like, or appropriate to, a hoiden.
The native language of the Irish; that branch of the Celticlanguages spoken by the natives of Ireland. Also adj.
A nickname given to an inhabitant of the State of Indiana.[U.S.]
Morbid or excessive secretion, as in catarrh.
Prognostication; soothsaying. [Obs.] Cockeram.
See Harebell.

A sort of panel, upon which the arms of a deceased person aretemporarily displayed, -- usually on the walls of his dwelling. It islozenge-shaped or square, but is hung cornerwise. It is used inEngland as a means of giving public notification of the death of thedeceased, his or her rank, whether married, widower, widow, etc.Called also achievement.His obscure funeral; No trophy, sword, or hatchment o'er his bones.Shak.
Surrounded with a halo; invested with an ideal glory;glorified.Some haloed face bending over me. C. Bronté.
High. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An instrument for tracing designs on glass.
See Harrier. A. Chalmers.
In a horrid manner. Shak.
A point some distance below the top of a mast or staff; as, aflag a half-mast (a token of mourning, etc.).

A genus of hexactinelline sponges, having a long stem composedof very long, slender, transparent, siliceous fibres twisted togetherlike the strands of a color. The stem of the Japanese species (H.Sieboldii), called glass-rope, has long been in use as an ornament.See Glass-rope.
The honey guide.
A nook; a corner. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who harmonizes.
Same as Hexylene.
To utter with outcry. "Go . . . howl it out in deserts."Philips.
Timorous; timid; easily frightened. Ainsworth.
A combining form signifying other, other than usual, different;as, heteroclite, heterodox, heterogamous.
Of hail. "Haily showers." Pope.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Hold, contraction for holdeth. [Obs.]Chaucer.
A plant of the genus Prunus (P. Padus); the bird cherry.[Scot.]
A cart with wooden wheels, drawn by bullocks. [Bengal] Malcom.
A large blood-sucking leech (Hæmopsis vorax), of Europe andNorthern Africa. It attacks the lips and mouths of horses.
A hydrocarbon, C11H24, of the paraffin series; -- so calledbecause it has eleven atoms of carbon in each molecule. Called alsoendecane, undecane.
Having hoofs; hoofed.
A harbor master. [Obs.]
Same as Hæmacyanin.
Domestic; used in a family; as, housekeeping commodities.
A stack or conical pile of hay in the open air.
A violent, passionate person; a hasty or impetuous person; as,the rant of a hot-head.
Hot. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A suborder of Hemiptera, in which the base of the anteriorwings is thickened. See Hemiptera.
Undecylic; pertaining to, or derived from, hendecane; as,hendecatoic acid.

The permanent court of arbitration created by the"International Convention for the Pacific Settle of InternationalDisputes.", adopted by the International Peace Conference of 1899. Itis composed of persons of known competency in questions ofinternational law, nominated by the signatory powers. From thesepersons an arbitration tribunal is chosen by the parties to adifference submitted to the court. On the failure of the parties toagree directly on the arbitrators, each chooses two arbitrators, anumpire is selected by them, by a third power, or by two powersselected by the parties.
A genus of poisonous plants of the Nightshade family; henbane.
Early fruit or vegetables; especially, early pease. Mortimer.
Half turned round; half inverted; (Crystallog.) having atwinned structure.
One who, or that which, hinders.
Salver-shaped; having a slender tube, expanding suddenly aboveinto a bowl-shaped or spreading border, as in the blossom of thephlox and the lilac.
Same as Hemadynamometer.
A hardened, engraved steel punch for impressing a device upon adie, used in coining, etc.
Having different names or designations; standing in oppositerelations. J. Le Conte.-- Het"er*on"y*mous*ly, adv.
In the direction of health; as, a healthward tendency.
Pertaining to the Holostei.
Hospitable. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to histolysis, or the degeneration of tissues.
A brother by one parent, but not by both.
A harpoon. Evelyn.
A genus of marine shells; the ear-shells. See Abalone.
To deal in small articles, or in petty bargains. Swift.
A thin silk or woolen goods, for women's dresses, woven invarious styles and colors.
A beam with projecting spikes, used to make a breachimpassable.
A somersault made with the assistance of the hands placed uponthe ground.
To determine the homologies or structural relations of.
The quality of being horrid.
Hence. [Obs.] Chaucer.
See Hyperæsthesia.
To produce young; -- said of eggs; to come forth from the egg;-- said of the young of birds, fishes, insects, etc.
Having violent contrasts of color, or of light and shade;lacking in harmony.

Of or relating to Hesse, in Germany, or to the Hessians.Hessian boots, or Hessians, boot of a kind worn in England, in theearly part of the nineteenth century, tasseled in front. Thackeray.-- Hessian cloth, or Hessians, a coarse hempen cloth for sacking.-- Hessian crucible. See under Crucible.-- Hessian fly (Zoöl.), a small dipterous fly or midge (Cecidomyiadestructor). Its larvæ live between the base of the lower leaves andthe stalk of wheat, and are very destructive to young wheat; -- socalled from the erroneous idea that it was brought into America bythe Hessian troops, during the Revolution.
See Haulm, stalk. Smart.
Being in the direction of home; as, the homeward way.
Affected with hypochondria; hypped. [Written also hyppish.]
A compound of the binary type, in which hydrogen is united withsome other element.
Any sail set forward of the foremast. Totten.

Belonging to the house and family; domestic; as, householdfurniture; household affairs. Household bread, bread made in thehouse for common use; hence, bread that is not of the finest quality.[Obs.] -- Household gods (Rom. Antiq.), the gods presiding over thehouse and family; the Lares and Penates; hence, all objects endearedby association with home.-- Household troops, troops appointed to attend and guard thesovereign or his residence.
An order of fishes having an incomplete or reduced branchialapparatus. It includes the sticklebacks, the flutemouths, andFistularia.
Tissue-producing; connected with the formation and developmentof the organic tissues.
A pen or sty for hogs.
Privacy; secrecy. Commonly in the phrase in hugger-mugger, withhaste and secrecy. [Archaic]Many things have been done in hugger-mugger. Fuller.
A hunch. [Obs.]
Hollo.

A tree of the genus Carpinus (C. Americana), having a smoothgray bark and a ridged trunk, the wood being white and very hard. Itis common along the banks of streams in the United States, and isalso called ironwood. The English hornbeam is C. Betulus. TheAmerican is called also blue beech and water beech. Hop hornbeam.(Bot.) See under Hop.
Gravel retaining in the hopper of a cradle.
That part of a bridle or halter which encompasses the head.Shak.
See Uranus.
One who, or that which, harbors.Geneva was . . . a harborer of exiles for religion. Strype.
Pubescent with minute and somewhat rigid hairs.
A hyperdicrotic condition.
Native barium sulphate or barite, -- so called because of itshigh specific gravity as compared with other non-metallic minerals.
A field where grass for hay has been cut; a meadow. Cowper.
The principles of dynamics in their application to the blood;that part of science which treats of the motion of the blood.
Resembling, or approximating to, a hemisphere in form.
One of the sets of parallel doubled threads which, withmounting, compose the harness employed to guide the warp threads tothe lathe or batten in a loom.
An official report of proceedings in the British Parliament; --so called from the name of the publishers.
See Ha-ha.
In pale, with the head in chief; -- said of the figure of afish, as if rising for air.
Rehearsal. [Obs.] Spenser.
Written in, or pertaining to, hierograms; expressive of sacredwriting. Bp. Warburton.
A kind of rue (Ruta sylvestris) growing in India. At Lahore theseeds are used medicinally and for fumigation.
Sound; entire; healthy; robust; not impaired; as, a hale body.Last year we thought him strong and hale. Swift.
That branch of the science of geodesy which has to do with themeasurement of heights, either absolutely with reference to the sealevel, or relatively.
Hydrogen; -- called also in view of its supposed metallicnature. Graham.

A figure of speech in which the expression is an evidentexaggeration of the meaning intended to be conveyed, or by whichthings are represented as much greater or less, better or worse, thanthey really are; a statement exaggerated fancifully, throughexcitement, or for effect.Our common forms of compliment are almost all of them extravaganthyperboles. Blair.Somebody has said of the boldest figure in rhetoric, the hyperbole,that it lies without deceiving. Macaulay.
In an heretical manner.
A light cloth covering for the head and neck, used by soldiersas a protection from sunstroke.
A heroine. [Obs.] Dryden.
Resembling the Greek letter
A shield-bearer or armor-bearer. Mitford.
Bearing holsters. Byron.
Leather tanned from a hog's skin. Also used adjectively.

A curve formed by a section of a cone, when the cutting planemakes a greater angle with the base than the side of the cone makes.It is a plane curve such that the difference of the distances fromany point of it to two fixed points, called foci, is equal to a givendistance. See Focus. If the cutting plane be produced so as to cutthe opposite cone, another curve will be formed, which is also anhyperbola. Both curves are regarded as branches of the samehyperbola. See Illust. of Conic section, and Focus.
In a hazy manner; mistily; obscurely; confusedly.
Shaped like a horseshoe.
The female of the domestic fowl; also, the female of grouse,pheasants, or any kind of birds; as, the heath hen; the gray hen.
Of the nature of a holograph; pertaining to holographs.
A chart or graphic representation of the average distributionof rain over the surface of the earth.
Pining for home; in a nostalgic condition.-- Home"sick`ness, n.
A nymph of paradise; -- so called by the Mohammedans.
Of or pertaining to rain; descriptive of the distribution ofrain, or of rainy regions.
Of or pertaining to the Helvetii, the ancient inhabitant of theAlps, now Switzerland, or to the modern states and inhabitant of theAlpine regions; as, the Helvetic confederacy; Helvetic states.
Growing into herbs.
To receive hospitality; to be a guest. [Obs.] Grew.
Resembling a hector; blustering; insolent; taunting. "Hectorly,ruffianlike swaggering or huffing." Barrow.
Glassy; resembling glass; consisting of glass; transparent,like crystal. "Hyaline spaces." Carpenter.
Having, consisting of, or pertaining to, half tones; specif.(Photo-engraving),
One versed in horology.
Hooked; hooklike; hamate; as, the hamular process of thesphenoid bone.
Like or pertaining to the swallows.
One who hears; an auditor.
The refuse or coarse part of fiax; tow.
Any South American monkey of the genus Mycetes. Many speciesare known. They are arboreal in their habits, and are noted for theloud, discordant howling in which they indulge at night.
Pertaining to, or derived from, heptyl or heptane; as, heptylicalcohol. Cf. .
Of or pertaining to the region beyond the North wind, or to itsinhabitants.
A field where hops are raised.
A box for a hat.
Eating plants; of or pertaining to the Herbivora.
A jury, for the trial of a fore foreigner, composed equally ofcitizens and aliens.
Under the tongue; -- applied esp., in the higher vertebrates,to the twelfth or last pair of cranial nerves, which are distributedto the base of the tongue.-- n.
In a haughty manner; arrogantly.
A large edible river fish (Erythrinus macrodon) of Guiana.
Toward hell. Pope.
The business of a huckster; small dealing; peddling.Ignoble huckster age of piddling tithes. Milton.
An astringent inspissated juice obtained from the fruit of aplant (Cytinus hypocistis), growing from the roots of the Cistus, asmall European shrub.
The commission or compensation allowed to a ship's husband.
A vermifuge.
A whip for horses.
A kind of gate or portcullis, having iron bars, like a harrow,studded with iron spikes. It is hung above gateways so that it may bequickly lowered, to impede the advance of an enemy. Farrow.
Insincerely; deceitfully. Shak.
An order of pelagic Gastropoda, having the foot developed intoa median fin. Some of the species are naked; others, as Carinaria andAtlanta, have thin glassy shells.
To hoist. [Obs.]They . . . hoised up the mainsail to the wind. Acts xxvii. 40.
Same as Hoiden.
A composition of wax and lampblack, used by shoemakers forpolishing, and by antiquaries in copying inscriptions.
Round-shoulded.
The raspberry. [Prov. Eng.]
The natural history of reptiles; that branch of zoölogy whichrelates to reptiles, including their structure, classification, andhabits.
Pertaining to humanitarians, or to humanitarianism; as, ahumanitarian view of Christ's nature.
A spree; a revel. [Low]
Hourly. [Obs.]
A bar used as a lever. Totten.
Born in or of hell. Shak.
A bully; a bravo; a ruffian; an assassin. [Obs.] Milton.
A very astringent shrub (Spiræa tomentosa), common in pastures.The Potentilla fruticosa in also called by this name.
Destitute of humor.
An awkward or foolish person. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
Sincerely beloved. [R.] Shak.

Secondary and less distinct tones which accompany anyprincipal, and apparently simple, tone, as the octave, the twelfth,the fifteenth, and the seventeenth. The name is also applied to theartificial tones produced by a string or column of air, when theimpulse given to it suffices only to make a part of the string orcolumn vibrate; overtones.
One who causes bad luck. [Colloq.]
Finished with great care; polished.
Resemblance between different plants or animals, in externalshape, in general habit, or in organs, which is not due to descentfrom a common ancestor, but to similar surrounding circumstances.
An oxide of holmium.
Them [Obs.] Chaucer.
Having the teeth differentiated into incisors, canines, andmolars, as in man; -- opposed to homodont.
Having the dorsal fin spines symmetrical, and in the same line;-- said of certain fishes.
The dabchick.
The inclination or deviation from the vertical of any mineralvein.
Having lofty arches. "The high-embowed roof." Milton.
An instrument for ascertaining the susceptibility of a personto hypnotic influences.
A kind of spider. See Hunting spider, under Hunting.
Hearty; sincere.
Heated; as, the iron though heat red-hot. [Obs. or Archaic.]Shak.
One of a mystical sect of the Greek Church in the fourteenthcentury; a quietist. Brande & C.
Hairiness. Burton.
In a hydropical manner.
Having the central florets of a flower head of a differentcolor from those of the circumference.
Possessing the property of homography.
A stone designating the Halliwell.
The side or declivity of a hill.
One who accepts the doctrines of Thomas Hobbes.
Weak in intellect; silly.
Of or pertaining to homonomy.
Hence. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Full of hubs or protuberances; as, a road that has been frozenwhile muddy is hubby. [U.S.]
To keep close to; as, to hug the land; to hug the wind. To hugone's self, to congratulate one's self; to chuckle.
Provided with a haustellum, or sucking proboscis.-- n.
Without a hump. Darwin.
Having permanent horns with a bony core, as cattle.
A threaded and fluted hardened steel cutter, resembling a tap,used in a lathe for forming the teeth of screw chasers, worm wheels,etc.
An hæmapodous animal. G. Rolleston.
A swineherd. W. Browne.
A little heart.
Relating to hymns, or sacred lyrics. Donne.
To twist or turn. "Hurled or crooked feet." [Obs.] Fuller.
Obstinacy. [R.] Gayton.
To pine; to lament; to long. Lamb.
Pertaining to, produced by, or consisting of, electricityevolved by the action or use of fluids; as, hydrogalvanic currents.[R.]
To render hybrid; to produce by mixture of stocks.
A compound having a relatively large percentage of oxygen; aperoxide. [Obs.]
A worthless dog that runs back on the scent; a blunderer.[Obs.] Shak.
Health; welfare. [Obs.] "In joy and perfyt hele." Chaucer.
The third lateral plate in the plastron of turtles; -- calledalso hyposternum.
The half channel or groove in the edge of the triglyph in theDoric order.
A cordial made of spiced wine, etc.
One who holds high-church principles.
Relating to homophily.
Enriched with spice and condiments; hence, exciting; piquant.
A species of the feldspar group containing barium. SeeFeldspar.
A hunter. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A plane figure of six angles. Regular hexagon, a hexagon inwhich the angles are all equal, and the sides are also all equal.
An ancient musical instrument played by the action of water; awater organ. [Written also hydraulis.]
An interrupter in which contact is broken by the movement of anautomatically vibrating hammer between a contact piece and anelectromagnet, or of a rapidly moving piece mechanically driven.
A young cow.
A borosilicate of iron and lime, near datolite in form andcomposition.
A loud exclamation; a call to invite attention or to incite aperson or an animal; a shout.List! List! I hear Some far off halloo break the silent air. Milton.
See Hobnob.
The neck or throat. [Obs.]Do me hangen by the hals. Chaucer.
Of a pale silvery gray.

A dynasty of Egyptian kings, often called the Shepherd kings,of foreign origin, who, according to the narrative of Manetho, ruledfor about 500 years, forming the XVth and XVIth dynasties. It is nowconsidered that the XVIth is merely a double of the XVth dynasty, andthat the total period of the six Hyksos kings was little more than100 years. It is supposed that they were Asiatic Semites.
A Hebraist. [R.]
Substance; subsistence; essence; person; personality; -- usedby the early theologians to denote any one of the three subdivisionsof the Godhead, the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.
Full of heath; abounding with heath; as, heathy land; heathyhills. Sir W. Scott.
Heather; heath. [Obs.] Burton.
A member of the highest rank of nobility in Germany andAustria, corresponding to the British duke.
The process of becoming, or the state of being, transparentlike glass.
A dish made of portions of the head, or head and feet, ofswine, cut up fine, seasoned, and pressed into a cheeselike mass.
To strip off the external covering or envelope of; as, to huskIndian corn.

Suicide, by slashing the abdomen, formerly practiced in Japan,and commanded by the government in the cases of disgraced officials;disembowelment; -- also written, but incorrectly, hari-kari. W. E.Griffis.
An alkaloid, prepared from atropine, and from other sources. Itis chemically related to atropine, and is used for the same purpose.
Forward; early; -- said of fruits. [Obs.]
One portion of a fruit that spontaneously divides into halves.
A mineral consisting of the arseniate of lime; -- so named inhonor of W. Haidinger, of Vienna.
Wholly or completely concealing; incapable of being deciphered.Holocryptic cipher, a cipher so constructed as to afford no clew toits meaning to one ignorant of the key.
An order of Annelida, including the leeches; -- called alsoHirudinei.

Furnished with a horn or horns; furnished with a hornlikeprocess or appendage; as, horned cattle; having some part shaped likea horn.The horned moon with one bright star Within the nether tip.Coleridge.Horned bee (Zoöl.), a British wild bee (Osmia bicornis), having twolittle horns on the head.-- Horned dace (Zoöl.), an American cyprinoid fish (Semotiluscorporialis) common in brooks and ponds; the common chub. See Illust.of Chub.-- Horned frog (Zoöl.), a very large Brazilian frog (Ceratophryscornuta), having a pair of triangular horns arising from the eyelids.-- Horned grebe (Zoöl.), a species of grebe (Colymbus auritus), ofArctic Europe and America, having two dense tufts of feathers on thehead.-- Horned horse (Zoöl.), the gnu.-- Horned lark (Zoöl.), the shore lark.-- Horned lizard (Zoöl.), the horned toad.-- Horned owl (Zoöl.), a large North American owl (BuboVirginianus), having a pair of elongated tufts of feathers on thehead. Several distinct varieties are known; as, the Arctic, Western,dusky, and striped horned owls, differing in color, and inhabitingdifferent regions; -- called also great horned owl, horn owl, eagleowl, and cat owl. Sometimes also applied to the long-eared owl. SeeEared owl, under Eared.-- Horned poppy. (Bot.) See Horn poppy, under Horn.-- Horned pout (Zoöl.), an American fresh-water siluroid fish; thebullpout.-- Horned rattler (Zoöl.), a species of rattlesnake (Crotaluscerastes), inhabiting the dry, sandy plains, from California toMexico. It has a pair of triangular horns between the eyes; -- calledalso sidewinder.-- Horned ray (Zoöl.), the sea devil.-- Horned screamer (Zoöl.), the kamichi.-- Horned snake (Zoöl.), the cerastes.-- Horned toad (Zoöl.), any lizard of the genus Phrynosoma, of whichnine or ten species are known. These lizards have several hornlikespines on the head, and a broad, flat body, covered with spinyscales. They inhabit the dry, sandy plains from California to Mexicoand Texas. Called also horned lizard.-- Horned viper. (Zoöl.) See Cerastes.
A tentative theory or supposition provisionally adopted toexplain certain facts, and to guide in the investigation of others;hence, frequently called a working hypothesis.
That form of homology due to common ancestry (phylogenetichomology), in opposition to homomorphy, to which genealogic basis iswanting. Haeckel.
Covered with a helmet.The helmed cherubim Are seen in glittering ranks. Milton.
The cry of a wild goose.-- Honk"ing, n.
A house for hatching fish, etc.
Covered with grass. Thomson.
An insoluble, proteid substance, described by Schützenberger,formed when albumin is heated for some time with dilute sulphuricacid. It is apparently identical with antialbumid and dyspeptone.
The practice or theory of using hellebore as a medicine.
Hairy. [Obc.]His hairen shirt and his ascetic diet. J. Taylor.

A lagging or retardation of the effect, when the forces actingupon a body are changed, as if from velocity or internal friction; atemporary resistance to change from a condition previously invuced,observed in magnetism, thermoelectricity, etc., on reversal ofpolarity.
Having the heaves.
A little hook.
Loaded dice so contrived as to turn up high numbers. [Obs] SirJ. Harrington.
That which causes horror. [R.] Miss Edgeworth.
To hearken. Tennyson.
An effusion of blood into the cavity of the pleura.
The haddock. [Scot.]
An instrument by which the pressure of the blood in thearteries, or veins, is measured by the height to which it will raisea column of mercury; -- called also a hæmomanometer.
A cover; a shelter; a protection. [Archaic] Carew. C. Kingsley.
To hiss. [Obs.] Shak.
To render heathen or heathenish. Firmin.
A woman that sells herbs.
Monotonous; dull; commonplace. "A humdrum crone." Bryant.
Same as Hemadynamics.
A distance lime brawn across the rink or course between themiddle line and the tee. [Scot.]
See Homoiothermal.
To pass the winter. [Obs. & R.]
See Hegira.
Dissolution of the red blood corpuscles with diminishedcoagulability of the blood; hæmolysis. -- Hæm`a*to*lyt"ic (#), a.
Having six hydrogen atoms or six radicals capable of beingreplaced or saturated by bases; -- said of acids; as, mellitic acidis hexabasic.
A servant; a farm laborer; a peasant; a hind. [Obs.]Bailiff, herd, nor other hine. Chaucer.
Having a hooked or aquiline nose. Shak.
Professional cant; the chatter of conjurers to divert attentionfrom their tricks; hence, jugglery. [Colloq.]
Full of humps or bunches; covered with protuberances; humped.
Vast. [Obs.] Dryden.
A small village; a little cluster of houses in the country.The country wasted, and the hamlets burned. Dryden.
Of or pertaining to the horopter.
On this; hereon.
See Hip, the fruit of the dog-rose.
Having six angles or corners.
A message transmitted by a heliograph.
Having all the flowers of a plant alike in respect to thestamens and pistils.
A page; a servant. [Obs.]
One who, or that which, heartens, animates, or stirs up. W.Browne.
To induce hypnotism in; to place in a state of hypnotism.
Inserted below the pistil or pistils; -- said of sepals,petals, and stamens; having the sepals, petals, and stamens insertedbelow the pistil; -- said of a flower or a plant. Gray.
A small haven. See Hithe. [Obs.]
of Hote. [Obs.] Spenser.
See Habergeon.
In confusion; topsy-turvy. [Colloq.] Johnson.
Hazard. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Same as Hemothorax.
The state of being heritable.
A kind of net for catching birds.
The character, personality, or office of a hostess. Shak.
Of or pertaining to a heptarchy; constituting or consisting ofa heptarchy. T. Warton.
Those insects which have a complete metamorphosis; metabola.
Hove. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A poisonous glucoside accompanying helleborin in severalspecies of hellebore, and extracted as a white crystalline substancewith a bittersweet taste. It has a strong action on the heart,resembling digitalin.
A plant found growing in salt marshes, or in the sea.
A story, anecdote, or legend in the Talmud, to explain orillustrate the text of the Old Testament. [Written also hadaga.]
Photography. R. Hunt.
An offering or oblation heaved up or elevated before the altar,as the shoulder of the peace offering. See Wave offering. Ex. xxix.27.
The science or art of comparing or measuring degrees ofmoisture. Evelyn.
imp. & p. p. of Hear.
A hatstand; hattree.
Destitute of honor; not honored. Bp. Warburton.

The normal coloring matter of the red blood corpuscles ofvertebrate animals. It is composed of hematin and globulin, and isalso called hæmatoglobulin. In arterial blood, it is always combinedwith oxygen, and is then called oxyhemoglobin. It crystallizes underdifferent forms from different animals, and when crystallized, iscalled hæmatocrystallin. See Blood crystal, under Blood.
Noise; confusion; uproar.That, with the hurly, death itself awakes. Shak.
Overcome by crushing sorrow; deeply grieved.
The snowy owl.

Pertaining to, or derived from, hydrogen and iodine; -- said ofan acid produced by the combination of these elements. Hydriodic acid(Chem.), a pungent, colorless gas, HI, usually prepared as a solutionin water. It is strong reducing agent. Called also hydrogen iodine.
Of or pertaining to clothing; wearing clothes. Ld. Lytton.
Harborage; lodging; shelter; harbor. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A seat or pavilion, generally covered, fastened on the back ofan elephant, for the rider or riders. [Written also houdah.]
The theory founded on the influence which the humors weresupposed to have in the production of disease; Galenism. Dunglison.
Same as Habitant, 2.General met an emissary . . . sent . . . to ascertain the feelings ofthe habitans or French yeomanry. W. Irwing.

Hateful; hatefully bad; flagrant; odious; atrocious; givinggreat great offense; -- applied to deeds or to character.It were most heinous and accursed sacrilege. Hooker.How heinous had the fact been, how deserving Contempt! Milton.
A built-up, rifled, rapid-fire gun of oil-tempered steel,having a rectangular breechblock which moves horizontally orvertically in a mortise cut completely through the jacket. It is madein France.
Carbureted hydrogen; also, a hydrocarbon. [Obs.]
The quality or state of being handy.

The nether world (according to classical mythology, the abodeof the shades, ruled over by Hades or Pluto); the invisible world;the grave.And death and Hades gave up the dead which were in them. Rev. xx. 13(Rev. Ver. ).Neither was he left in Hades, nor did his flesh see corruption. Actsii. 31 (Rev. Ver.).And in Hades he lifted up his eyes, being in torments. Luke xvi.23(Rev. Ver.).
Having leaves of more than one shape on the same plant.
A cell annexed to an abbey, for the use of a hermit. Howell.
The religion of the Huguenots in France.
A disease of horses, characterized by difficult breathing, withheaving of the flank, wheezing, flatulency, and a peculiar cough;broken wind.
Horselike. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A servant. See Hine. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An instrument for drawing spiral lines on a plane.
See Headway, 2.
In an heraldic manner; according to the rules of heraldry.
A ruler of one division of a heptarchy. [Written alsoheptarch.]
An aquatic mite of the genus Hydrachna. The hydrachids, whileyoung, are parasitic on fresh-water mussels.
The doctrine of belief that matter is God, or that there is noGod except matter and the universe; pantheism. See Materialism.
Same as Hematite.
Pertaining to, or including, similar forms or kinds of life;as, homoeozoic belts on the earth's surface. E. Forbes.
Themselves. See Hemself. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A South African mullet, salted for food.
That which heightens.
An abnormally watery state of the blood; anæmia.
A division of Cheiroptera, including the bloodsucking bats. SeeVampire.
The common European grosbeak (Coccothraustes vulgaris); --called also cherry finch, and coble.
The state of being hilly.
Pertaining both to the hyoidean arch and the mandible or lowerjaw; as, the hyomandibular bone or cartilage, a segment of the hyoidarch which connects the lower jaw with the skull in fishes.-- n.
An harpooner. Grabb.
Habitude; mode of life; general appearance.
A little hook.
The posterior of the three principal divisions of the brain,including the epencephalon and metencephalon. Sometimes restricted tothe epencephalon only.

A variety of the domestic dog, usually having large, droopingears, esp. one which hunts game by scent, as the foxhound,bloodhound, deerhound, but also used for various breeds of fleethunting dogs, as the greyhound, boarhound, etc.Hounds and greyhounds, mongrels, spaniels, curs. Shak.
Rough; uneven; causing one to hobble; as a hobbly road.
An umbelliferous plant of the genus Sison (S.Amomum); -- socalled because used to cure a swelling called a hone.
One who loves horses. Holmes.

An instrument consisting of a mirror moved by clockwork, bywhich a sunbeam is made apparently stationary, by being steadilydirected to one spot during the whole of its diurnal period; also, ageodetic heliotrope.
Having no horn.
A humming bird.
A harbinger. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Dull; stupid. [Obs.]
Pertaining to homology; having a structural affinity proceedingfrom, or base upon, that kind of relation termed homology.-- Ho`mo*log"ic*al*ly, adv.

To set the cock of (a firearm) at the first notch. To go offhalfcocked. (a) To be discharged prematurely, or with the trigger athalf cock; -- said of a firearm. (b) To do or say something withoutdue thought or care. [Colloq. or Low]
Altrices.
Full of heed; regarding with care; cautious; circumspect;attentive; vigilant. Shak.-- Heed"ful*ly, adv.-- Heed"ful*ness, n.
Same as Histology.
See under Blast.
Pertaining to Hybla, an ancient town of Sicily, famous for itsbees.
A musical note produced by a number of vibrations which is amultiple of the number producing some other; an overtone. SeeHarmonics.
See Halibut.
Trembling of the heart; trepidation; fear.In many an hour of danger and heartquake. Hawthorne.
Home. [Scot. & O. Eng.]
Of or pertaining to the hypophysis; pituitary.
A figure by which the ordinary course of thought is inverted inexpression, and the last put first; -- called also hysteron proteron.
A plant which aids, shelters, or protects another plant in itsgrowth, as those which are used for nurse crops.
Having no hood.
Passage of urine mingled with blood.
A small, flat, wind instrument of music, in which the notes areproduced by the vibration of free metallic reeds.

A Scotch pudding made of the heart, liver, lights, etc., of asheep or lamb, minced with suet, onions, oatmeal, etc., highlyseasoned, and boiled in the stomach of the same animal; minced headand pluck. [Written also haggiss, haggess, and haggies.]
A large rope made of three strands each containing many yarns.
See Cinch (the game).
Equipment; qualification. [Obs.] Bacon.
Under the tail; -- applied to the bones which support thecaudal fin rays in most fishes.
A band round the crown of a hat; sometimes, a band of blackcloth, crape, etc., worn as a badge of mourning.
An Israelitish woman.
Same as Hæmochromometer.
The histronic art; stageplaying. W. Black.
A place where herons breed.
Imperfectly learned.
An instrument or machine for showing when the sun arrived atthe tropics and equinoctial line.
One versed in histology.
Same as Homoeomeria. [Obs.] Cudworth.
Full of spirit or natural fire; haughty; courageous; impetuous;not brooking restraint or opposition.
Home-returning; -- used specifically of carrier pigeons.
One who hangs another; esp., one who makes a business ofhanging; a public executioner; -- sometimes used as a term ofreproach, without reference to office. Shak.
Applied to coarse cloth made of undyed wool, formerly worn byScotch peasants. [Scot.]
One who higgles.
See Henbane. [Obs.] Shak.
The first six books of the Old Testament.
The state or quality of being hybrid.
Having the nasal bones contiguous.
The condition of having homogonous flowers.
From hence. [Obs.]

One of the race of horses described by Swift in his imaginarytravels of Lemuel Gulliver. The Houyhnhnms were endowed with reasonand noble qualities; subject to them were Yahoos, a race of bruteshaving the form and all the worst vices of men.
One who navigates a hoy.A common hoyman to carry goods by water for hire. Hobart.
The larva of a botfly.
A short note, equal to one fourth of a semiquaver, or thesixty-fourth part of a whole note.
In a hankering manner.
A storm accompanied with hail; a shower of hail.
The act of harmonizing.
A salt formed by the union of hydrotelluric acid and the base.
Of or pertaining to the liver and gall bladder; as, thehepatocystic ducts.
An iron bucket for hoisting coal or ore. Raymond.
To cough faintly and frequently, or in a short, broken manner;as, a hacking cough.
Of an excitable or irritable temperament; irascible. Milton.
To usher in; to be a harbinger of. "Thus did the star ofreligious freedom harbinger the day." Bancroft.
Knapweed.
Henchman. [Obs.]
Like or pertaining to the porcupines.
Spread over the surface of the ground; procumbent. Gray.
A word used as a shout of joy, exultation, approbation, orencouragement.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Have.
The science which treats of the complex relations of livingcreatures to other organisms, and to their surrounding conditionsgenerally. St. George Mivart.
Western; being in the west; occidental. [Poetic] Milton.
To inherit; to succeed to. [R.]One only daughter heired the royal state. Dryden.
An extensive division of ganoids, including the gar pike,bowfin, etc.; the bony ganoids. See Illustration in Appendix.
, 2d pers. sing. pres. of. Fave, contr. of havest. [Archaic]
A short line used in drawing and engraving, especially inshading and denoting different surfaces, as in map drawing. SeeHatching.
An honorary payment, usually in recognition of services forwhich it is not usual or not lawful to assign a fixed business price.Heumann.
A mounted soldier; a cavalryman.
A process on the posterior side of the tarsometatarsus of manybirds; the calcaneal process.-- Hy`po*tar"sal, a.
A concretion, or kind of bezoar, from the intestines of thehorse.
Having seven angles.
The quality of being humble; humility; meekness.
See Daddy longlegs, 1.
The wild ass of Persia.
Confirmation or ratification (as of something otherwise nulland void), by a court or a grantor.
One who hypothecates or pledges anything as security for therepayment of money borrowed.
Of or relating to Sir William Herschel; as, the Herscheliantelescope.
See Here, pron. Chaucer.

Pertaining to, or resembling, the plants called Hepaticæ, orscale mosses and liverworts. Hepatic duct (Anat.), any biliary duct;esp., the duct, or one of the ducts, which carries the bile from theliver to the cystic and common bile ducts. See Illust., underDigestive.-- Hepatic gas (Old Chem.), sulphureted hydrogen gas.-- Hepatic mercurial ore, or Hepatic cinnabar. See under Cinnabar.
Of or pertaining to, or in the form of, a helix; spiral; as, ahelical staircase; a helical spring.-- Hel"i*cal*ly, adv.

An eel-like marine marsipobranch (Myxine glutinosa), allied tothe lamprey. It has a suctorial mouth, with labial appendages, and asingle pair of gill openings. It is the type of the orderHyperotpeta. Called also hagfish, borer, slime eel, sucker, andsleepmarken.
Extra hazard; chance; accident; random.We take our principles at haphazard, upon trust. Locke.
A common herb of the Mint family (Brunela vulgaris), destituteof active properties, but anciently thought a panacea.
Full of harm; injurious; hurtful; mischievous. " Most harmfulhazards." Strype. --Harm"ful*ly, adv.-- Harm"ful*ness, n.
With a harsh, grating sound or voice.
A raised part of the floor of a large room; a platform for araised table or throne. See Dais.

A speech addressed to a large public assembly; a popularoration; a loud address a multitude; in a bad sense, a noisy orpompous speech; declamation; ranting.Gray-headed men and grave, with warriors mixed, Assemble, andharangues are heard. Milton.
The science of water, its properties, phenomena, anddistribution over the earth's surface.
In a manner to excite horror; dreadfully; terribly.
An appearance as of a halo of light, surround the edges of darkobject
Entrails of a deer. [Written also umbles.] Johnson.
Same as Hemadynamics.

Pertaining to, or compounded of, chlorine and hydrogen gas; as,hydrochloric acid; chlorhydric. Hydrochloric acid (Chem.), hydrogenchloride; a colorless, corrosive gas, HCl, of pungent, suffocatingodor. It is made in great quantities in the soda process, by theaction of sulphuric acid on common salt. It has a great affinity forwater, and the commercial article is a strong solution of the gas inwater. It is a typical acid, and is an indispensable agent incommercial and general chemical work. Called also muriatic, andchlorhydric, acid.
A female huckster.
Half a poetic verse or line, or a verse or line not completed.
One of the sinuous tracks on the surfaces of many stones, andpopularly considered as worm trails.
A condition of excessive fever; an elevation of temperature ina disease, in excess of the limit usually observed in that disease.
One who hands over or transmits; a conveyer in succession.Dryden.

The old name, in Scotland, for the last day of the year, onwhich children go about singing, and receive a dole of bread orcakes; also, the entertainment given on that day to a visitor, or thegift given to an applicant. [Scot.]
A treatise upon fish or the art of fishing; ichthyology.
Rising higher; ascending.In ever highering eagle circles. Tennyson.
The general appearance and manner of life of a living organism.

The common black, or dark green or brown, variety of amphibole.(See Amphibole.) It belongs to the aluminous division of the species,and is also characterized by its containing considerable iron. Alsoused as a general term to include the whole species. Hornblendeschist (Geol.), a hornblende rock of schistose structure.

A symbolical acknowledgment made by a feudal tenant to, and inthe presence of, his lord, on receiving investiture of fee, or comingto it by succession, that he was his man, or vassal; profession offealty to a sovereign.
A neutral organic substance found in the root of the elecampane(Inula helenium), and extracted as a white crystalline or oilymaterial, with a slightly bitter taste.
In a horizontal direction or position; on a level; as, movinghorizontally.

Pertaining to, or derived from, or containing, phosphorus in alower state of oxidation than in phosphoric compounds; as,hypophosphoric acid. Hypophosphoric acid (Chem.), an acid, P2H4O6,produced by the slow oxidation of moist phosphorus, and isolated onlyas a solution in water. It is regarded as a condensation product ofone molecule of phosphoric acid with one of phosphorous acid, bypartial dehydration.
A deception for mockery or mischief; a deceptive trick orstory; a practical joke. Macaulay.
A small black gibbon (Hylobates hoolock), found in themountains of Assam.
A kind of sandal worn by Indians and the lower classesgenerally; --usually used in pl. [Southern U. S. & Mex.]
Capable of being healed.
Originally, a nickname for a member of the conservative sectionof the Democratic party in New York; hence, one opposed to progressin general; a fogy. [Political Cant, U.S.]
One of the Hymenoptera.
Any small shark of the genus Galeus or Mustelus, of which thereare several species, as the smooth houndfish (G. canis), of Europeand America; -- called also houndshark, and dogfish.
Same as Hematin.

An order of hexapod insects having a jointed proboscis,including four sharp stylets (mandibles and maxillæ), for piercing.In many of the species (Heteroptera) the front wings are partiallycoriaceous, and different from the others.

Of or pertaining to Hippocrates, or to his teachings.Hippocratic face Etym: [L. facies Hippocratica], the change producedin the countenance by death, or long sickness, excessive evacuations,excessive hunger, and the like. The nose is pinched, the eyes aresunk, the temples hollow, the ears cold and retracted, the skin ofthe forehead tense and dry, the complexion livid, the lips pendent,relaxed, and cold; -- so called, as having been described byHippocrates. Dunglison.-- Hippocratic oath, an oath said to have been dictated byHippocrates to his disciples. Such an oath is still administered tocandidates for graduation in medicine.
Haughty manner or spirit; haughtiness; pride; arrogance.
See Heteroousian.
The fall dandelion (Leontodon autumnale).
The condition of the Helots or slaves in Sparta; slavery.
One who hybridizes.
The government of an alien. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
The European sand eel. [Scot.]
An Indian monkey. See Entellus. [Written also hoonuman.]
Same as Hyena.
Of or pertaining to the leeches.
A horse that moves with a high step or proud gait; hence, aperson having a proud bearing. [Colloq.]
The driver of a hack or carriage for public hire.
See 1st Himself. [Obs.]
A salt of humic acid.
One who hybridizes.
A hymn. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The science which treats of the liver; a treatise on the liver.
One of the semi-Arians of the 4th century, who held that theSon was of like, but not the same, essence or substance with theFather; -- opposed to homoousian.
A philosopher who treats chiefly of matter; one who adopts orteaches hylism.
Same as Hemin.
A persulphocyanate. [Obs.]
To make hungry; to famish.
A tobacco pipe, so arranged that the smoke passes throughwater, making a bubbling noise, whence its name. In India, the bulbcontaining the water is often a cocoanut shell.
Pertaining to, or derived from, the ivy (Hedera); as, hedericacid, an acid of the acetylene series.
Homogeneous. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
Having coarse, unattractive or stern features. Smollett.
Hepatic. [R.]
Same as Hydrocephaloid.
One of a degraded and savage race of South Africa, withyellowish brown complexion, high cheek bones, and wooly hair growingin tufts.
Hospitality. [Obs.] Spenser.

A serpent or monster in the lake or marsh of Lerna, in thePeloponnesus, represented as having many heads, one of which, whencut off, was immediately succeeded by two others, unless the woundwas cauterized. It was slain by Hercules. Hence, a terrible monster.Gorgons, and Hydras, and Chimeras dire. Milton.
A pain that affects only one side of the head.

A fabulous monster, with the head and fore quarters of a horsejoined to the tail of a dolphin or other fish (Hippocampusbrevirostris), -- seen in Pompeian paintings, attached to the chariotof Neptune. Fairholt.
The cold-blooded vertebrates. Same as Hematocrya.
Forcible manipulation of a dislocated, stiff, or painful joint.
Heterodactylous.-- n.
Pubescent with coarse or stiff hairs. Gray.
A plant of the genus Cannabis (C. sativa), the fibrous skin orbark of which is used for making cloth and cordage. The name is alsoapplied to various other plants yielding fiber.
Same as Hypoblast.
The for pump in the pit. Raymond.
To record or narrate in the manner of a history; to chronicle.[R.]
An opening for the hoist, or
See Hermaphroditism.
Same as Hedonic, 2.
In promorphology, pertaining to or exhibiting that kind oforganic form, in which the stereometric ground form is a pyramid,with similar poles. See Promorphology.
A siliceous stone, a variety of quartz, closely resemblingflint, but more brittle; -- called also chert.
Made at home; of domestic manufacture; made either in a privatefamily or in one's own country. Locke.
Anæsthesia upon one side of the body.
Strung to a high pitch; spirited; sensitive; as, a high-strunghorse.
The quality of being heady.
The opening by which the two scalæ communicate at the top ofthe cochlea of the ear.
A hæmoscope.
See Odometer.
Heroism. [R.] W. Montagu.
A picrate compound, used as an explosive in blasting.
Hectic fever.
Formed into a hydrate; combined with water.
An aquatic plant; an alga.
A lip, commonly the upper one, having a fissure ofperpendicular division like that of a hare.-- Hare"lipped`, a.
Partly idiomorphic; -- said of rock a portion only of whoseconstituents have a distinct crystalline form.-- Hy*pid`i*o*mor"phic*al*ly, adv.
In a high manner, or to a high degree; very much; as, highlyesteemed.

A large, strong wasp. The European species (Vespa crabro) is ofa dark brown and yellow color. It is very pugnacious, and its stingis very severe. Its nest is constructed of a paperlike material, andthe layers of comb are hung together by columns. The American white-faced hornet (V. maculata) is larger and has similar habits. Hornetfly (Zoöl.), any dipterous insect of the genus Asilus, and alliedgenera, of which there are numerous species. They are large andfierce flies which capture bees and other insects, often larger thanthemselves, and suck their blood. Called also hawk fly, robber fly.-- To stir up a hornet's nest, to provoke the attack of a swarm ofspiteful enemies or spirited critics. [Colloq.]
To form, or surround with, a halo; to encircle with, or aswith, a halo.The fire That haloed round his saintly brow. Sothey.

A genus of plants (herbs, shrubs, or trees), some species ofwhich have large, showy flowers. Some species are cultivated in Indiafor their fiber, which is used as a substitute for hemp. See Althea,Hollyhock, and Manoe.
A variety of barite emitting a fetid odor when rubbed orheated.
See Handsel.
See Harebrained.

An inhabitant or resident; -- a name applied to and denotingfarmers of French descent or origin in Canada, especially in theProvince of Quebec; -- usually in plural.The habitants or cultivators of the soil. Parkman.
Same as Hæmatachometry.

A hoofed quadruped of the genus Equus; especially, the domestichorse (E. caballus), which was domesticated in Egypt and Asia at avery early period. It has six broad molars, on each side of each jaw,with six incisors, and two canine teeth, both above and below. Themares usually have the canine teeth rudimentary or wanting. The horsediffers from the true asses, in having a long, flowing mane, and thetail bushy to the base. Unlike the asses it has callosities, orchestnuts, on all its legs. The horse excels in strength, speed,docility, courage, and nobleness of character, and is used fordrawing, carrying, bearing a rider, and like purposes.
A climbing plant of the genus Cardiospermum, having round seedswhich are marked with a spot like a heart. Loudon.
With a hissing sound.
A kind of country-dance or round. [Obs.] Spenser.
The consecrated wafer, believed to be the body of Christ, whichin the Mass is offered as a sacrifice; also, the bread beforeconsecration.
Authority or dignity; chief place.
In the manner of a hag.
An upward curve or very obtuse angle in the upper surface ofany member, as of a timber laid horizontally; -- the opposite ofcamber.
That method of spelling in which the same letters representdifferent sounds in different words, as in the ordinary Englishorthography; e. g., g in get and in ginger.
The person who takes charge of a locomotive when it is left bythe engineer after a trip.
A stand of wood or iron, with hooks or pegs upon which to hanghats, etc.
Relating to the measurement of the amount of hematin orhemoglobin contained in blood, or other fluids.

Hereditary transmission of the physical and psychical qualitiesof parents to their offspring; the biological law by which livingbeings tend to repeat their characteristics in their descendants. SeePangenesis.
Pertaining to, or involving, homodynamy; as, successive orhomodynamous parts in plants and animals.
In a Hebraistic sense or form.Which is Hebraistically used in the New Testament. Kitto.
Pertaining to the harp; as, harping symphonies. Milton.
Hemiplegia.
See Haulm, straw.

One of various species of fishes of the genus Clupea, andallied genera, esp. the common round or English herring (C. harengus)of the North Atlantic. Herrings move in vast schools, coming inspring to the shores of Europe and America, where they are salted andsmoked in great quantities. Herring gull (Zoöl.), a large gull whichfeeds in part upon herrings; esp., Larus argentatus in America, andL. cachinnans in England. See Gull.-- Herring hog (Zoöl.), the common porpoise.-- King of the herrings. (Zoöl.) (a) The chimæra (C. monstrosa)which follows the schools of herring. See Chimæra. (b) The opah.
Carefully; in shipshape style.
Of this; concerning this; from this; hence.Hereof comes it that Prince Harry is valiant. Shak.
Causing intense grief; overpowering with anguish; verydistressing.
One who believes in the theory of spontaneous generation, orheterogenesis. Bastian.

Of or pertaining to the blood; sanguine; brownish red. Hæmaticacid (Physiol.), a hypothetical acid, supposed to be formed fromhemoglobin during its oxidation in the lungs, and to have the powerof freeing carbonic acid from the sodium carbonate of the serum.Thudichum.
Elated. Young.
Of a blood-red color; crimson; (Bot.) brownish red.

Heath. [Scot.]Gorse and grass And heather, where his footsteps pass, The brighterseem. Longfellow.Heather bell (Bot.), one of the pretty subglobose flowers of twoEuropean kinds of heather (Erica Tetralix, and E. cinerea).
See Herborize.
One who is extravagant in pretensions, opinions, or manners.Swift.
Destitute of haze. Tyndall.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, ivy.
The process of washing ore, or of uncovering mineral veins, bya heavy discharge of water from a reservoir; flushing; -- also calledbooming.
Destitute of heat; cold. Beau. & Fl.
A hedge bill. See under Hedge.
The act of becoming, or state of being, a hydrate. Water ofhydration (Chem.), water chemically combined with some substance toform a hydrate; -- distinguished from water of crystallization.
The basking or liver shark; -- called also homer. See Livershark, under Liver.
Same as Hæmatachometer.
Having six feet.-- n. (Zoöl.)
A stone used by seamen for scrubbing the decks of ships.Totten.
Having all the planes required by complete symmetry, -- inopposition to hemihedral.
To as, to hash meat. Hudibras.
Pertaining or appropriate to a housewife; domestic; economical;prudent.A good sort of woman, ladylike and housewifely. Sir W. Scott.
Certain prayers to be repeated at stated times of the day, asmatins and vespers.
A genus of plants, generally with dotted leaves and yellowflowers; -- called also St. John's-wort.

A mercantile establishment or factory for foreign trade inChina, as formerly at Canton; a succession of offices connected by acommon passage and used for business or storage. Hong merchant, oneof the few Chinese merchants who, previous to the treaty of 1842,formed a guild which had the exclusive privilege of trading withforeigners.

Thoughtless; giddy; flighty; also, haughty; patronizing; as, tobe in hoity-toity spirits, or to assume hoity-toity airs; used alsoas an exclamation, denoting surprise or disapprobation, with somedegree of contempt.Hoity-toity! What have I to do with dreams Congreve.
Causing no loss of light; -- applied to reflectors which throwback the rays of light without perceptible loss.
A composer or compiler of hymns; one versed in hymnology.Busby.
A neuropterous insect of the genus Hemerobius, and alliedgenera.

In an equal part or degree; in some paas, half-colored, halfdone, half-hearted, half persuaded, half conscious. "Half loth andhalf consenting." Dryden.Their children spoke halfin the speech of Ashdod. Neh. xiii. 24
Capable of being, or deserving to be, hated; odious;detestable.
A semitranslucent variety of opal that becomes translucent ortransparent on immersion in water.
Same as Gorgerin.
Curled; spiral; helicoid; -- applied esp. to certain arteriesof the penis.

Tending to remove or separate water; eliminating water.Hydrolytic agents, such as sulphuric acid or caustic alkali. Encyc.Brit.Hydrolitic ferment (Physiol. Chem.), a ferment, enzyme, or chemicalferment, which acts only in the presence of water, and which causesthe substance acted upon to take up a molecule of water. Thus,diastase of malt, ptyalin of saliva, and boiling dilute sulphuricacid all convert starch by hydration into dextrin and sugar. Nearlyall of the digestive ferments are hydrolytic in their action.
The branch of physical science which treats of the geographicaldistribution of rain.
Same as Hastate. Gray.
A derivative of urea, C3H4N2O2, obtained from allantion, as awhite, crystalline substance, with a sweetish taste; -- called alsoglycolyl urea.
Wholesome. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An intestinal worm, or wormlike intestinal parasite; one of theHelminthes.
An instrument with long iron teeth set in a board, forcleansing flax or hemp from the tow, hards, or coarse part; a kind oflarge comb; -- called also hackle and heckle.
A bargelike vessel with steel hull, large hatchways, and coaltransporters, for coaling war vessels from its own hold or from othercolliers.
The denuded stems or stalks of such crops as buckwheat and thecereal grains, beans, etc.; straw.
Same as Helicoid.-- Hel`i*coid"al*ly, adv.
Hearty; heartily. [Obs.] Chaucer.
See Eccentric, and V-hook.
A solid having forty-eight equal triangular faces.

An important ore of iron, the sesquioxide, so called because ofthe red color of the powder. It occurs in splendent rhombohedralcrystals, and in massive and earthy forms; -- the last called redocher. Called also specular iron, oligist iron, rhombohedral ironore, and bloodstone. See Brown hematite, under Brown.
A body formed from bilirubin, identical with urobilin.
A condition of the blood, characterized by an abnormally largeamount of fibrin, as in many inflammatory diseases.
A measure of weight, containing a hundred grams, or about 3.527ounces avoirdupois.
An extract of hops.
One of the Hymenoptera.
A supposed compound of hydrofluoris acid and a base; afluoride. [Archaic]
Having no hedge.
Of or pertaining to an extensive forest in Germany, of whichthere are still portions in Swabia and the Hartz mountains.
A bully; a blusterer. Hudibras.
A water nymph.
One who hangs on, or sticks to, a person, place, or service; adependent; one who adheres to others' society longer than he iswanted. Goldsmith.
Hypochondria. [Colloq.]
Homology of the germinal layers.

Appearance of the moon when increasing, or in the form of acrescent. J. Gregory. Letters of horning (Scots Law), the process orauthority by which a person, directed by the decree of a court ofjustice to pay or perform anything, is ordered to comply therewith.Mozley & W.
A combining form from Gr. "omo`s, one and the same, common,joint.
Having half as many (three) carboxyl radicals as mellitic acid;-- said of an organic acid.

Formerly, one of the four terms of the courts of common law inEngland, beginning on the eleventh of January and ending on thethirty-first of the same month, in each year; -- so called from thefestival of St. Hilary, January 13th.
A harquebus, of which the but was bent down or hooked forconvenience in taking aim. [Written also haguebut and hackbuss.]
After the manner of the Hebrews or of the Hebrew language.
The art or office of a herald; the art, practice, or science ofrecording genealogies, and blazoning arms or ensigns armorial; also,of marshaling cavalcades, processions, and public ceremonies.
The quality or state of being human.
A Linnæan class of plants having six stamens.
Blood formative; -- applied to a substance in early fetal life,which breaks up gradually into blood vessels.
Same as Hematoglobin.
Shaped like a helmet; galeate. See Illust. of Galeate.
An instrument for determining the depth of the sea water by itspressure.
Heroic. [R.] Spectator.-- He*ro"ic*al*ly, adv.-- He*ro"ic*al*ness, n.
The possession of a homocercal tail.
Wide and general destruction; devastation; waste.As for Saul, he made havoc of the church. Acts viii. 3.Ye gods, what havoc does ambition make Among your works! Addison.
In Turkey and other Oriental countries, a porter or burdenbearer; specif., in Western India, a palanquin bearer.
The property of crystallizing hemihedrally.
See Dartrous diathesis, under Dartrous.
Of or pertaining to Homer, the most famous of Greek poets;resembling the poetry of Homer. Homeric verse, hexameter verse; -- socalled because used by Homer in his epics.
A horizontal dislocation in a metallic lode, taking place at anintersection with another lode.
