. See under Hydro-.
Partly crystalline; -- said of rock which consists of crystalsimbedded in a glassy ground mass.
Wrought with severe labor; elaborate; studied. Swift.
A binary compound containing hydrogen; a hydride. [R.] SeeHydride.
One who harrows.

Any bee of the genus Apis, which lives in communities andcollects honey, esp. the common domesticated hive bee (Apismellifica), the Italian bee (A. ligustica), and the Arabiab bee (A.fasciata). The two latter are by many entomologists considered onlyvarieties of the common hive bee. Each swarm of bees consists of alarge number of workers (barren females), with, ordinarily, one queenor fertile female, but in the swarming season several young queens,and a number of males or drones, are produced.
An extensive order of Hydrozoa or Acalephæ. [Written alsoHydroida.]
A term applied to a lachrymal gland on the inner side of theorbit of many animals which have a third eyelid, or nictitatingmembrane. See Nictitating membrane, under Nictitate.
Heavy; dull. [Prov.]
A bryozoan of the genus Flustra.
Beneath the axis of the skeleton; subvertebral; hyposkeletal.
A fossil bivalve mollusk of the genus Hippurites, of manyspecies, having a conical, cup-shaped under valve, with a flattishupper valve or lid. Hippurites are found only in the Cretaceousrocks.
Plainly; inelegantly. [R.]

An electro-negative element or radical, which, by combinationwith a metal, forms a haloid salt; especially, chlorine, bromine, andiodine; sometimes, also, fluorine and cyanogen. See Chlorine family,under Chlorine.
An exclamation denoting surprise, or contempt, doubt, etc.

One who lives either north or south of the tropics, ascontrasted with one who lives on the other side of them; -- so calledbecause at noon the shadows always fall in opposite directions (theone northward, the other southward).

One of the lessons from the Nebiim (or Prophets) read in theJewish synagogue on Sabbaths, feast days, fasts, and the ninth of Ab,at the end of the service, after the parashoth, or lessons from theLaw. Such a practice is evidenced in Luke iv.17 and Acts xiii.15.
A irrevocable Turkish decree countersigned by the sultan.
A person affected with hypochondriasis.He had become an incurable hypochondriac. Macaulay.
Humiliating; humbling. "Humiliant thoughts." [R.] Mrs.Browning.
The aqueous vapor of the entire atmosphere.
The central chapel of the three forming the sanctuary of aCoptic church. It contains the high altar, and is usually closed byan embroidered curtain.
In a hapless, unlucky manner.
To furnish with a helve, as an ax.
A hundred times as much or as many.He shall receive as hundredfold now in this time. Mark x. 30.
Pertaining to Hegelianism.-- n.
Having a broad hem separated from the body of the article by aline of open work; as, a hemistitched handkerchief.
Stone forming the hearth; hence, the fireside; home.Chords of memory, stretching from every battlefield and patriot graveto every living heart and hearthstone. A. Lincoln.
One who determines the conditions of a handicap.
A condition of overgrowth or excessive development of an organor part; -- the opposite of atrophy.
To mind; to regard with care; to take notice of; to attend to;to observe.With pleasure Argus the musician heeds. Dryden.
A corner. [Obs.]Lurking in hernes and in lanes blind. Chaucer.
Same as Homoplast.
Any medusa or jellyfish which is produced by budding from ahydroid. They are called also Craspedota, and naked-eyed medusæ.
The feast of All Saints, or Allhallows.To speak puling, like a beggar at Hallowmas. Shak.
One who cries out or gives an alarm; specifically, a balker; aconder. See Balker.
A shed or hovel for cattle. [Prov. Eng.] Wright.
Relating to, or connected with, the hypoblast; as, the hypoicsac.
A method of securing a good draught in chimneys by covering thetop, leaving openings in the sides, or by carrying up two of thesides higher than the other two. [Written also hovelling.]
Designating a light and elegant style developed in Englandunder George III., chiefly by Messrs. A.Heppelwhite & Co.
See Hatchel.

A thorny tree or shrub of the genus Lawsonia (L. alba). Thefragrant white blossoms are used by the Buddhists in religiousceremonies. The powdered leaves furnish a red coloring matter used inthe East to stain the hails and fingers, the manes of horses, etc.
See Howdah.
A hold in which an arm of one contestant is held twisted andbent behind his back by his opponent.
Struck with horror; horrified.Blank and horror-stricken faces. C. Kingsley.
An instrument to measure the velocity of a liquid current bythe force of its impact.
A harvesting ant.
The mansion of a heavenly body. [Obs.]
A collection of specimens of plants, dried and preserved, andarranged systematically; an herbarium.
A believer in, or practitioner of, homeopathy. [Written alsohomoepathist.]
Harmonizing; irenic. Gladstone.
Shaped like a snail shell; pertaining to the Helicidæ, or Snailfamily. Helicoid parabola (Math.), the parabolic spiral.
A saddlecloth; a housing. [Obs.] Dryden.
That branch of moral philosophy which treats of the relation ofduty to pleasure; the science of practical, positive enjoyment orpleasure. J. Grote.
One of the great tendons situated in each side of the ham, orspace back of the knee, and connected with the muscles of the back ofthe thigh.
An effusion of watery liquid into the cavity of a joint.
A hydropathist.
Having the end hooked or curved.
Of or pertaining to Hanover or its people, or to the House ofHanover in England.
Pertaining to a hierarchy.-- Hi`er*arch`ic*al*ly, adv.
Of or pertaining to hyperkinesis.
A term of reproach, implying that one is fit to be hanged.[Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
Pertaining to, or denoting, a compound consisting of a doublefluoride of hydrogen and silicon; silicofluoric. See Silicofluoric.
The natural abode, locality or region of an animal or plant.
Moldy; musty. [Obs.] Granmer.
Seeing imperfectly; having weak discernment. Bacon.
Having a hump, as the back.
Having all the florets in the same flower head of the samecolor.
To bring to mind by a slight mention or remote allusion; tosuggest in an indirect manner; as, to hint a suspicion.Just hint a fault and hesitate dislike. Pope.
To decide to be heresy or a heretic; to denounce as a hereticor heretical. Bp. Hall.And let no one be minded, on the score of my neoterism, to hereticateme. Fitzed. Hall.
The sunfish (Mola).
To combine with hydrogen; to treat with, or subject to theaction of, hydrogen; to reduce; -- contrasted with oxidize.
A tool used by turners in metal, having a bend forming a heelnear the cutting end.
Command; precept; injunction. [Archaic] See Behest. "At thyhest." Shak.Let him that yields obey the victor's hest. Fairfax.Yet I thy hest will all perform, at full. Tennyson.
A compound radical, C6H13, regarded as the essential residue ofhexane, and a related series of compounds.
Suitable to a funeral.If you listen to David's harp, you shall hear as many hearselike airsas carols. Bacon.
The kestrel.
One who dwells in the same house with another. R. Browning.
The act or art of riding, and of training and managing horses;manege.
The act of breaking open and entering, with a feloniouspurpose, the dwelling house of another, whether done by day or night.See Burglary, and To break a house, under Break.
A genus of composite plants, with shining, commonly white oryellow, or sometimes reddish, radiated involucres, which are oftencalled "everlasting flowers."
Two in a year; semiannual.-- adv. Twice in a year; semiannually.
The knowledge of herbs.
The true, or six-legged, insects; insects other than myriapodsand arachnids.
Ability; aptitude. [Obs.] Robynson. (More's Utopia).
See Hals.
A light, with a powerful reflector, placed at the head of alocomotive, or in front of it, to throw light on the track at night,or in going through a dark tunnel.
An American sole (Achirus lineatus, or A. achirus), related tothe European sole, but of no market value.
Hysteria.
The man at the helm; a steersman.
To hike one's self; specif., to go with exertion or effort; totramp; to march laboriously. [Dial. or Colloq.] "If you persist inheaving and hiking like this."  Kipling.
In a hungry manner; voraciously. Dryden.
A heart. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Relating to homodermy; originating from the same germ layer.

To make holy; to set apart for holy or religious use; toconsecrate; to treat or keep as sacred; to reverence. "Hallowed bethy name." Matt. vi. 9.Hallow the Sabbath day, to do no work therein. Jer. xvii. 24.His secret altar touched with hallowed fire. Milton.In a larger sense . . . we can not hallow this ground [Gettysburg].A. Lincoln.
The state or quality of being horrible; dreadfulness;hideousness.The horribleness of the mischief. Sir P. Sidney.
Relating to, or connected with, hydrocephalus, or dropsy of thebrain.
The lower group of the Wealden formation; -- so called from itsdevelopment around Hastings, in Sussex, England.
The crested curassow; -- called also royal pheasant. SeeCurassow.
Half; by the part. [Obs.] Chaucer.-- n.
Pertaining to, or having, a hobby or whim; eccentric;whimsical.[Colloq.] Sterne.
A loud noise of many confused voices; a tumult; uproar. Milton.This hubbub of unmeaning words. Macaulay.
One skilled in the hydrography; one who surveys, or draws mapsor charts of, the sea, lakes, or other waters, with the adjacentshores; one who describes the sea or other waters. Boyle.
See Hæma-.
Having the ganglia of the nervous system symmetricallyarranged, as in certain invertebrates; -- opposed to heterogangliate.
One who hurls, or plays at hurling.
Habitude. [Obs.]
A small piece or silver of skin which hangs loose, near theroot of finger nail. Holloway.
Serving to moisten the eye; -- sometimes applied to thelachrymal ducts.
To deceive; to impose; to cajole; to hoax.
See Hæmacytometer.
Having six columns in front; -- said of a portico or temple.-- n.
The office of an historiographer. Saintsbury.
An imagined space having more than three dimensions.
Laws relating to the equilibrium of the blood in the bloodvessels.
A reddish brown or violet crystalline substance, C16H12O6, gotfrom hematoxylin by partial oxidation, and regarded as analogous tothe phthaleins.
In a harsh manner; gratingly; roughly; rudely.'T will sound harshly in her ears. Shak.
Pressed while heat is applied. See Hotpress, v. t.
A vitiated or morbid animal fluid, such as often causes aneruption on the skin. "A body full of humors." Sir W. Temple.
Without a heel.
To render (a building) unfit for habitation, by long continueduse as a hospital.
Same as Hematinometer.

Deviating from the normal, perfect, or mature form; havingdifferent forms at different stages of existence, or in differentindividuals of the same species; -- applied especially to insects inwhich there is a wide difference of form between the larva and theadult, and to plants having more than one form of flower.
Of or pertaining to mercury; containing, or impregnated with,mercury. [R.]
A machine in which hay is chopped short, as fodder for cattle.
See Hyloist.
A measure of two hanks of linen thread. [Scot.] [Written alsohasp.] Knight.
That which is hard to hear, as toil, privation, injury,injustice, etc. Swift.
The condition of being heterostyled.
A man who lets horses and carriages for hire.
Ridden by a hag or witch; hence, afflicted with nightmare.Beattie. Cheyne.
Having abundance of mettle; ardent; full of fire; as, a high-mettled steed.

Variation in arrangement from that existing in a normal form;heterogenous arrangement or structure, as, in botany, the deviationin position of the organs of a plant, from the ordinary or typicalarrangement.
The slender recoil spring which regulates the motion of thebalance in a timepiece.
See Semitone.
Same as Hydrobromide.
Like a hag; ugly; wrinkled.But on both did haggish age steal on. Shak.
One who throws the harpoon.
High relish or flavor; high seasoning.
United by hyphens; hyphened; as, a hyphenated or hyphened word.
Out of the combat; disabled from fighting.
A soldier armed with a hagbut or arquebus. [Written alsohackbutter.] Froude.
Inflated, as with conceit.
A part of the breastbone. [Obs.]He feeleth through the herte-spon the pricke. Chaucer.
A liquor consisting of honey diluted in water, and afterfermentation called mead.
An alkaloid found in the plant Peganum harmala. It formsbitter, yellow salts.
Having six-rayed spicules; belonging to the Hexactinellinæ.
A small hole in a boiler for the insertion of the hand incleaning, etc. Hand-hole plate, the cover of a hand-hole.

Any one of several isometric hydrocarbons, C7H16, of theparaffin series (nine are possible, four are known); -- so calledbecause the molecule has seven carbon atoms. Specifically, acolorless liquid, found as a constituent of petroleum, in the tar oilof cannel coal, etc.
The asarabacca.
Changed into a hectocotylus; having a hectocotylis.
A composition made from blood, mixed with mineral or vegetablesubstances, used for making buttons, door knobs, etc.
One of a breed of cattle originating in Herefordshire, England.The Herefords are good working animals, and their beef-producingquality is excellent.
A fish. See Hornfish.
An accumulation of urine in the pelvis of the kidney,occasioned by obstruction in the urinary passages.
A lateral and backward-projecting process on the dorsal side ofa vertebra.-- Hy`per*ap`o*phys"i*al, a.
One who assists in saving life and property from a wreck; acoast boatman. [Written also hoveller.] [Prov. Eng.] G. P. R. James.
The quality of being hospitable; hospitality. Barrow.
A disease of the eyes, in consequence of which a person can seeclearly or without pain only by daylight or a strong artificiallight; day sight.
Wormlike; vermiform.
Having the two ends modified with unlike planes; -- said of acrystal.
In the phrase on one's hunkers, in a squatting or crouchingposition. [Scot. & Local, U. S.]
Presenting hemihedral forms, in which all the sectants havehalt the whole number of planes. Dana.
Unequal growth of a cell, or of a part of a plant.

Intense publicity for a future event, performed in a showy orexcessively dramatic manner suggesting an importance not justified bythe event; as, the hype surrounding the superbowl is usuallyludicrous.[PJC]
A hind in the year of its age. [Eng.] Wright.
A ring or eye of rope, wood, or iron, attached to the edge of asail and running on a stay.
The white particles formed by the congelation of dew; whitefrost. [Written also horefrost. See Hoar, a.]He scattereth the hoarfrost like ashes. Ps. cxlvii. 16.
Pertaining to, or resembling, the Hebrew language or idiom.
Same as Heptylene.
Homodynamous. Quain.

A large, northern, marine flatfish (Hippoglossus vulgaris), ofthe family Pleuronectidæ. It often grows very large, weighing morethan three hundred pounds. It is an important food fish. [Writtenalso holibut.]

Belonging to the hyacinth; resemblingthe hyacinth; in colorlike the hyacinth. Milton.His curling locks like hyacinthine flowers. Cowper.The hyacinthine boy, for whom Morn well might break and April bloom.Emerson.
Of or pertaining to hypothenuse. [R.]
Hyperdicrotic.
The whole interior portion of a vessel below the lower deck, inwhich the cargo is stowed.
One who practices hydropathy; a water-cure doctor.
The offspring of the union of two distinct species; an animalor plant produced from the mixture of two species. See Mongrel.
See Here, pron. Chaucer.
An American herbivorous dinosaur of great size, allied to theiguanodon. It is found in the Cretaceous formation.
A genus of leeches, including the common medicinal leech. SeeLeech.
A division of ciliated Infusoria in which the cilia cover onlythe under side of the body.

To become or to keep still or quiet; to become silent; -- esp.used in the imperative, as an exclamation; be still; be silent orquiet; make no noise.Hush, idle words, and thoughts of ill. Keble.But all these strangers' presence every one did hush. Spenser.
A harbor. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
By hap, chance, luck, or accident; perhaps; it may be.Lest haply ye be found even to fight against God. Acts v. 39.
A writer of hymns.
An order of fishes, comprising the flounders, halibut, sole,etc., having the body and head asymmetrical, with both eyes on oneside. Called also Heterosomata, Heterosomi.
In a handfast or publicly pledged manner. [Obs.] Holinshed.
To love less, relatively. Luke xiv. 26.
Of or relating to hierophants or their teachings.
Pertaining to, or suited for, a hermit. Coventry.
The art or process of assaying or reducing ores by means ofliquid reagents.
Home. Chaucer.
Divination by means of water, -- practiced by the ancients.
To stammer; to speak unintelligibly; to prevaricate.[Prov.Eng.] Halliwell.
One who has high and controlling authority in sacred things;the chief of a sacred order; as, princely hierarchs. Milton.
To use the Greek language; to play the Greek; to Grecize.
The horned or piked dogfish. See Dogfish. Dutch hoe, one havingthe blade set for use in the manner of a spade.-- Horse hoe, a kind of cultivator.
In a heathenish manner.
A sort of breeches. [Obs..] Chaucer.

Pertaining to, or containing, hydrogen; as, hydric oxide.Hydric dioxide. (Chem.) See Hydrogen dioxide, under Hydrogen.-- Hydric oxide (Chem.), water.-- Hydric sulphate (Chem.), hydrogen sulphate or sulphuric acid.
A treatise on heresy.

The absence of correspondence, or relation, in type ofstructure; lack of analogy between parts, owing to their beingcomposed of different elements, or of like elements in differentproportions; variation in structure from the normal form; -- opposedto homology.

One of numerous species and genera of rapacious birds of thefamily Falconidæ. They differ from the true falcons in lacking theprominent tooth and notch of the bill, and in having shorter and lesspointed wings. Many are of large size and grade into the eagles.Some, as the goshawk, were formerly trained like falcons. In a moregeneral sense the word is not infrequently applied, also, to truefalcons, as the sparrow hawk, pigeon hawk, duck hawk, and prairiehawk.
A diviner of ancient Rome. Same as Aruspice.
A tub lashed to a vessel's deck and containing saltedprovisions for daily use; -- called also harness tub. W. C. Russell.

Of or pertaining to the hypogastrium or the hypogastric region.Hypogastric region. (a) The lower part of the abdomen. (b) Anarbitrary division of the abdomen below the umbilical and between thetwo iliac regions.
A native of either ancient or modern Greece; a Greek. Brewer.
Contraction of only one ventricle of the heart.
The master or head of a family; one who occupies a house withhis family.Towns in which almost every householder was an English Protestant.Macaulay.Compound householder. See Compound, a.
Harshness or roughness of voice or sound, due to mucuscollected on the vocal cords, or to swelling or looseness of thecords.

The act or practice of a hypocrite; a feigning to be what oneis not, or to feel what one does not feel; a dissimulation, or aconcealment of one's real character, disposition, or motives;especially, the assuming of false appearance of virtue or religion; asimulation of goodness.Hypocrisy is the necessary burden of villainy. Rambler.Hypocrisy is the homage vice pays to virtue. La Rochefoucauld (Trans.).
It. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Rooted in the heart. Herbert.
The hematin of blood. [R.]
Cold-blooded.
A halter consisting of a long leather or rope strap andheadstall, -- used for leading or tieing a pack animal. [WesternU.S.]
A hart. [Obs.] Chaucer.
See Horned Owl.
See Hæmatoin.
A reaping hook. Knight.
Of a strong red color.
Probably, the baked berry of the hawthorn tree, that is, coarsefare. See 1st Haw, 2. [Obs.] Chaucer.
With hesitation or doubt.
To lay snares for rabbits. Huloet.
Standing erect, as bristles; covered with bristling points;bristled; bristling.Rough and horrent with figures in strong relief. De Quincey.With bright emblazonry and horrent arms. Milton.
Of or pertaining to the Hebrews, or to the language of theHebrews.
See Hypocritical. Swift.
Of or pertaining to horticulture, or the culture of gardens ororchards.
The condition of being homogamous.
A compound radical, C7H15, regarded as the essential radical ofheptane and a related series of compounds.
Belonging or relating to winter; wintry; winterish. Sir T.Browne.
A young hedgehog. Shak.
Having each of the two flexor tendons of the toes bifid, thebranches of one going to the first and second toes; those of theother, to the third and fourth toes. See Illust. in Append.
The consecrated wafer; the host. [Obs.] Bp. Burnet.
A herdsman. [Obs.]

A helper; a companion; specifically, a wife.In Minorca the ass and the hog are common helpmates, and are yokedtogether in order to turn up the land. Pennant.A waiting woman was generally considered as the most suitablehelpmate for a parson. Macaulay.
A large and valuable food fish (Polyprion prognathus) of NewZealand. It sometimes weighs one hundred pounds or more.
The principles or authority of a hierarchy.The more dominant hierarchism of the West. Milman.
Causing overpowering sorrow.
A fossil coral of the genus Heliolites, having twelve-rayedcells. It is found in the Silurian rocks.

The land or region lying behind the coast district. The term isused esp. with reference to the so-called doctrine of the hinterland,sometimes advanced, that occupation of the coast supports a claim toan exclusive right to occupy, from time to time, the territory lyinginland of the coast.
Highlanders, collectively.

A cyst in which some unicellular organisms temporarily inclosethemselves, from which they emerge unchanged, after a period ofdrought or deficiency of food. In some instances, a process of sporeformation seems to occur within such cysts.

An instrument for measuring the degree of moisture of theatmosphere. Daniell's hygrometer, a form of hygrometer consisting ofa bent glass tube terminating in two bulbs, the one covered withmuslin, the other of black glass, and containing ether and athermometer. Ether being poured on the muslin, the black ball, cooledby the evaporation of the ether within, is soon covered with dew; atthis moment, the inclosed thermometer gives the dew-point, and this,compared with the reading of one in the air, determines the humidity.

An ancient long-handled weapon, of which the head had a pointand several long, sharp edges, curved or straight, and sometimesadditional points. The heads were sometimes of very elaborate form.[Written also halbert.]
Same as Hockday.
Destruction by cutting down. [Obs.]Of whom he makes such havoc and such hew. Spenser.
A land tax. See Hidage.
A claylike mineral, occurring in soft, smooth, amorphousmasses, of a whitish color.

An obstacle formed by turning an ordinary harrow upside down,the frame being buried. Bush harrow, a kind of light harrow made ofbushes, for harrowing grass lands and covering seeds, or to finishthe work of a toothed harrow.-- Drill harrow. See under 6th Drill.-- Under the harrow, subjected to actual torture with a toothedinstrument, or to great affliction or oppression.
Insincere; deceitful; not sound and true; having a cavity ordecayed spot within.
Dress, in general. Shak.
One who heles or covers; hence, a tiler, slater, or thatcher.[Obs.] [Written also heler.] Usher.
A basket made of rushes or flags, as for carrying fish. [Obs.]Spenser.
An outwork composed of two faces, forming a salient angle whosegorge resembles a half-moon; -- now called a ravelin.
Having the bark so close and constricting that it impedes thegrowth; -- said of trees. Bacon.

A writ having for its object to bring a party before a court orjudge; especially, one to inquire into the cause of a person'simprisonment or detention by another, with the view to protect theright to personal liberty; also, one to bring a prisoner into courtto testify in a pending trial. Bouvier.
The branch of botany which treats of water plants.
Of or pertaining to histography.
Characterized by heterogony.-- Het`er*og"o*nous*ly, adv.
Having the limbs on, or directed toward, the ventral or hemalside, as in vertebrates; -- opposed to neuropodous.
A fold of muscous membrane often found at the orifice of thevagina; the vaginal membrane.
See Hagbut.
Wholly. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Horror-stricken; horrified. M. Arnold.
Chinese maritime customs.
One who dresses or cuts hair; a barber.
One who is hired, or who serves for wages; esp., one whosemotive and interest in serving another are wholly gainful; amercenary. "Lewd hirelings." Milton.
See Harmonic suture, under Harmonic. Close harmony, Dispersedharmony, etc. See under Close, Dispersed, etc.-- Harmony of the spheres. See Music of the spheres, under Music.
To relate as history; to chronicle; to historicize. [R.]Evelyn.
To form into a hydrate; to combine with water.
An apparatus for measuring the amount of hemoglobin in a fluid,by comparing it with a solution of known strength and of normalcolor.
A fleshy protuberance on the back of an animal, as a camel orwhale.

A linguistic group of warlike North American Indians, belongingto the same stock as the Algonquins, and including several tribes,among which were the Five Nations. They formerly occupied the regionabout Lakes Erie and Ontario, and the larger part of New York.
The chipping sparrow.
Hoggish character or manners; selfishness; greed; beastliness.Crime and shame And all their hoggery. Mrs. Browning.

To press together promiscuously, from confusion, apprehension,or the like; to crowd together confusedly; to press or hurry indisorder; to crowd.The cattle huddled on the lea. Tennyson.Huddling together on the public square . . . like a herd of panic-struck deer. Prescott.
See Handiwork.

Consecrated to sacred uses; sacerdotal; pertaining to priests.Hieratic character, a mode of ancient Egyptian writing; a modifiedform of hieroglyphics, tending toward a cursive hand and formerlysupposed to be the sacerdotal character, as the demotic was supposedto be that of the people.It was a false notion of the Greeks that of the three kinds ofwriting used by the Egyptians, two -- for that reason calledhieroglyphic and hieratic -- were employed only for sacred, while thethird, the demotic, was employed for secular, purposes. No suchdistinction is discoverable on the more ancient Egyptian monuments;bur we retain the old names founded on misapprehension. W. H. Ward(Johnson's Cyc.).
Having the same center.
See Pituitary body, under Pituitary.
The largest genus of true mosses; feather moss.
Clad or crowned with heath.

The daughters of Hesperus, or Night (brother of Atlas), andfabled possessors of a garden producing golden apples, in Africa, atthe western extremity of the known world. To slay the guarding dragonand get some of these apples was one of the labors of Hercules.Called also Atlantides.
A coarse kind of linen; -- called also harden. [Prov. Eng.]
A composite plant (Erigeron Canadensis), which is a commonweed.
Reaching high or upward; hence, ambitious; aspiring. Shak.
An historian; a writer of history; especially, one appointed ordesignated to write a history; also, a title bestowed by somegovernments upon historians of distinction.

Passing through the different stages in its life history on analternation of hosts, as the common wheat-rust fungus (Pucciniagraminis), and certain other parasitic fungi; -- contrasted withautocious. -- Het`er*o"cism (#), n.
A measure of area, or superficies, containing a hundred ares,or 10,000 square meters, and equivalent to 2.471 acres.
Belonging to the hilum.

The correspondence of common descent; -- a term used tosupersede homology by Lankester, who also used homoplasy to denoteany superinduced correspondence of position and structure in partsembryonically distinct (other writers using the term homoplasmy).Thus, there is homogeny between the fore limb of a mammal and thewing of a bird; but the right and left ventricles of the heart inboth are only in homoplasy with each other, these having arisenindependently since the divergence of both groups from auniventricular ancestor.
A mixed mass; a medley. See Hotchpot. Johnson.

Obtained from the urine of horses; as, hippuric acid. Hippuricacid, a white crystalline substance, containing nitrogen, present inthe urine of herbivorous animals, and in small quantity in humanurine. By the action of acids, it is decomposed into benzoic acid andglycocoll.
To encumber with a handicap in any contest; hence, in general,to place at disadvantage; as, the candidate was heavily handicapped.
One who hugs or embraces.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, homology; as, homologinicqualities, or differences.
In the form of an hyperbola.

One of several species of sea birds of the genus Puffinus;esp., P. major, the greater shearwarter, and P. Stricklandi, theblack hagdon or sooty shearwater; -- called also hagdown, haglin, andhag. See Shearwater.
Expressing a phrase or sentence in a single word, -- as is thecase in the aboriginal languages of America.
The inner or lower layer of the blastoderm; -- called alsoendoderm, entoderm, and sometimes hypoderm. See Illust. ofBlastoderm, Delamination, and Ectoderm.
To criticise with unjust severity; to criticise captiously.
A chief priest; esp., the head of the Jewish priesthood.

Any species or marine hydroids, of the genus Hydractinia andallied genera. These hydroids form, by their rootstalks, a firm,chitinous coating on shells and stones, and esp. on spiral shellsoccupied by hermit crabs. See Illust. of Athecata.
Similarity of form; resemblance in external characters, whilewidely different in fundamental structure; resemblance in geometricground form. See Homophyly, Promorphology.
Having fine, short, and sharp points on the surface; as, thehackly fracture of metallic iron.
One who harangues, or is fond of haranguing; a declaimer.With them join'd all th' harangues of the throng, That thought to getpreferment by the tongue. Dryden.
A player. [R.] Pope.
Having the first and second toes turned backward, as in thetrogons.
See Alomancy.

A violent storm, characterized by extreme fury and suddenchanges of the wind, and generally accompanied by rain, thunder, andlightning; -- especially prevalent in the East and West Indies. Alsoused figuratively.Like the smoke in a hurricane whirl'd. Tennyson.Each guilty thought to me is A dreadful hurricane. Massinger.Hurricane bird (Zoöl.), the frigate bird.-- Hurricane deck. (Naut.) See under Deck.
A glucoside obtained as a white crystalline substance bypartial oxidation of salicin, from a willow (Salix Helix of Linnæus.)
Same as Homotaxis.
One who hypnotizes.
Soft to sweet in speech; persuasive. Shak.
Of pertaining to Hayti.-- n.

A kind of basket, usually of wickerwork, and adapted for thepacking and carrying of articles; a hamper. Hanaper office, an officeof the English court of chancery in which writs relating to thebusiness of the public, and the returns to them, were anciently keptin a hanaper or hamper. Blackstone.
The state of abounding, or being covered, with hair. Johnson.
The state of an heir; succession by inheritance. Burke.
Same as Hæmatic.

A member of any tribe or race of savages who have the custom ofdecapitating human beings and preserving their heads as trophies. TheDyaks of Borneo are the most noted head-hunters.-- Head"-hunt`ing, n.
Any species of the genus Hylobates; a gibbon, or long-armedape. See Gibbon.
Manifesting heliotropism; turning toward the sun.
Producing hysteria; as, the hysterogenicpressure points on thesurface of the body, pressure upon which is said both to produce andarrest an attack of hysteria. De Watteville.
To buzz; to murmur. [Obs.]Huzzing and burring in the preacher's ear. Latimer.
State of being a hoiden.
A bed of earth heated by fermenting manure or other substances,and covered with glass, intended for raising early plants, or fornourishing exotics.
To inclose for mowing; to set aside for grass. "A ground . . .hained in." Holland.
One who is armed with a halberd. Strype.
One who, or a machine which, hummels.
Sameness 9kind or nature; uniformity of structure or material.
Having an excessive proportion of carbonic acid; -- said ofbicarbonates or acid carbonates. [Written also hypercarburetted.]

Of or pertaining to the humerus, or upper part of the arm;brachial. Humeral veil (R. C. Ch.), a long, narrow veil or scarf ofthe same material as the vestments, worn round the shoulders by theofficiating priest or his attendant at Mass, and used to protect thesacred vessels from contact with the hands.
To make hostile; to cause to become an enemy. [Obs.] A. Seward.
The act or practice of feeding on horseflesh.
A heap or pile of hay, usually covered with thatch forpreservation in the open air.
The invocation or worship of saints.
The art, practice, or method of measuring time by hours andsubordinate divisions. "The horometry of antiquity." Sir T. Browne.
One who uses a hatchel.

Containing or derived from nitrogen having a lower valence thanin nitrous compounds. Hyponitrous acid (Chem.), an unstable nitrogenacid, NOH, whose salts are produced by reduction of the nitrates,although the acid itself is not isolated in the free state except asa solution in water; -- called also nitrosylic acid.
The expectoration of blood, due usually to hemorrhage from themucous membrane of the lungs.
A holiday commemorating the expulsion of the Danes, formerlyobserved on the second Tuesday after Easter; -- called also hocktide.[Eng.] [Written also hokeday.]
A genus of small rubiaceous herbs, having tetramerous salveformblue or white flower. There are about twenty species, natives ofNorth America. Also, a plant of this genus.
Same as Hæmaphæin.
A somnambulist. [R.]
One who, or that which, helps, aids, assists, or relieves; as,a lay helper in a parish.Thou art the helper of the fatherless. Ps. x. 14.Compassion . . . oftentimes a helper of evils. Dr. H. More.
Of or pertaining to hydrometeorology, or to rain, clouds,storms, etc.

Pertaining to, or derived from the combination of, hydrogen andcyanogen. Hydrocyanic acid (Chem.), a colorless, mobile, volatileliquid, HCN, having a characteristic peach-blossom odor. It is one ofthe most deadly poisons. It is made by the action of sulphuric acidon yellow prussiate of potassium (potassium ferrocyanide), andchemically resembles hydrochloric and hydrobromic acids. Called alsoprussic acid, hydrogen cyanide, etc.
The concurrence of two vowels in two successive words orsyllables. Pope.
Having hydrocephalus. "Hydrocephalous offspring." G. Eliot.
At, or by reason of, this; as, he was offended hereat. Hooker.
A woman's skirt so scant at the bottom as to restrain freedomof movement after the fashion of a hobble. -- Hob"ble-skirt`ed, a.
See Grasshopper, 2.

That branch of science, or of engineering, which treats offluids in motion, especially of water, its action in rivers andcanals, the works and machinery for conducting or raising it, its useas a prime mover, and the like.
A wood or grove; -- a word used in the composition of manynames, as in Hazlehurst.
A disciple of Hermogenes, and heretical teacher who lived inAfrica near the close of the second century. He ha
An outer garment worn in Europe in the Middle Ages. [Writtenalso heuk and hyke.] [Obs.] Bacon.
Imperfectly or partly heard to the end.And leave half-heard the melancholy tale. Pope.

A white, semisolid, spermaceti-like hydrocarbon, C16H34, of theparaffin series, found dissolved as an important ingredient ofkerosene, and so called because each molecule has sixteen atoms ofcarbon; -- called also hexadecane.
A base, menial wretch.-- a.
The act of harassing, or state of being harassed; worry;annoyance; anxiety.Little harassments which I am led to suspect do occasionally molestthe most fortunate. Ld. Lytton.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, an extinct genus of sharks(Hybodus), especially in the form of the teeth, which consist of aprincipal median cone with smaller lateral ones.
The water cure; a mode of treating diseases by the copious andfrequent use of pure water, both internally and externally.
A tool used by coopers for smoothing and chamfering rheir work,especially the inside of casks.
Eaters of horseflesh.
A combining form fr. Gr. "o`los whole.
To take out the entrails of; to disembowel; as, to hulk a hare.[R.] Beau. & Fl.
Having a syllable or two beyond measure; as, a hypercatalecticverse.
Ardent in temper; violent; rash; impetuous; as, hot-brainedyouth. Dryden.
One half of a shutter made in two parts for closing a porthole.
Having no hat.
A compound of the bichloride of mercury with another chloride.[Obs.]
The negative pole or cathode. [R.]
of Heave. Hove short, Hove to. See To heave a cable short, Toheave a ship to, etc., under Heave.
Room or place in a house; as, to give any one houseroom.
The act of hiding or concealing, or of withholding from view orknowledge; concealment.There was the hiding of his power. Hab. iii. 4.
A constellation of the southern hemisphere, near the southpole.
Pertaining to, or designating, a brown resinous substanceresembling tannin, and extracted from the henna plant; as,hennotannic acid.
A genus of shrubby plants bearing opposite leaves and largeheads of showy flowers, white, or of various colors. H. hortensis,the common garden species, is a native of China or Japan.
A verse which has a redundant syllable or foot; ahypercatalectic verse.

A substance formed from the hematin of blood, by removal of theiron through the action of concentrated sulphuric acid. Two likebodies, called respectively hæmatoporphyrin and hæmatolin, are formedin a similar manner.
A humanist. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A sheep of the second year. [Written also hogrel.] Ash.
To enhance. [Obs.] Lydgate.
A shell of the genus Crepidula; a boat shell. See Boat shell.

An atom whose valence is six, and which can be theoreticallycombined with, substituted for, or replaced by, six monad atoms orradicals; as, sulphur is a hexad in sulphuric acid. Also used as anadjective.
To search for plants, or new species of plants, with a view toclassifying them.He herborized as he traveled. W. Tooke.
One of the great division of fungi, containing those specieswhich have naked spores borne on free or only fasciculate threads. M.J. Berkley.
Born of a hag or witch. Shak.
A half of a spheroid.
A large South African antelope (Alcelaphus caama), formerlymuch more abundant than it is now. The face and legs are marked withblack, the rump with white. [Written also hartebeest, and hartebest.]
Pertaining to, or derived from, heptane; as, heptoic acid.
Having only one form of pistils; -- said of the flowers of someplants. Darwin.
One who renders humane.
A person or thing belonging to a home or to a particularcountry; a native; as, a word which is a homeling. Trench.

A process of hardening the face of steel, as armor plates,invented by Hayward A. Harvey of New Jersey, consisting in theadditional carburizing of the face of a piece of low carbon steel bysubjecting it to the action of carbon under long-continued pressureat a very high heat, and then to a violent chilling, as by a spray ofcold water. This process gives an armor plate a thick surface ofextreme hardness supported by material gradually decreasing inhardness to the unaltered soft steel at the back.

Pertaining to, employed in, or produced by, the evolution ofelectricity by means of a battery in which water or steam is used.Hydro-electric machine (Physics), an apparatus invented by SirWilliam Armstrong of England for generating electricity by the escapeof high-pressure steam from a series of jets connected with a strongboiler, in which the steam is produced.
A long, narrow foot, carried (that is, produced or extending)forward; -- said of dogs.
Same as Holostomatous.
Same as Hydrochloride.
One who hungers; one who longs. Lamb.
A herbalist. Ray.
See Hydrophobia.
A division of ganoid fishes, including the gar pikes andbowfins.-- Hy`o*ga"noid, a.
A small tumor upon the eyelid, resembling a grain of barley; asty.
The work belonging to housekeeping; especially, kitchen work,sweeping, scrubbing, bed making, and the like.
A brush for cleansing and smoothing the hair.
The property possessed by vegetable tissues of absorbing ordischarging moisture according to circumstances.
The practice of imposition.
A huck or hull, as of a nut. [Prov. Eng.] Wright.
Containing sensible moisture; damp; moist; as, a humidair oratmosphere; somewhat wet or watery; as, humid earth; consisting ofwater or vapor.Evening cloud, or humid bow. Milton.
In a hidden manner.
The art or act of composing hymns.
A seigniory or lordship held of the king, on which otherlordships and manors depended. Cowell.
Half-demented; half-witted. [Colloq.]
Same Hemostatic.

To lend aid or assistance; to contribute strength or means; toavail or be of use; to assist.A generous present helps to persuade, as well as an agreeable person.Garth.To help out, to lend aid; to bring a supply.
One who hurts or does harm.I shall not be a hurter, if no helper. Beau. & Fl.
A salt of hypophosphoric acid.
Having six atoms or radicals capable of being replaced byacids; hexatomic; hexavalent; -- said of bases; as, mannite is ahexacid base.
Same as Harl, 2.

Pertaining to, or containing, sulphur, all, or a part, in a lowstate of oxidation. Hyposulphurous acid. (a) Thiosulphuric acid.[Obs.] (b) An acid, H2SO2, obtained by the reduction of sulphurousacid. It is not obtained in the free state, but in an orange-yellowwater solution, which is a strong reducing and bleaching agent.Called also hydrosulphurous acid.

A colorless, liquid hydrocarbon, C6H12, of the ethylene series,produced artificially, and found as a natural product of distillationof certain coals; also, any one several isomers of hexylene proper.Called also hexene.
To shut or fasten with a hasp.

Pertaining to, or derived from, chlorine having a valence lowerthan in chlorous compounds. Hypochlorous acid (Chem.), an acidderived from chlorine, not known in a pure state, but forming varioussalts, called hypochlorites.
Same as Dropsy.
The science of measuring time, or the principles and art ofconstructing instruments for measuring and indicating portions oftime, as clocks, watches, dials, etc.
Quicksilver; mercury.
A man who carries a hod; a mason's tender.
A genus of trees (Celtis) related to the elm, but bearingdrupes with scanty, but often edible, pulp. C. occidentalis is commonin the Eastern United States. Gray.

Report; rumor; fame; common talk; something heard from another.Much of the obloquy that has so long rested on the memory of ourgreat national poet originated in frivolous hearsays of his life andconversation. Prof. Wilson.Hearsay evidence (Law), that species of testimony which consists in aa narration by one person of matters told him by another. It is, witha few exceptions, inadmissible as testimony. Abbott.
Without hap or luck; luckless; unfortunate; unlucky; unhappy;as, hapless youth; hapless maid. Dryden.
The state of being healthful.
Having a humped back.
Feeding on horseflesh; -- said of certain nomadic tribes, asthe Tartars.
Of or pertaining to the hippocampus.
A salt of hypochlorous acid; as, a calcium hypochloride.
See Semiglutin.
A title borne by the princes or governors of Moldavia andWallachia before those countries were united as Roumania.
Dwelling; abode; residence. [Obs.] Spenser.
Somewhat like horn; hard.
To cause to feel horror; to strike or impress with horror; as,the sight horrified the beholders. E. Irving.
A firm, or commercial establishment.
p. p. of Heave.
One who believes in hylotheism.
See Hende.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from sorbicacid when this takes up hydrogen; as, hydrosorbic acid.
Eating green shoots, as certain insects do.

An extensive division of Mammalia. It formerly included theProboscidea, Hyracoidea, Perissodactyla, and Artiodactyla, but bylater writers it is generally restricted to the two latter groups(Ungulata). They feed almost exclusively upon vegetation.
Composed of, or containing, hypersthene.
Same as Hematoid.
Hematin.
See Hæmocytotrypsis.
Wrapped; covered; cloaked. [Scot.]All happed with flowers in the green wood were. Hogg.
A confused noise; uproar; tumult. [Colloq.] Thackeray.
See Hollo.
The act of harvesting; also, that which is harvested.Swinburne.
To make hollow, as by digging, cutting, or engraving; toexcavate. "Trees rudely hollowed." Dryden.
Art of writing or engraving on glass.

A plant of the genus Hyoscyamus (H. niger). All parts of theplant are poisonous, and the leaves are used for the same purposes asbelladonna. It is poisonous to domestic fowls; whence the name.Called also, stinking nightshade, from the fetid odor of the plant.See Hyoscyamus.
According to the practice of homeopathy. [Alsohomoepathically.]
Of or pertaining to the rectum; rectal; as, the hemorrhoidalarteries, veins, and nerves.
A bar or lever, generally of wood, used in a windlass orcapstan, for heaving anchor, and, in modified forms, for variouspurposes.
One of an order of fresh-water Bryozoa, in which the tentaclesare on a lophophore, shaped like a horseshoe. See Phylactolæma.
Having sound judgment; sagacious; shrewd.-- Hard"-head`ed*ness, n.
An attendant; a servant; a follower. Now chiefly used as apolitical cant term.
Same as Halidom.
A civil officer charged with the duty of impounding hogsrunning at large. [New Eng.] Bartlett.
The obtaining of a curve similar to a pulse curve orsphygmogram by allowing the blood from a divided artery to strikeagainst a piece of paper.
Inhabited by, or subject to the visits of, apparitions;frequented by a ghost.All houses wherein men have lived and died Are haunted houses.Longfellow.
A leader in heresy; the chief of a sect of heretics. Bp.Stillingfleet.
Of or pertaining to the hallux.
A fee or toll paid for goods sold in a hall.
Tending to excess of formative action.
Same as Hollo.
See Halidom.
Same as Hatchel.
A winter bud, in which the rudimentary foliage or flower, as ofmost trees and shrubs in the temperate zone, is protected by closelyoverlapping scales.
A hydrocarbon, C6H10, of the acetylene series, obtainedartificially as a colorless, volatile, pungent liquid; -- called alsohexoylene.
In a halting or limping manner.
Return home.Kepeth this child, al be it foul or fayr, And eek my wyf, unto mynhoom-cominge. Chaucer.
See St. Elmo's fire, under Saint.

See Have. Had as lief, Had rather, Had better, Had as soon,etc., with a nominative and followed by the infinitive without to,are well established idiomatic forms. The original construction wasthat of the dative with forms of be, followed by the infinitive. SeeHad better, under Better.And lever me is be pore and trewe. [And more agreeable to me it is tobe poor and true.] C. Mundi (Trans. ).Him had been lever to be syke. [To him it had been preferable to besick.] Fabian.For him was lever have at his bed's head Twenty bookes, clad in blackor red, . . . Than robes rich, or fithel, or gay sawtrie. Chaucer.
The source and upper part of a stream; -- commonly used in theplural; as, the headwaters of the Missouri.
Hindermost; -- superl. of Hind, a. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Any dipterous fly of the family Tabanidæ, that stings horses,and sucks their blood.
A salmon in its fifth year of growth. [Prov. Eng.]
Dullness; stupidity. Harvey.
Capable of being husbanded, or managed with economy. Sherwood.
Like or pertaining to the genus Haliotis; ear-shaped.
The natural history, or study, of worms, esp. parasitic worms.
Showing, or characterized by, hesitation.[He said] in his mild, hesitative way. R. D. Blackmore.
One who makes or mends hedges; also, one who hedges, as, inbetting.
Relating to the production of hypnotic sleep; as, the so-calledhypnogenic pressure points, pressure upon which is said to cause anattack of hypnotic sleep. De Watteville.
The decay and dissolution of the organic tissues and of theblood.

To winter; to pass the season of winter in close quarters, in atorpid or lethargic state, as certain mammals, reptiles, and insects.Inclination would lead me to hibernate, during half the year, in thisuncomfortable climate of Great Britain. Southey.
Same as Hindrance.
A predominant shade in a composition of primary colors; aprimary color modified by combination with others.
A heron; esp., the common European heron. "A stately hern."Trench.
By inheritance; in an hereditary manner. Pope.
Without a visible hammer; -- said of a gun having a cock orstriker concealed from sight, and out of the way of an accidentaltouch.
A worthless, base, degenerate person or animal. [Obs.]Callander.
An orchard. [Obs.]
Without hire. Davenant.
A priest who becomes a martyr.
Possessed of noble or honorable principles.

Any natural projection or excrescence from an animal,resembling or thought to resemble a horn in substance or form; esp.:(a) A projection from the beak of a bird, as in the hornbill. (b) Atuft of feathers on the head of a bird, as in the horned owl. (c) Ahornlike projection from the head or thorax of an insect, or the headof a reptile, or fish. (d) A sharp spine in front of the fins of afish, as in the horned pout.
An emerald-green variety of spodumene found in North Carolina;lithia emerald, -- used as a gem.
A sweating bath or place for sweating. Sir T. Herbert.
More or less brittle when heated; as, hot-short iron.
A pipe with a long, flexible stem, so arranged that the smokeis cooled by being made to pass through water.
See Hoopoe. [Obs.]
To make hoarse.I shall be obliged to hoarsen my voice. Richardson.
Strong aversion; intense dislike; hate; an affection of themind awakened by something regarded as evil.
Hypocritically. [R.] Sylvester.
, from Harvest, v. t. Harvesting ant (Zoöl.), any species ofant which gathers and stores up seeds for food. Many species areknown.
A term employed to describe one of the varieties of stammering.Tylor.
A group of birds including the trogons.
Felt in one's own breast; inward; private. "Home-felt quiet.Pope.
A tree nymph whose life ended with that of the particular tree,usually an oak, which had been her abode.
Furnishing help; giving aid; assistant; useful; salutary.Heavens make our presence and our practices Pleasant and helpful tohim! Shak.-- Help"ful*ly, adv.-- Help"ful*ness, n. Milton.
To harass; to plunder from. [Obs.] Fuller.
The great woolly mullein (Verbascum Thapsus).
Of or pertaining to homeopathy; according to the principles ofhomeopathy. [Also homoepathic.]
To overwhelm. [Obs.] Spenser.
Any species of marine fishes of the genus Trichiurus; esp., T.lepterus of Europe and America. They are long and like a band, with aslender, pointed tail. Called also bladefish.
A convent or monastery which is also a place of refuge orentertainment for travelers on some difficult road or pass, as in theAlps; as, the Hospice of the Great St. Bernard.
A hydrous phosphate of zinc in transparent prismatic crystals.
Properly, a short hauberk, but often used loosely for thehauberk. Chaucer.
A white, crystalline substance having a sweetish taste,obtained by the decomposition of hesperidin, and regarded as acomplex derivative of caffeic acid.
An owl. See Howlet.
The European green woodpecker or yaffle. [Written also high-hoo.]
Same as Hematocrystallin.
The business of a farrier; especially, the art of curing thediseases of horses.
The sum or number of seven.
Wholesome; salubrious. [R.] "Healthsome air." Shak.
The eye or loop formed in each heddle to receive a warp thread.
See Hyppogriff.
A machine for throwing water by hand power, as a garden engine,a fire extinguisher, etc.

A prefix denoting that the element to the name of which it isprefixed enters with a low valence, or in a low state of oxidization,usually the lowest, into the compounds indicated; as, hyposulphurousacid.
The hoopoe. See Hoopoe.
Destitute of herbs or of vegetation. J. Warton.
A governor or prefect appointed by the Spartans in the citiessubjugated by them.
One who practices horticulture.
See Hop-o'-my-thumb.
A Rhenish wine, of a light yellow color, either sparkling orstill. The name is also given indiscriminately to all Rhenish wines.
See Huckster.
A lock in which a close grip is obtained and a fall attemptedby a heave over the hip.
Horrisonous. [Obs.]
Inhospitable. [Obs.] "A hostless house." Spenser.
Diluent.-- n.
Having a hip roof.
Of or pertaining to an hyperbaton; transposed; inverted.
Pertaining to, or containing, hallelujahs. [R.]
A domestic servant; a retainer. [Obs.] "False homely hewe."Chaucer.
Pertaining to, or resembling, the herpes; partaking of thenature of herpes; as, herpetic eruptions.
The wild dog-rose.
A curve traced by a point in the circumference of a circlewhich rolls on the concave side in the fixed circle. Cf. Epicycloid,and Trochoid.
Furnished with hoofs. Grew.
A substance found in the blood of the octopus, which gives toit its blue color.

Religious opinion opposed to the authorized doctrinal standardsof any particular church, especially when tending to promote schismor separation; lack of orthodox or sound belief; rejection of, orerroneous belief in regard to, some fundamental religious doctrine ortruth; heterodoxy.Doubts 'mongst divines, and difference of texts, From whence arisediversity of sects, And hateful heresies by God abhor'd. Spenser.Deluded people! that do not consider that the greatest heresy in theworld is a wicked life. Tillotson.
A frame mounted on the running gear of a wagon, and used inhauling hay, straw, sheaves, etc.; -- called also hay rigging.
The second element in each half of a hemal arch, correspondingto the sternal part of a rib. Owen.-- Hem`a*po*phys"i*al, a.
An extensive artificial division of gastropod mollusks,including those that breathe by gills, as contrasted with thePulmonifera.-- Hy`dro*bran"chi*ate, a.
A witch; a hag. Middleton.
The hypothenar eminence.
The worship of saints or sacred things. [R.] Coleridge.
Having a single series of large scutes on the posterior side ofthe tarsus; -- said of certain birds.

A small salmon (Oncorhynchus gorbuscha) which ascends therivers of the Pacific coast from California to Alaska, and also onthe Asiatic side. In the breeding season the male has a large dorsalhump and distorted jaws.
See Hemoglobin.
An instrument for making of angular measurements.
Having a humped back.
A brownish substance sometimes found in the blood, in cases ofjaundice.
A kind of metamorphosis, in certain insects, in which the larvaitself undergoes remarkable changes of form and structure during itsgrowth.

One of the very minute, disk-shaped bodies found in blood withthe ordinary red corpuscles and white corpuscles; a third kind ofblood corpuscle, supposed by some to be an early stage in thedevelopment of the red corpuscles; -- called also blood plaque, andblood plate.
A fork for pitching and tedding hay. Horse hayfork, acontrivance for unloading hay from the cart and depositing it in theloft, or on a mow, by horse power.
Comrade; boon companion; good fellow; -- a term of familiaraddress and fellowship among sailors. Dickens.
The coloring principle of logwood. It is obtained as a yellowcrystalline substance, C16H14O6, with a sweetish taste. Formerlycalled also hematin.
Pertaining to, or depending upon, both liquid and gaseoussubstances; as, hydropneumatic apparatus for collecting gases overwater or other liquids.
A square or oblong opening in a deck or floor, affordingpassage from one deck or story to another; the entrance to a cellar.
A series of six notes, with a semitone between the third andfourth, the other intervals being whole tones.
Quite mad; -- raving crazy.Did I tell you about Mr. Garrick, that the town are horn-mad afterGray.
Same as Haybote.
Of or pertaining to horologiography. Chambers.
A hold in which one arm is thrust under the corresponding armof the opponent, generally behind, and the hand placed upon the backof his neck. In the full nelson both hands are so placed.
A word having the same sound as another, but differing from itin meaning; as the noun bear and the verb bear. [Written alsohomonyme.]
See Hooded seal, under Hooded.
A herald. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Having the same relative position, proportion, value, orstructure. Especially:(a) (Geom.) Corresponding in relative position and proportion.In similar polygons, the corresponding sides, angles, diagonals,etc., are homologous. Davies & Peck (Math. Dict. ).(b) (Alg.)
Pleasantly; humorously.
The act of drawing the warp threads through the heddle-eyes ofa weaver's harness; the harness itself. Knight.
To change the direction of a ship by hauling the wind. Seeunder Haul, v. t.I . . . hauled up for it, and found it to be an island. Cook.
The eye of a bean or other seed; the mark or scar at the pointof attachment of an ovule or seed to its base or support; -- calledalso hile.
A player on the harp; a harper. W. Browne.
A species of agate, sprinkled with spots of red jasper.
Of or pertaining to an hour, or to hours. Prior.
A rare fluophosphate of glucina, in small white crystals.
Of or pertaining to hydrophobia; producing or caused by rabies;as, hydrophobic symptoms; the hydrophobic poison.
A show or exhibition having a great number of scenes or views.
The goods and wares sold by a haberdasher; also (Fig.),trifles. Burke.
A wise man; a physician, esp. a Mohammedan. [India]

A kingfisher. By modern ornithologists restricted to a genusincluding a limited number of species having omnivorous habits, asthe sacred kingfisher (Halcyon sancta) of Australia.Amidst our arms as quiet you shall be As halcyons brooding on awinter sea. Dryden.
See Haruspicy. Tylor.
Of, or connected with, hernia.
A flat muscle on either side of the tongue, connecting it withthe hyoid bone.
To use the hands.They have hands, but they handle not. Ps. cxv. 7.
The evening; Hesperus.
A heronshaw. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Into this. Hooker.
Disposed to be blustering or arrogant; petulant.-- Huff"ish*ly, adv.-- Huff"ish*ness, n.
Same as Homolographic.
One of numerous species of Heliconius, a genus of tropicalAmerican butterflies. The wings are usually black, marked with green,crimson, and white.
Hungry; pinched for food. [Obs.] Milton.
Cowardly; timid; chicken-hearted. Udall.
A proprietor or landholder in a parish. [Scot.]
= Jewish calendar.
An instrument for measuring time.
An instrument for determining the specific gravities ofliquids, and thence the strength spirituous liquors, salinesolutions, etc.
Same as Hilum, 2.
A low, oven-shaped mound, common in volcanic regions, andemitting smoke and vapors from its sides and summit. Humboldt.

A thicket of bushes, usually thorn bushes; especially, such athicket planted as a fence between any two portions of land; and alsoany sort of shrubbery, as evergreens, planted in a line or as afence; particularly, such a thicket planted round a field to fenceit, or in rows to separate the parts of a garden.The roughest berry on the rudest hedge. Shak.Through the verdant maze Of sweetbrier hedges I pursue my walk.Thomson.
Any slender, marine fish of the genus Hemirhamphus, having theupper jaw much shorter than the lower; -- called also balahoo.
One who is versed in hypnology.
A parent stock or race of people, not yet divided into separatebranches or tribes.
A base, degraded person; a sneak; a gallows bird.
Imperfectly hatched; as, half-hatched eggs. Gay.
Impregnated with hops.
The act of exhorting, inciting, or giving advice; exhortation.[R.]
Kept at home.

The cohesion of the particles on the surface of a body,determined by its capacity to scratch another, or be itselfscratched;-measured among minerals on a scale of which diamond andtalc form the extremes.
Any species of Old World geckoes of the genus Hemidactylus. Thehemidactyls have dilated toes, with two rows of plates beneath.
The Baltimore oriole (Icterus galbula); -- so called becauseits nest is suspended from the limb of a tree. See Baltimore oriole.
An order of fresh-water rhizopods having a more or lessglobular form, with slender radiating pseudopodia; the sunanimalcule.
A composition sung to the sound of seven chords or tones. Moore(Encyc. of Music).
A prefix equivalent to super- or per-; as hyperoxide, orperoxide. [Obs.] See Per-.
One who hoops casks or tubs; a cooper.
One who prepares homilies; one who preaches to a congregation.
The bumblebee. Shak.
A curve, traced by a point in the radius, or radius produced,of a circle which rolls upon the concave side of a fixed circle. SeeHypocycloid, Epicycloid, and Trochoid.
See Halloo.
Mirthful; noisy; merry.
Having six feet; belonging to the Hexapoda.
Pertaining to, or containing, or obtained from, hydrogen,ferric iron, and cyanogen; as, hydroferricyanic acid. SeeFerricyanic.
See Hectograph.
See New thought, below.
One who is guilty of the crime of housebreaking.
Either of the hypochondriac regions.
A diseased condition produced by poisoning with hydrargyrum, ormercury; mercurialism.
Same Hagiographa.
Out of this. [Obs.] Spenser.
One who eats horseflesh.
See Mercury.
Of or pertaining to Spain or its language; as, Hispanic words.

A body of cavalry so called; esp., a British regiment, calledthe Royal Horse Guards, which furnishes guards of state for thesovereign. The Horse Guards, a name given to the former headquartersof the commander in chief of the British army, at Whitehall inLondon.
High; elevated; hence, haughty; proud. [Obs.] Shak.
Same as Hooker.

Belonging or appropriate to an enemy; showing the dispositionof an enemy; showing ill will and malevolence, or a desire to thwartand injure; occupied by an enemy or enemies; inimical; unfriendly;as, a hostile force; hostile intentions; a hostile country; hostileto a sudden change.
Like a huswife; capable; economical; prudent.-- adv.
Indiana; -- a nickname of obscure origin.
Like hemp. [R.] Howell.
Contempt; scorn. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A telescope or instrument for viewing the sun without injury tothe eyes, as through colored glasses, or with mirrors which reflectbut a small portion of light.-- He`li*o*scop`ic, a.
A coarse umbelliferous plant of Europe (Tordylium maximum).
A celebrated French wine, both white and red, of the Departmentof Drôme.
Primitive religion in which each of several divinities isregarded as independent, and is worshiped without reference to therest. [R.]
A worshiper of the sun.
Ware made of metal, as cutlery, kitchen utensils, and the like;ironmongery.
Having hot blood; excitable; high-spirited; irritable; ardent;passionate.
To reduce to a lower position in one's own eyes, or in the eyesof others; to humble; to mortify.We stand humiliated rather than encouraged. M. Arnold.
Giving exhortation or advise; encouraging; exhortatory;inciting; as, a hortatory speech. Holland.
An executioner who cuts off heads. Dryden.
Formed or perforated like a honeycomb.Each bastion was honeycombed with casements. Motley.
Seizure by, or grasp of, the hand; also, close quarters infighting. Hudibras.
Of or pertaining to the method of heteropathy; allopathic.
Veneration or worship given to the Virgin Mary as the mostexalted of mere creatures; higher veneration than dulia. Addis &Arnold.
Done or happening at intervals of half an hour.
In six parts; in sixes.
One who is employed in the hold of a vessel.
Hook-shaped.
A contrivance or apparatus to prevent the explosion of steamboilers.
A tendency towards moisture.
The cultivation of a garden or orchard; the art of cultivatinggardens or orchards.
Exciting, or tending to excite, horror or fear; dreadful;terrible; shocking; hideous; as, a horrible sight; a horrible story;a horrible murder.A dungeon horrible on all sides round. Milton.
Of or pertaining to the Helianthoidea.
A head covering of various kinds; a hood; a coif; a cap. [Obs.]Chaucer.
Having the nature of, pertaining to, or covered with, herbs orherbage. "Herby valleys." Chapman.
An instrument devised by Hermann, for regulating and measuringthe thickness of a layer of blood for spectroscopic examination.
Hollow. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Familiar, social intercourse. W. Black.
The use of hyperbole. Jefferson.
To make into a distinct substance; to conceive or treat as anexisting being; to hypostatize. [R.]The pressed Newtonians . . . refused to hypostasize the law ofgravitation into an ether. Coleridge.
A note at the head of a page or chapter; in law reports, anabstract of a case, showing the principles involved and the opinionof the court.
Swinish; gluttonous; filthy; selfish.-- Hog"gish*ly, adv.-- Hog"gish*ness, n.Is not a hoggish life the height of some men's wishes Shaftesbury.
An orthorhombic mineral of the pyroxene group, of a grayish orgreenish black color, often with a peculiar bronzelike luster(schiller) on the cleavage surface.
To fasten (an animal) by a rope binding the head to one of thefore legs; as, to hamshackle a horse or cow; hence, to bind orrestrain; to curb.
See Hinderest. [Obs.]
The state of being bent like a hook; incurvation.
See Hydrocyanide.
One who, or that which, heightens.
A measure of solidity, containing one hundred cubic meters, andequivalent to 3531.66 English or 3531.05 United States cubic feet.
An order of sponges, having simple siliceous spicules andkeratose fibers; -- called also Keratosilicoidea.
Resembling glass; vitriform; transparent; hyaline; as, thehyaloid membrane, a very delicate membrane inclosing the vitreoushumor of the eye.

Having the expression of one wasted by want or suffering;hollow-eyed; having the features distorted or wasted, or anxious inappearance; as, haggard features, eyes.Staring his eyes, and haggard was his look. Dryden.
One of the Homoptera.
Same as Hobblebush.
Scorn; derision; abusive talk. [Obs.] -- Ho"ker*ly, adv. [Obs.]Chaucer.
A young male fur seal, esp. one from three to six years old; --called also bachelor, because prevented from breeding by the olderfull-grown males.
A soluble ferment occurring in the animal body, to the presenceof which many normal decompositions and synthetical processes aresupposed to be due.
The branches of polite or elegant learning; as language,rhetoric, poetry, and the ancient classics; belles-letters.
In the preceding part of this (writing, document, book, etc.).
Having a lofty spirit; haughty. [Obs.] Shak.
An appendage or fold on the lower side of the pharynx, incertain insects.
A variety of native Epsom salt occurring in silky fibers.
Same as Helvetic.-- n.
The cloth which covers a coach box.
A cod salted and dried. Ainsworth.
Same as Hindoo.
In health; wholesomely.
A blacksmith's fuller or chisel, having a square shank forinsertion into a square hole in an anvil, called the hardy hole.
A day fixed by law for suspension of business; a legal holiday.
Humbleness; abasement; low obeisance. [Obs.] Chaucer. Spenser.
Beset with stiff hairs or bristles.
Sacramental; as, housling fire. [R.] Spenser.
Same as Hemapophysis.-- Hæm`a*po*phys"i*al, a.
An homopter.
A hollow, muscular organ, which, by contracting rhythmically,keeps up the circulation of the blood.Why does my blood thus muster to my heart! Shak.
Presiding over matter. [Obs.] Hallywell.
One who believes in hedonism.
Fit; qualified; also, apt. [Obs.] Spenser.
Of the nature, or containing, hydrocarbons.
Having one of the two florets in the same spikelet neuter, andthe other unisexual, whether male or female; -- said of grasses.
A mental disorder in which melancholy and gloomy views tormentthe affected person, particularly concerning his own health.
The state of being healthy or healthful; freedom from disease.
An explosive mixture, consisting of sawdust, charcoal, niter,and ferrocyanide of potassium, used as a substitute for gunpowder.
Dull; stupid. "Gross heavy-headed fellows." Beau. & Fl.

Of or pertaining to hydraulics, or to fluids in motion;conveying, or acting by, water; as, an hydraulic clock, crane, ordock. Hydraulic accumulator, an accumulator for hydraulic machineryof any kind. See Accumulator, 2.-- Hydraulic brake, a cataract. See Cataract, 3.-- Hydraulic cement, a cement or mortar made of hydraulic lime,which will harden under water.-- Hydraulic elevator, a lift operated by the weight or pressure ofwater.-- Hydraulic jack. See under Jack.-- Hydraulic lime, quicklime obtained from hydraulic limestone, andused for cementing under water, etc.-- Hydraulic limestone, a limestone which contains some clay, andwhich yields a quicklime that will set, or form a firm, strong mass,under water.-- Hydraulic main (Gas Works), a horizontal pipe containing water atthe bottom into which the ends of the pipes from the retorts dip, forpassing the gas through water in order to remove ammonia.-- Hydraulic mining, a system of mining in which the force of a jetof water is used to wash down a bank of gold-bearing gravel or earth.[Pacific Coast] -- Hydraulic press, a hydrostatic press. See underHydrostatic.-- Hydraulic propeller, a device for propelling ships by means of astream of water ejected under water rearward from the ship.-- Hydraulic ram, a machine for raising water by means of the energyof the moving water of which a portion is to be raised. When the rushof water through the main pipe d shuts the valve at a, the momentumof the current thus suddenly checked forces part of it into the airchamber b, and up the pipe c, its return being prevented by a valveat the entrance to the air chamber, while the dropping of the valve aby its own weight allows another rush through the main pipe, and soon alternately.-- Hydraulic valve. (Mach.) (a) A valve for regulating thedistribution of water in the cylinders of hydraulic elevators,cranes, etc. (b) (Gas Works) An inverted cup with a partition dippinginto water, for opening or closing communication between two gasmains, the open ends of which protrude about the water.
One who hits or strikes; as, a hard hitter.
Fearful; frightful. [Obs.] I. Watts.

That which is homologous to something else; as, thecorresponding sides, etc., of similar polygons are the homologues ofeach other; the members or terms of an homologous series in chemistryare the homologues of each other; one of the bones in the hand of manis the homologue of that in the paddle of a whale.
The hooded crow; also, in Scotland, the hooded gull.
See Hara-kiri.
Inflammation of the liver.

An eruption of the skin, taking various names, according to itsform, or the part affected; especially, an eruption of vesicles insmall distinct clusters, accompanied with itching or tingling,including shingles, ringworm, and the like; -- so called from itstendency to creep or spread from one part of the skin to another.
One who, or that which, hacks. Specifically: A cuttinginstrument for making notches; esp., one used for notching pine treesin collecting turpentine; a hack.
Of or pertaining to the motions of fluids, or the forces whichproduce or affect such motions; -- opposed to hydrostatic. Sir W.Thomson.
A whoremonger. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Excessive criticism, or unjust severity or rigor of criticism;zoilism.
High-priesthood.
A juggler. [Cant] hocus pocus Hudibras.
Having six fingers or toes.
One versed in helminthology.
In a heady or rash manner; hastily; rashly; obstinately.
A cake of Indian meal, water, and salt, baked before the fireor in the ashes; -- so called because often cooked on a hoe.[Southern U.S.]
One who, or that which, hardens; specif., one who temperstools.
See with hobnails, as a shoe.

The act or practice of one who is hospitable; reception andentertainment of strangers or guests without reward, or with kind andgenerous liberality.Given to hospitality. Rom. xii. 13.And little recks to find the way to heaven By doing deeds ofhospitality. Shak.
A lateral half of the heart, either the right or left. B. G.Wilder.
To leap; to caper; to romp noisily. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
Furnished with a small hook; hook-shaped. Gray.
A castrated deer.
A minor subdivision at the base of the Cambrian system inWales.
Of or pertaining to Horace, the Latin poet, or resembling hisstyle.
Interment; inhumation. [R.]
The act of honesting; grace; adornment. [Obs.] W. Montagu.
A large North American aquatic salamander (Protonopsis horridaor Menopoma Alleghaniensis). It is very voracious and very tenaciousof life. Also called alligator, and water dog.
Constructed of a timber frame, having the spaces filled in withmasonry; -- said of buildings.
See Hypoplastron.

An alkaloid found in henbane (Hyoscyamus niger), and regardedas its active principle. It is also found with other alkaloids in thethorn apple and deadly nightshade. It is extracted as a whitecrystalline substance, with a sharp, offensive taste. Hyoscyamine isisomeric with atropine, is very poisonous, and is used as a medicinefor neuralgia, like belladonna. Called also hyoscyamia, duboisine,etc.
A composition for infernal purposes; a magical preparation.Shak.

One who, or that which, hems with a needle. Specifically:(a) An attachment to a sewing machine, for turning under the edge ofa piece of fabric, preparatory to stitching it down.(b) A tool for turning over the edge of sheet metal to make a hem.
High-flown, bombastic language. [Written also hifalutin.][Jocular, U. S.] Lowell.
The goddess of health, daughter of Esculapius.
One who works with a hammer.
Destitute of a husband. Shak.
A dependent; a hanger-on; -- so called in contempt. B. Jonson.
Of or pertaining to the Homoptera.
Having an entire aperture; -- said of many univalve shells.
Habitableness.
Same as Hemadynamometer.
Variant of Height. [Obs.]
See Andrion. [Obs.]
A red consisting of silica, borax, and soda, fused with oxideof copper and iron, and used in enamels, mosaics, etc.
To excite; to tease, or worry; to harry. [Obs.] Locke.
The East Indian name of the Cynodon Dactylon; dog's-grass.

A nervous affection, occurring almost exclusively in women, inwhich the emotional and reflex excitability is exaggerated, and thewill power correspondingly diminished, so that the patient losescontrol over the emotions, becomes the victim of imaginarysensations, and often falls into paroxism or fits.
A saw used with one hand.
The garfish or sea needle.
Qualified or entitled. [Obs.] Bacon.
The cold-blooded vertebrates, that is, all but the mammals andbirds; -- the antithesis to Hematotherma.
See Mellite.
One of the Herbivora. P. H. Gosse.

To fatigue; to tire with repeated and exhausting efforts; esp.,to weary by importunity, teasing, or fretting; to cause to endureexcessive burdens or anxieties; -- sometimes followed by out.[Troops] harassed with a long and wearisome march. Bacon.Nature oppressed and harass'd out with care. Addison.Vext with lawyers and harass'd with debt. Tennyson.
The flicker; -- called also high-hole. [Local, U. S.]
An uneasy, burning sensation in the stomach, often attendedwith an inclination to vomit. It is sometimes idiopathic, but isoften a symptom of often complaints.

A succulent plant of the genus Sempervivum (S. tectorum),originally a native of subalpine Europe, but now found very generallyon old walls and roofs. It is very tenacious of life under droughtand heat; -- called also ayegreen.
A fabulous sea monster. [Obs.] Spenser.
Pertaining to, or derived from, barley; as, hordeic acid, anacid identical or isomeric with lauric acid.
The post to which a gate or door is hinged.
The piping frog (Hyla Pickeringii), a small American tree frog,which in early spring, while breeding in swamps and ditches, singswith high, shrill, but musical, notes.
To throw by means of a hipe. -- Hip"er (#), n.
To send away. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
A shed for swine; a sty.
A hazardous attempt or situation; hazard. [Obs.]Herself had run into that hazardize. Spenser.
A form of sacred or hieratic writing.
Half-bred; imperfect. [R.] "A half-strained villain." Dryden.
A hill; a cliff. [Obs.] Spenser.
In a hinting manner.
One who hobbles.
A handkerchief.
A solid body of six sides or faces. Regular hexahedron, ahexagon having six equal squares for its sides; a cube.

To be gentle, agreeable, or coaxing; to talk fondly; to useendearments; also, to be or become obsequiously courteous orcomplimentary; to fawn. "Honeying and making love." Shak.Rough to common men, But honey at the whisper of a lord. Tennyson.
A saint. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The state of being heterogeneous; contrariety.The difference, indeed the heterogeneity, of the two may be felt.Coleridge.
A man skilled or employed in handcraft. Bacon.
Sun worship. See Sabianism.
A child's game, in which a player, hopping on one foot, drivesa stone from one compartment to another of a figure traced orscotched on the ground; -- called also hoppers.
Being without a horse; specif., not requiring a horse; -- saidof certain vehicles in which horse power has been replaced byelectricity, steam, etc.; as, a horseless carriage or truck.
Same as Monoclinic.

Of or pertaining to the bony or cartilaginous arch whichsupports the tongue. Sometimes applied to the tongue itself. Hyoidarch (Anat.), the arch of cartilaginous or bony segments, whichconnects the base of the tongue with either side of the skull.-- Hyoid bone (Anat.), the bone in the base of the tongue, themiddle part of the hyoid arch.
Of lofty structure; tall. "High-built organs." Tennyson.The high-built elephant his castle rears. Creech.
Native salt; sodium chloride.
Half-blooded.
According to hydrostatics, or to hydrostatic principles.Bentley.
The science of interpretation and explanation; exegesis; esp.,that branch of theology which defines the laws whereby the meaning ofthe Scriptures is to be ascertained. Schaff-Herzog Encyc.
See Legislature, Austria, Prussia.

A commercial city of Germany, near the mouth of the Elbe. BlackHamburg grape. See under Black.-- Hamburg , a kind of embroidered work done by machinery on cambricor muslin; -- used for trimming.-- Hamburg lake, a purplish crimson pigment resembling cochineal.
To worship; to glorify; to praise. [Obs.] Chaucer. Spenser.
An owl; an owlet. [Written also houlet.] R. Browning.
A fruit consisting in large part of a receptacle, enlargedbelow the calyx, as in the alycanthus, the rose hip, and the pear.
To tread down roughly, as with hobnailed shoes.Your rights and charters hobnailed into slush. Tennyson.
Overbearing; oppressive; arbitrary; violent; as, a high-handedact.

The long, branching filaments of which the mycelium (and thegreater part of the plant) of a fungus is formed. They are also foundenveloping the gonidia of lichens, making up a large part of theirstructure.
Wanton; lewd; low; base. Shak.
Having color; -- usually in composition; as, bright-hued; many-hued. Chaucer.
A sea fish. See Hake. Ash.
A mineral of a transparent vitreous brown color, found in theejected masses of Vesuvius. It is a silicate of iron and magnesia,containing fluorine.
A country in Central Europe, now a part of the Austro-HungarianEmpire. Hungary water, a distilled "water," made from dilute alcoholaromatized with rosemary flowers, etc.
Hospitable. [Obs.] Howell.
A light horseman. See 2d Hobbler. [Obs.] Brande & C.
From this time forward; henceforward.I never from thy side henceforth to stray. Milton.
See Hiccough.
Similarly in arrangement of parts; -- the opposite ofheterotaxy.
An apparatus for determining the number of corpuscles in agiven quantity of blood.
Like a hare. [R.] Huloet.
A division along the mesial plane; also, one of the parts sodivided.
Of or pertaining to hot water; -- used esp. with reference tothe action of heated waters in dissolving, redepositing, andotherwise producing mineral changes within the crust of the globe.
A book in seven languages.
Clothed. Taylor (1630).
Crushing sorrow or grief; a yielding to such grief. Shak.
One who, or that which, humbles some one.
Tending to moisten. [Obs.]
Hereafter. [Obs.]Thou shalt hereafterward . . . come. Chaucer.
The qualities characteristic of a hero, as courage, bravery,fortitude, unselfishness, etc.; the display of such qualities.Heroism is the self-devotion of genius manifesting itself in action.Hare.
A pen, house, or inclosure, for hogs.
Hydraulic.
See Haulm, straw.
Staying at home; not gadding.Home-keeping youth have ever homely wits. Shak.
Wild; giddy; flighty; rash; thoughtless. [Colloq.]They had a quarrel with Sir Thomas Newcome's own son, a harum-scarumlad. Thackeray.
Having high antlers; bearing full-grown antlers aloft.
A platform of a staircase where the stair turns back in exactlythe reverse direction of the lower flight. See Quarterpace.
