Of or pertaining to a hypoarion.
Indued with humanity. [Obs.] Cranmer.
Consisting of seven parts, or having the parts in sets ofsevens. Gray.
The fore parts of the wales, which encompass the bow of avessel, and are fastened to the stem. [Written also harpins.] Totten.
Earnestness; sincerity; heartiness. [R.] Clarendon.
Being or growing on the under side of a leaf, as the fruit dotsof ferns.
Those insects which have an incomplete metamorphosis.
In a handy manner; skillfully; conveniently.

A fabulous winged monster, ravenous and filthy, having the faceof a woman and the body of a vulture, with long claws, and the facepale with hunger. Some writers mention two, others three.Both table and provisions vanished guite. With sound of harpies'wings and talons heard. Milton.
An apparatus for drying anything, as yarn, cloth, sugar, etc.,by centrifugal force; a centrifugal.
A sacred government; by holy orders of men. Southey.
In a heating manner; so as to make or become hot or heated.
Same as Ascites.
Not capable of self-fertilization; -- said of hermaphroditeflowers in which some structural obstacle forbids autogamy.
According to the Hellenistic manner or dialect. J. Gregory.
Capable of being formed or shaped by a hammer. Sherwood.

Livid and painful swellings formed by the dilation of the bloodvessels around the margin of, or within, the anus, from which bloodor mucus is occasionally discharged; piles; emerods. [The sing.hemorrhoid is rarely used.]

A spear or javelin used to strike and kill large fish, aswhales; a harping iron. It consists of a long shank, with a broad,fiat, triangular head, sharpened at both edges, and is thrown byhand, or discharged from a gun. Harpoon fork, a kind of hayfork,consisting of bar with hinged barbs at one end a loop for a rope atthe other end, used for lifting hay from the load by horse power.-- Harpoon gun, a gun used in the whale fishery for shooting theharpoon into a whale.
Making excessively nice or trivial distinctions in reasoning;subtle.-- n.
Plainly; rudely; coarsely; as, homely dressed. [R.] Spenser.
Abnormally increased muscular movement; spasm.
The small part of a gunstock near the lock, which is grasped bythe hand in taking aim.
Minutely hispid.
One of the great divisions of fungi, containing those speciesin which the hymenium is completely exposed. M. J. Berkley.
Pertaining to, or designating, an isomeric variety of lasticacid that breaks down into acrylic acid and water.
See Hematophilia.
Same as Heptarchist.
The nut of the hazel. Shak.
Elevated or mountainous land; (often in the pl.) an elevatedregion or country; as, the Highlands of Scotland. Highland fling, adance peculiar to the Scottish Highlanders; a sort of hornpipe.

A shark of the genus Sphyrna or Zygæna, having the eyes set onprojections from the sides of the head, which gives it a hammershape. The Sphyrna zygæna is found in the North Atlantic. Called alsohammer fish, and balance fish.
A row of shrubs, or trees, planted for inclosure or separationof fields.By hedgerow elms and hillocks green. Milton.
One of the Hemiptera.
Covered with honeysuckles.
A saline compound of hydrosulphurous acid and a base. [R.]
Hyperdulia. [Obs.]
Causing horror; frightful.Let . . . nothing ghastly or horrific be supposed. I. Taylor.
Same as Acton. [Obs.]
To add a piece of leather to the heel of (a shoe, boot, etc.)

Any wading bird of the genus Ardea and allied genera, of thefamily Ardeidæ. The herons have a long, sharp bill, and long legs andtoes, with the claw of the middle toe toothed. The common Europeanheron (Ardea cinerea) is remarkable for its directly ascendingflight, and was formerly hunted with the larger falcons.
Same as Hoazin.
A young rowdy; a rough, lawless fellow. [Colloq. U.S.]
Not orthodox. Howell.
The person blindfolded in the game called hoodman-blind. [Obs.]Shak.
Having the ganglia of the nervous system unsymmetricallyarranged; -- said of certain invertebrate animals.
Orthodoxy pushed to excess.
Of or pertaining to ivy.
One whose business is to build houses; a housewright.
The quality or state of being hazy.
An old term for blindman's buff. Shak.
The office of a herald. Selden.
Description of the sea; the science that treats of the sea.
To give a Spanish form or character to; as, to HispanicizeLatin words.
Having an incomplete metamorphosis, the larvæ differing fromthe adults chiefly in laking wings, as in the grasshoppers andcockroaches.
A highway; a much travele
A warm-blooded animal. [R.]

A marine food fish (Melanogrammus æglefinus), allied to thecod, inhabiting the northern coasts of Europe and America. It has adark lateral line and a black spot on each side of the body, justback of the gills. Galled also haddie, and dickie. Norway haddock, amarine edible fish (Sebastes marinus) of Northern Europe and America.See Rose fish.
A plant described by Milton as "of sovereign use against allenchantments."
A fragrant kind of green tea. Hyson skin, the light andinferior leaves separated from the hyson by a winnowing machine.M'Culloch.
From this time forward; henceforth.
One who dissects, or studies the anatomy of, reptiles.
Relating to the blood or blood vessels; pertaining to, situatedin the region of, or on the side with, the heart and great bloodvessels; -- opposed to neural.
Related to, or resembling, the hydra; of or pertaining to theHydroidea.-- n.
The science of veterinary medicine; the pathology of the horse.
With humility; lowly. Pope.
Pertaining to, or derived from, hexyl or hexane; as, hexylicalcohol.
Having wings that are like hands in the structure andarrangement of their bones; -- said of bats. See Cheiroptera.
Variant of Huke. [Obs.]
A layer of tissue beneath the epidermis in plants, andperforming the physiological function of strengthening the epidermaltissue. In phanerogamous plants it is developed as collenchyma.
imp. & p. p. of Hide. See Hidden.
In the form of a hexahedron; having six sides or faces.
A wind attending or presaged by the cloud called helm. [Prov.Eng.]
One who hews.
The history or description of the sacred writings or of sacredpersons; a narrative of the lives of the saints; a catalogue ofsaints. J. H. Newman.
To set in, or furnish with, a haft; as, to haft a dagger.
The science of health; hygiene.
A disease in cattle consisting in inflammation of the stomachby gas, ordinarily caused by eating too much green food; tympany;bloating.
High. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A genus of birds including the swallows and martins.

A combining form, also used adjectively, indicating hydroxyl asan ingredient. Hydroxy acid (Chem.), an organic acid, having (besidesthe hydroxyl group of the carboxyl radical) an alcoholic hydroxylgroup, and thus having the qualities of an alcohol in addition to itsacid properties; as, lactic and tartaric acids are hydroxy acids.
A dry, hot wind, prevailing on the Atlantic coast of Africa, inDecember, January, and February, blowing from the interior or Sahara.It is usually accompanied by a haze which obscures the sun.
See Highfaluting.
Same as Handicraft.
subject to much traffic or travel; as, the region's mostheavily traveled highways.Syn. -- heavily traveled.[WordNet 1.5]
To deal in small wares. [R.]To haberdash in earth's base ware. Quarles.
To hurt; to injure; to damage; to wrong.Though yet he never harmed me. Shak.No ground of enmity between us known Why he should mean me ill orseek to harm. Milton.
A division of wading birds, including the herons, storks, andallied forms. Called also Herodii.-- He*ro`di*o"nine, a.
Hernia of the liver.
One who treats of the sacred writings; a writer of the lives ofthe saints; a hagiographer. Tylor.Hagiologists have related it without scruple. Southey.
A deformity of the penis, in which the urethra opens upon itsunder surface.
A hedge. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Curved like a hawk's bill; crooked.
The condition of having two or more kinds of flowers, differentas to the length of their stamens and pistils.
Full of harangue.
A low bush (Viburnum lantanoides) having long, stragglingbranches and handsome flowers. It is found in the Northern UnitedStates. Called also shinhopple.
One who understands the principles of harmony or is skillful inapplying them in composition; a musical composer.
Having the tail nearly or quite symmetrical, the vertebralcolumn terminating near its base; -- opposed to heterocercal.
A whirlwind. [Obs.] Sandys.
To convert into the Hebrew idiom; to make Hebrew or Hebraistic.J. R. Smith.
The science which treats of the laws relating to organictissues, their formation, development, functions, etc.
A fastening, consisting of an iron ring around the wrist,usually connected by a chain with one on the other wrist; a manacle;-- usually in the plural.
Having females very unlike the males in form and structure; --as certain insects, the males of which are winged, and the femaleswingless.
The sucking proboscis of various insects. See Lepidoptera, andDiptera.
Of or pertaining to the Himalayas, the great mountain chain inHindostan.
A Linnæan order of plants having seven pistils.
Literally, this-ness. A scholastic term to expressindividuality or singleness; as, this book.
The first, or preaxial, digit of the hind limb, correspondingto the pollux in the fore limb; the great toe; the hind toe of birds.
To hamstring. [Obs.]
The lives of the saints. Brande & C.
That which is heteronymous; a thing having a different name ordesignation from some other thing; -- opposed to homonym.
Hellish. Anderson (1573).
Causing discontent.
See Guanaco.
Half-filled. [Obs.]Lions' half-clammed entrails roar food. Marston.
See Halyard.
Government by ecclesiastics; a hierarchy. Jefferson.
A vascular sac connected, beneath the brain, in many fishes,with the infundibulum.
A follower of John Hutchinson of Yorkshire, England, whobelieved that the Hebrew Scriptures contained a complete system ofnatural science and of theology.
Belonging to winter; done in winter. Sir T. Browne.
To move or act with haste; to proceed with celerity orprecipitation; as, let us hurry. To hurry up, to make haste.[Colloq.]
See Hose. [Archaic]
Homogenous; -- applied to that class of homologies which arisefrom similarity of structure, and which are taken as evidences ofcommon ancestry.

The line or surface in which are situated all the points whichare seen single while the point of sight, or the adjustment of theeyes, remains unchanged.The sum of all the points which are seen single, while the point ofsight remains unchanged, is called the horopter. J. Le Conte.
Same as Histogenesis. Dunglison.
Causing perspiration; diaphoretic or sudorific.
A treatise on, or the science of, the preservation of health.[R.]
One who speaks in public; an haranguer; a preacher. Addison.
A name given to the old Parthenon at Athens, because measuring100 Greek feet, probably in the width across the stylobate.
Made of hair. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Pertaining to, or of, ivy; full of ivy.
A fabulous winged animal, half horse and half griffin. Milton.
Heedful. [Obs.] "Heedy shepherds." Spenser.-- Heed"i*ly, adv. [Obs.] -- Heed"i*ness, n. [Obs.] Spenser.

Preserving the mutual relations of parts, especially as to sizeand form; maintaining relative proportion. Homolographic projection,a method of constructing geographical charts or maps, so that thesurfaces, as delineated on a plane, have the same relative size asthe real surfaces; that is, so that the relative actual areas of thedifferent countries are accurately represented by the correspondingportions of the map.
The quality of being handsome.Handsomeness is the mere animal excellence, beauty the mereimaginative. Hare.
Having heartburn. Shak.
A small hill. Shak.
A Chinese weight ( 1/10 catty) equivalent to 1 1/3 oz. or37.801 g.
The offspring of a hag. Shak.
contested; as, a hard-fought battle.

Nevertheless; notwithstanding; yet; still; though; as, I shallnot oppose your design; I can not, however, approve of it.In your excuse your love does little say; You might howe'er have tooka better way. Dryden.
Millet.
The state of being a high-churchman. J. H. Newman.
A compound of hydrobromic acid with a base; -- distinguishedfrom a bromide, in which only the bromine unites with the base.
Of or pertaining to matter; material; corporeal; as, hylicinfluences.
Same as Hematemesis.
Same as Homogeneousness.
A heated room for drying green ware.
The posterior part of the alimentary canal, including therectum, and sometimes the large intestine also.
Born under a hedge; of low birth. Shak.
A believer in hylozoism. A. Tucker.
A worn-out strumpet; a vixenish woman; a hag.Such a weak, watery, wicked old harridan, substituted for the prettycreature I had been used to see. De Quincey.
, A female heir.

The art of curing, founded on resemblances; the theory and itspractice that disease is cured (tuto, cito, et jucunde) by remedieswhich produce on a healthy person effects similar to the symptoms ofthe complaint under which the patient suffers, the remedies beingusually administered in minute doses. This system was founded by Dr.Samuel Hahnemann, and is opposed to allopathy, or heteropathy.[Written also homoepathy.]
According to the principles of interpretation; as, a verse ofScripture was examined hermeneutically.
A tumor filled with blood.
One who, or that which, heals.
One skilled in hydrology.

A nitrogenous, organic base, NH2.OH, resembling ammonia, andproduced by a modified reduction of nitric acid. It is usuallyobtained as a volatile, unstable solution in water. It acts as astrong reducing agent.
One born of a European parent on the one side, and of a Hindooor Mohammedan on the other. Also adjective; as, half-caste parents.
A form of hygrometer having wet and dry bulb thermometers, withan adjustable index showing directly the percentage of moisture inthe air, etc.
Afflicted with headache. [Colloq.]
Of or belonging to that part or end which is in the rear, orwhich follows; as, the hinder part of a wagon; the hinder parts of ahorse.He was in the hinder part of the ship. Mark iv. 38.
One of two or more words identical in orthography, but havingdifferent derivations and meanings; as, fair, n., a market, and fair,a., beautiful.
Home. [North of Eng.] Chaucer.
Having a complete metamorphosis;-said of certain insects, asthe butterflies and bees.
Prepared in hell. Milton.
Same as Inhabitancy.
A herbalist.
One who humbugs.
A low-grade actor or performer. [Theatrical Slang]
A fog; esp., a fog or mist with a chill wind. [Scot.] T.Chalmers.
See Hie. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Sounding dreadfully; uttering a terrible sound. [Obs.] Bailey.
The greater shearwater or hagdon. See Hagdon.
A feast or merry-making made by or for a family or businessfirm on taking possession of a new house or premises. Johnson.
Ebony. [Obs.] Spenser.
A straight line considered as drawn from a center to anindefinite distance in one direction, the complete ray being thewhole line drawn to an indefinite distance in both directions.
A large nocturnal beetle of the genus Lucanus (as L. capreolus,and L. dama), having long, curved upper jaws, resembling a sickle.The grubs are found in the trunks of old trees.
In the middle; at half the distance; imperfectly; partially;as, he halfway yielded.Temples proud to meet their gods halfway. Young.
By chance. [Obs.]
See Hoarding, 2. Smart.
See Hockey. Holloway.

A member of one description of roof truss, called hammer-beamtruss, which is so framed as not to have a tiebeam at the top of thewall. Each principal has two hammer-beams, which occupy thesituation, and to some extent serve the purpose, of a tiebeam.
A solid hemihedrally derived. The tetrahedron is a hemihedron.

A figure consisting of a transference of attributes from theirproper subjects to other. Thus Virgil says, "dare classibus austros,"to give the winds to the fleets, instead of dare classibus austris,to give the fleets to the winds.The hypallage, of which Virgil is fonder than any other writer, ismuch the gravest fault in language. Landor.
A slave in ancient Sparta; a Spartan serf; hence, a slave orserf.Those unfortunates, the Helots of mankind, more or less numerous inevery community. I. Taylor.
The group of hydroids to which the fresh-water hydras belong.
Variant of Hote. [Obs.]But one avow to greate God I hete. Chaucer.
The power of producing two kinds of reproductive bodies, as inAmphicarpæa, in which besides the usual pods, there are othersunderground.
Of or pertaining to certain non-fossiliferous rocks on theborders of Lake Huron, which are supposed to correspond in time tothe latter part of the Archæan age.
Possession; goods; estate.I 'll lend you something; my having is not much. Shak.
The under side of the toes.
Sounding harshly in the throat; inharmonious; rough. [Obs.]Carew.
A maker of clocks, watches, or dials.
Sacred writing. [R.] Bailey.
Resembling the normal tissues; as, histoid tumors.
A pteroid of the genus Cavolina. See Pteropoda, andIllustration in Appendix.
Pertaining to a line of eleven syllables.

That branch of the science of mechanics which relates tofluids, or, as usually limited, which treats of the laws of motionand action of nonelastic fluids, whether as investigatedmathematically, or by observation and experiment; the principles ofdynamics, as applied to water and other fluids.
The state of being hoary. Dryden.
Sweet as honey. Chaucer.
The disposition or the practice of a hector; a bullying. [R.]

A shrub or small tree of the genus Corylus, as the C. avellana,bearing a nut containing a kernel of a mild, farinaceous taste; thefilbert. The American species are C. Americana, which produces thecommon hazelnut, and C. rostrata. See Filbert. Gray.
Same as Hematinometric.
A collection of the Holy Scriptures in six languages or sixversions in parallel columns; particularly, the edition of the OldTestament published by Origen, in the 3d century.
The unit of electric induction; the induction in a circuit whenthe electro-motive force induced in this circuit is one volt, whilethe inducing current varies at the rate of one ampère a second.
Of or pertaining to hylozoism.
Whole. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One skilled in hygiena; a hygienist.

Any furniture, movable, or personal chattel, which by law orspecial custom descends to the heir along with the inheritance; anypiece of personal property that has been in a family for severalgenerations.Woe to him whose daring hand profanes The honored heirlooms of hisancestors. Moir.
A salt of hydrofluosilic acid; a silicofluoride. SeeSilicofluoride.
The science which treats of the blood. Same as Hematology.
An abnormal state of the voice. Mayne.
A name given to a vase having a rounded body; esp.:(a) A closed vessel of nearly spherical form on a high stem orpedestal. Fairholt.(b) A drinking cup having a foot and stem.
The state of being huffish; petulance; bad temper. Ld. Lytton.
A boot with a short top covering only the ankle. See Cocker,and Congress boot, under Congress.
Of or pertaining to the Hebrews; as, the Hebrew language orrites.
Having the form of a helix; spiral.
A tree of the genus Carpinus, of compact, horny texture;hornbeam.
An acid containing hydrogen; -- sometimes applied todistinguish acids like hydrochloric, hydrofluoric, and the like,which contain no oxygen, from the oxygen acids or oxacids. See Acid.
The art or practice of hunting, or the qualification of ahunter. Donne.
Without a harbor; shelterless.
The British sand lance or sand eel (Ammodytes lanceolatus).

To lie concealed; to keep one's self out of view; to bewithdrawn from sight or observation.Bred to disguise, in public 'tis you hide. Pope.Hide and seek, a play of children, in which some hide themselves, andothers seek them. Swift.
Shocked; dismayed.
Fast by contract; betrothed by joining hands. [Obs.] Bale.
An order of small hoofed mammals, comprising the single livinggenus Hyrax.
One of a series of artificial, organic bases, usually producedas thick viscous liquids by the action of ammonia on ethylene oxide.They have the properties both of alcohol and amines.
Same as Hemialbumose.
To make a rolling or burring sound. [Obs.]R is the dog's letter, and hurreth in the sound. B. Jonson.
To hock; to hamstring. See Hock. [Obs.] Shak.

A crystalline or amorphous pigment, free from iron, formed fromhematin in old blood stains, and in old hemorrhages in the body. Itresembles bilirubin. When present in the corpora lutea it is calledhæmolutein.

A curve described by the moving extremity of a line the otherend of which is fixed, this line being constantly parallel to thedirection of motion of, and having its length constantly proportionalto the velocity of, a point moving in any path; -used ininvestigations respecting central forces.
A sea turtle (Eretmochelys imbricata), which yields the bestquality of tortoise shell; -- called also caret.
Half the length of a sword; close fight. "At half-sword." Shak.
A treatise upon, or a history and description of, the water ofthe earth.
A cutting for the cure or relief of hernia; celotomy.
Same as Hæma-, Hæmo-.

A modified respiratory movement; a spasmodic inspiration,consisting of a sudden contraction of the diaphragm, accompanied withclosure of the glottis, so that further entrance of air is prevented,while the impulse of the column of air entering and striking upon theclosed glottis produces a sound, or hiccough. [Written also hickup orhiccup.]
An officer who is appointed to guard hedges, and to keep cattlefrom breaking or cropping them, and whose further duty it is toimpound animals found running at large.
Undercutting in a bed of coal, in order to bring down the uppermass. Raymond.
In a hovering manner.
A picture obtained by the process of heliotypy.
Similar to, or in the style of, the poem "Hudibras," by SamuelButler; in the style of doggerel verse. Macaulay.
A kind of linen cloth with raised figures, used for towelings.
A possession; the Israelites, as God's chosen people; also, aflock under pastoral charge. Joel iii. 2.1 Peter v. 3.
State of being hereditable. Brydges.
See Hydropathy.
See Badderlocks.

A form of sleep or somnambulism brought on by artificial means,in which there is an unusual suspension of some powers, and anunusual activity of others. It is induced by an action upon thenerves, through the medium of the senses, as in persons of veryfeeble organization, by gazing steadly at a very bright object heldbefore the eyes, or by pressure upon certain points of the surface ofthe body.
That branch of biological science, which treats of the minute(microscopic) structure of animal and vegetable tissues; -- calledalso histiology.
Probably a corruption either of charlock or hardock. Drayton.

Maintaining a uniform temperature; hæmatothermal; homothermic;-- applied to warm-bodied animals, because they maintain a nearlyuniform temperature in spite of the great variations in thesurrounding air; in distinct from the cold-blooded (poikilothermal)animals, whose body temperature follows the variations in temperatureof the surrounding medium.
A kind of linen first manufactured in Holland; a linen fabricused for window shades, children's garments, etc.; as, brown orunbleached hollands.
See Eagre. [Obs.] Drayton.
Toward heaven.
Heterogeneous.
Tumult; bustle; confusion. Shak.All places were filled with tumult and hurly-burly. Knolles.
The act or process of producing hypnotism.
Same as Hydrosulphurent.
Wood allowed to a tenant for repairing the house and for fuel.This latter is often called firebote. See Bote.
Bearing two kinds of heads or capitula; -- said of certaincomposite plants.
A low-lying meadow by the side of a river. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]On a haugh or level plain, near to a royal borough. Sir W. Scott.
To wander; to go astray; to err; to blunder; -- used of mentalprocesses. [R.] Byron.
Looking upward; supercilious. Shak.
Bearing or covered with hair; made of or resembling hair; roughwith hair; rough with hair; rough with hair; hirsute.His mantle hairy, and his bonnet sedge. Milton.
Same as Hachure.
Spur gearing having teeth slanting across the face of thewheel, sometimes slanting in opposite directions from the middle.
One of a party among the Jews, composed of partisans of Herodof Galilee. They joined with the Pharisees against Christ.
Clear space under an arch, girder, and the like, sufficient toallow of easy passing underneath.
Those books of the New Testament which were acknowledged ascanonical by the early church; -- distinguished from antilegomena.
Of relating to the hemerobians.

The quarters or place of residence of any chief officer, as thegeneral in command of an army, or the head of a police force; theplace from which orders or instructions are issued; hence, the centerof authority or order.The brain, which is the headquarters, or office, of intelligence.Collier.
One of a breed of cattle, originally from Schleswig-Holstein,valued for the large amount of milk produced by the cows. The coloris usually black and white in irregular patches.
Place of a home; homestead. Cowper.
A division of Coleoptera, having heteromerous tarsi.
Exhibiting a downward convexity caused by unequal growth. Cf.Epinastic.
The upper stage of a porcelian furnace.
Pertaining to one or more small elements in the hyoidean archof fishes, between the caratohyal and urohyal.-- n.
A description of, or treatise on, organic tissues.

Pertaining to, or obtained from, the peanut, or earthnut(Arachis hypogæa). Hypogæic acid (Chem.), an acid in the oil of theearthnut, in which it exists as a glyceride, and from which it isextracted as a white, crystalline substance.
Of or pertaining to the Hydrozoa.
One of a warlike nomadic people of Northern Asia who, in the5th century, under Atilla, invaded and conquered a great part ofEurope.
Belonging to horometry.
A road or way open to the use of the public; a main road orthoroughfare.
Mankind. Pope.
The person at a geodetic station who has charge of theheliotrope.

Pertaining to, or containing, hydrogen and fluorine;fluohydric; as, hydrofluoric acid. Hydrofluoric acid (Chem.), acolorless, mobile, volatile liquid, HF, very corrosive in its action,and having a strong, pungent, suffocating odor. It is produced by theaction of sulphuric acid on fluorite, and is usually collected as asolution in water. It attacks all silicates, as glass or porcelain,is the agent employed in etching glass, and is preserved only invessels of platinum, lead, caoutchouc, or gutta-percha.

To lean or tip to one side, as a ship; as, the ship heelsaport; the boat heeled over when the squall struck it. Heeling error(Naut.), a deviation of the compass caused by the heeling of an ironvessel to one side or the other.
The bank of a canal opposite, and corresponding to, that of thetowpath; berm. [U. S.]
Covered with herbs. [Obs.] Bailey.

A genus of perennial herbs (Helleborus) of the Crowfoot family,mostly having powerfully cathartic and even poisonous qualities. H.niger is the European black hellebore, or Christmas rose, blossomingin winter or earliest spring. H. officinalis was the officinalhellebore of the ancients.
See Uhlan.
A midwife. [Prov. Eng.]
Perchloric; as, hyperoxymuriatic acid. [Obs.]
Subject to homage. Howell.
Relating to heterogenesis; as, heterogenetic transformations.
A prexif used in anatomy, and generally denoting connectionwith the hyoid bone or arch; as, hyoglossal, hyomandibular,hyomental, etc.
One who does homage, or holds land of another by homage; avassal. Bacon.
Any one of five hydrocarbons, C6H14, of the paraffin series.They are colorless, volatile liquids, and are so called because themolecule has six carbon atoms.
Hawthorn. R. Scot.
of Hang. Hung beef, the fleshy part of beef slightly salted andhung up to dry; dried beef.
Heritage; inheritance. [R.]Robbing their children of the heritance Their fathers handed downSouthey.
With hesitancy or doubt.
Hastate.

Of or pertaining to a hypocrite, or to hypocrisy; as, ahypocriticalperson; a hypocritical look; a hypocritical action.Hypocritical professions of friendship and of pacific intentions werenot spared. Macaulay.-- Hyp`o*crit"ic*al*ly, adv.
An artificial, orange dyestuff, analogous to tropaolin, andlike it used as an indicator in alkalimetry; -- called also methylorange.
A disease in which worms are present in some part of the body.
A photograph in colors. R. Hunt.
Hygiene.
Of or pertaining to heliography or a heliograph; made byheliography. Heliographic chart. See under Chart.
The name of several poisonous umbelliferous herbs having finelycut leaves and small white flowers, as the Cicuta maculata,bulbifera, and virosa, and the Conium maculatum. See Conium.
The office or character of a hangman.
A free-swimming, dimorphic, sexual form of certain species ofNereis.
An obligation by which property of a debtor was made over tohis creditor in security of his debt.
Heartache; sorrow. Milton.
A pellucid variety of opal in globules looking like colorlessgum or resin; -- called also Müller's glass.
A sacred or holy work or worship. [Obs.] Waterland.
A soft black, iron ore, nearly earthy, a hydrous silicate ofiron.
A constellation; Lyra, or the Lyre.
Whole. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Harbor dues; port dues.
The science which treats of the precipitation of rain, snow,etc. -- Hy`e*to*log"ic*al, a.
The first month after marriage. Addison.
Containing heresy; of the nature of, or characterized by,heresy.
A species of violet (Viola tricolor); -- called also pansy.
The second lateral plate in the plastron of turtles; -- calledalso hyosternum.
Like, or allied to, the porcupines; -- said of a group(Hystricomorpha) of rodents.
One who writes on heresies.
A heron. [Written variously hernshaw, harnsey, etc.]
A cheer; a shout of joy, etc. Hurrah's nest, state of utmostconfusion. [Colloq. U.S.]A perfect hurrah's nest in our kitchen. Mrs. Stowe.
Headstrong.That hot-mouthed beast that bears against the curb. Dryden.
The state or quality of being humoral.
A defensive covering for the head. See Casque, Headpiece,Morion, Sallet, and Illust. of Beaver.
A hybrid between a stallion and an ass.
Warm-blooded.
A form of apparatus (somewhat different from the hemadrometer)for measuring the velocity of the blood.
A kind of graduated breech sight for a small arm, or a cannon.
A glucoside found in ripe and unripe fruit (as the orange), andextracted as a white crystalline substance.
One of a group of crystalline bodies produced by the action ofammonia on certain aldehydes.
Theatrical representation; acting; affectation. Sir T. Browne.
A genus of leguminous plants containing but a single species,the H. Campechianum or logwood tree, native in Yucatan.
The anatomy or dissection of reptiles.
Hoity-toity.
The red-breasted merganser.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained by thereduction of sulphurous acid. See Hyposulphurous acid, underHyposulphurous.
See Hoonoomaun.
A small, strong-winged European falcon (Falco subbuteo),formerly trained for hawking.
Relating to Hygeia, the goddess of health; of or pertaining tohealth, or its preservation.

Belonging to man or mankind; having the qualities or attributesof a man; of or pertaining to man or to the race of man; as, a humanvoice; human shape; human nature; human sacrifices.To err is human; to forgive, divine. Pope.
A cloth for covering a coffin when on a bier; a pall. Bp.Sanderson.

Of, pertaining to, or derived from, mutton suet; -- applied byChevreul to an oily acid which was obtained from mutton suet, and towhich he attributed the peculiar taste and smell of that substance.The substance has also been called hircin. Watts.
Same as Centaur.
An alkaloid accompanying harmaline (in the Peganum harmala),and obtained from it by oxidation. It is a white crystallinesubstance.
A gallery, drift, or adit in a mine; also, the end of a driftor gallery; the vein above a drift.
To greet; to salute. [Obs.] P. Plowman.
Confusedly; in a bustle. [Obs.] Gray.
One who heaps, piles, or amasses.
A chief or great heresy. [R.]The book itself [the Alcoran] consists of heresiarchies against ourblessed Savior. Sir T. Herbert.
A palsy that affects one side only of the body.-- Hem`i"pleg"ic, a.
Behavior; demeanor. [Obs.] Shak.
Toward the hæmal side; on the hæmal side of; -- opposed toneurad.
A figure in which the idea is expressed by two nouns connectedby and, instead of by a noun and limiting adjective; as, we drinkfrom cups and gold, for golden cups.
The condition of being horned.
A play or part of play in which the harlequin is conspicuous;the part of a harlequin. Macaulay.
In haste; foothot. [Colloq.]
Of or pertaining to a hermit; solitary; secluded from society.Pope.
One who makes excessively nice or needless distinctions inreasoning; one who quibbles. "The caviling hairsplitter." De Quincey.
Of or pert. to hysteresis. -- Hysteretic constant, thehysteretic loss in ergs per cubic centimeter per cycle.
A frame or barrow, without a wheel, carried by hand.
The Anthozoa.
Of half the whole or ordinary length, as a picture.

Light vapor or smoke in the air which more or less impedesvision, with little or no dampness; a lack of transparency in theair; hence, figuratively, obscurity; dimness.O'er the sky The silvery haze of summer drawn. Tennyson.Above the world's uncertain haze. Keble.
In the following part of this (writing, document, speech, andthe like).
Humidity.
A hospital.
Having or containing hulls.
Ten times ten; five score; as, a hundred dollars.
Impregnating with sulphureted hydrogen gas. [Obs.]

Any bird of the family Bucerotidæ, of which about sixty speciesare known, belonging to numerous genera. They inhabit the tropicalparts of Asia, Africa, and the East Indies, and are remarkable forhaving a more or less horn-like protuberance, which is usually largeand hollow and is situated on the upper side of the beak. The size ofthe hornbill varies from that of a pigeon to that of a raven, or evenlarger. They feed chiefly upon fruit, but some species eat deadanimals.

An American tree of the genus Carya, of which there are severalspecies. The shagbark is the C. alba, and has a very rough bark; itaffords the hickory nut of the markets. The pignut, or brown hickory,is the C. glabra. The swamp hickory is C. amara, having a nut whoseshell is very thin and the kernel bitter. Hickory shad. (Zoöl.) (a)The mattowacca, or fall herring. (b) The gizzard shad.
To starve with hunger; to famish. [Obs.] Shak.
A sister by one parent only.
Having the maxilla, or lower jaw, longer than the upper, as inthe skimmer.
One of a class of respiratory pigments, widely distributed inthe animal kingdom, capable of ready oxidation and reduction.
A large sturgeon (Acipenser huso) from the region of the BlackSea. It is sometimes twelve feet long.
The act or employment of shoeing horses.
Emitting a murmuring sound; droning; murmuring; buzzing.

The hard, central part of the trunk of a tree, consisting ofthe old and matured wood, and usually differing in color from theouter layers. It is technically known as duramen, and distinguishedfrom the softer sapwood or alburnum.
A figure of speech by which one form of a noun, verb, orpronoun, and the like, is used for another, as in the sentence: "Whatis life to such as me" Aytoun.
A large berry with a thick rind, as a lemon or an orange.

A person given as a pledge or security for the performance ofthe conditions of a treaty or stipulations of any kind, on theperformance of which the person is to be released.Your hostages I have, so have you mine; And we shall talk before wefight. Shak.He that hath a wife and children hath given hostages to fortune.Bacon.
In the British Indian armies, a noncommissioned officer ofnative soldiers, corresponding to a sergeant. Havildar major, anative sergeant major in the East Indian army.
Pertaining to, or invented by, Christian Huyghens, a Dutchastronomer of the seventeenth century; as, the Huyghenian telescope.Huyghenian eyepieceSee under Eyepiece.
See Jumping hare, under Hare.
Any substance, such as an iron salt or organic compoundcontaining iron, which when ingested tends to increase the hemoglobincontents of the blood.
Having seven units of attractive force or affinity; -- said ofheptad elements or radicals.
That which has the same fundamental type of structure withsomething else; thus, the right arm is the homotype of the right leg;one arm is the homotype of the other, etc. Owen.
Relating to, or characterized by, heterotaxy.

To cut roughly or hack; to cut into small pieces; to notch orcut in an unskillful manner; to make rough or mangle by cutting; as,a boy haggles a stick of wood.Suffolk first died, and York, all haggled o'er, Comes to him, wherein gore he lay insteeped. Shak.
One of a small breed of hounds, used for hunting hares.[Written also harier.]
The garfish. [Prov. Eng.]
One of several species of flowering plants, much admired fortheir beauty, and some for their fragrance.
Resembling hydrocephalus. Hydrocephaloid affection (Med.), thegroup of symptoms which follow exhausting diarrhea in young children,resembling those of acute hydrocephalus, or tubercular meningitis.
Bearing a small hook at the end. Gray.

An extinct genus of Tertiary mammals allied to the horse, butthree-toed, having on each foot a small lateral hoof on each side ofthe main central one. It is believed to be one of the ancestralgenera of the Horse family.
Rehearsal. [Obs.] Spenser.
A combining form from Gr. "epta`, seven.
Drooping at the ends; arching;-in distinction from sagging.Hogging frame. See Hogframe.
The act of combining with hydrogen, or the state of being socombined.
An accumulation of serous fluid in the cavity of the chest.
Hydrotic.
See Whortleberry.
One of the nutritive zooids of a hydroid colony. Also appliedto the proboscis or manubrium of a hydroid medusa. See Illust. ofHydroidea.
Excessive conservatism; hostility to progress. [Political Cant,U.S.]
To make human; to invest with a human personality; toincarnate. [R.]The humanifying of the divine Word. H. B. Wilson.
A book containing the list and pedigrees of one or more herdsof choice breeds of cattle; -- also called herd record, or herdregister.
A Spanish idiom or mode of speech. Keightley.
Pertaining to, or derived from, hexdecyl or hecdecane; as,hexdecylic alcohol.
Tending to cure; soothing; mollifying; as, the healing art; ahealing salve; healing words.Here healing dews and balms abound. Keble.
The form of the objective and the possessive case of thepersonal pronoun she; as, I saw her with her purse out.
One whose judgment and acts are affected by hallucinations; onewho errs on account of his hallucinations. N. Brit. Rev.
An extinct genus of sharks having conical, compressed teeth.
Of the color of the hazelnut; of a light brown. Mortimer.

The perception of objects which have no reality, or ofsensations which have no corresponding external cause, arising fromdisorder or the nervous system, as in delirium tremens; delusion.Hallucinations are always evidence of cerebral derangement and arecommon phenomena of insanity. W. A. Hammond.
One versed in the phenomena of history and the laws controllingthem.And historionomers will have measured accurately the sidereal yearsof races. Lowell.
That part of an elliptical or many-centered arch which has theshorter radius and immediately adjoins the impost.
A circumscribed swelling produced by an effusion of bloodbeneath the skin.
A superior officer or official; -- used chiefly in pl. [Slang]
Pertaining to, or containing, or obtained from, hydrogen,ferrous iron, and cyanogen; as, hydroferrocyanic acid. SeeFerrocyanic.
A weed of the genus Lamium (L. amplexicaule) with deeplycrenate leaves.
To place in happiness or bliss, as if in heaven; to beatify.[R.]We are happy as the bird whose nest Is heavened in the hush of purplehills. G. Massey.
Pain in the head; ceph "Headaches and shivering fits."Macaulay.
A nematoid worm of the genus Gordius, resembling a hair. SeeGordius.
Extravagant in opinions or ambition. "Highflying, arbitrarykings." Dryden.
One who hearkens; a listener.
In this.Herein is my Father glorified, that ye bear much fruit. John xv. 8.
A device in an incubator for protecting the young chickens andkeeping them warm.
Same as Haulm.
To separate from the awns; -- said of barley. [Scot.]
Having six petals.
That department of sanitary science which treats of thepreservation of health, esp. of households and communities; a systemof principles or rules designated for the promotion of health.
An alkaloid found with hyoscyamine (with which it is alsoisomeric) in henbane, and extracted as a white, amorphous, semisolidsubstance.
A French Protestant of the period of the religious wars inFrance in the 16th century.
A common evergreen oak, of Europe (Quercus Ilex); -- calledalso ilex, and holly.
Rustic; rude; bold. Younq.

An instrument devised originally for measuring the diameter ofthe sun; now employed for delicate measurements of the distance andrelative direction of two stars too far apart to be easily measuredin the field of view of an ordinary telescope.

; sing. Huron. (Ethnol.) A powerful and warlike tribe of NorthAmerican Indians of the Algonquin stock. They formerly occupied thecountry between Lakes Huron, Erie, and Ontario, but were nearlyexterminated by the Five Nations about 1650.
Hoariness; antiquity. [R.]Covered with the awful hoar of innumerable ages. Burke.
An exclamation used in addressing a familiar acquaintance.[Obs.] Shak.
A blusterer; a bully. [Obs.] -- a.
Government by a priesthood; hierarchy.
A red variety of zircon, sometimes used as a gem. See Zircon.Hyacinth bean (Bot.), a climbing leguminous plant (Dolichos Lablab),related to the true bean. It has dark purple flowers and fruit.
A stocking without a foot, worn by coal miners at work.
One of the writers of the hagiographa; a writer of lives of thesaints. Shipley.

The Egyptian asp or cobra (Naja haje.) It is related to thecobra of India, and like the latter has the power of inflating itsneck into a hood. Its bite is very venomous. It is supposed to be thesnake by means of whose bite Cleopatra committed suicide, and henceis sometimes called Cleopatra's snake or asp. See Asp.
To subject to petty authority; -- said of a wife who thustreats her husband. Commonly used in the past participle (oftenadjectively).
A bone near the middle of the buttock of a horse. Crabb.
A rich goblet, esp. one used on state occasions. [Obs.]
Destitute of an heir. Shak.
The philosophical system of Thomas Hobbes, an Englishmaterialist (
An order of elasmobranch fishes, including, among livingspecies, only the chimæras; -- called also Holocephala. See Chimæra;also Illustration in Appendix.

The quality or state of being harsh.O, she is Ten times more gentle than her father 's crabbed, And he'scomposed of harshness. Shak.'Tis not enough no harshness gives offense, The sound must seem anecho to the sense. Pope.
That mode of treating diseases, by which a morbid condition isremoved by inducing an opposite morbid condition to supplant it;allopathy.
Of or pertaining to hell; like hell; infernal; malignant;wicked; detestable; diabolical. "Hellish hate." Milton.-- Hell"ish*ly, adv.-- Hell"ish*ness, n.
An artificial division of gastropods, including those that havean entire aperture.
Of or pertaining to hematite, or resembling it.
A stone with spangles of gold color in it.
Of or pertaining to, or favoring, the party called the HighChurch, or their doctrines or policy. See High Church, under High, a.
An inclosed place for keeping hens. [U. S.]
All right; in a good condition; also, even; square. [Slang, U.S.]
See Gastrohepatic.
An opinion or doctrine, or a system of doctrines, contrary tosome established standard of faith, as the Scriptures, the creed orstandards of a church, etc.; heresy. Bp. Bull.
A wind instrument, sounded through a reed, and similar in shapeto the clarinet, but with a thinner tone. Now more commonly calledoboe. See Illust. of Oboe.
Having six sides and six angles; six-sided. Hexagonal system.(Crystal.) See under Crystallization.
The quality of being hearty; as, the heartiness of a greeting.

A plant of the genus Marrubium (M. vulgare), which has a bittertaste, and is a weak tonic, used as a household remedy for colds,coughing, etc. [Written also hoarhound.] Fetid horehound, or Blackhorehound, a disagreeable plant resembling horehound (Ballota nigra).-- Water horehound, a species of the genus Lycopus, resembling mint,but not aromatic.
Situated below an artery; applied esp. to the branches of thebronchi given off below the point where the pulmonary artery crossesthe bronchus.
The silver moonfish (Selene vomer).

A surface of the second order, which is cut by certain planesin hyperbolas; also, the solid, bounded in part by such a surface.Hyperboloid of revolution, an hyperboloid described by an hyperbolarevolving about one of its axes. The surface has two separate sheetswhen the axis of revolution is the transverse axis, but only one whenthe axis of revolution is the conjugate axis of the hyperbola.
Hungered; hungry. [Archaic]
A composition consisting of seven lines or verses.
To make a predatory incursion; to plunder or lay waste. [Obs.]Beau. & Fl.
See Hagbut.
Steel hardened by the addition of other elements, as manganese,phosphorus, or (usually) carbon.
The doctrine that matter is sentient. Krauth-Fleming.
See Cyamellone.
Hemicranis.
Having the vertebral column evidently continued into the upperlobe of the tail, which is usually longer than the lower one, as insharks.
Firmly established by custom; formed by habit; habitual. [R.]Hammond.
A system of treating disease by baths and mineral waters.
The European blue titmouse (Parus coeruleus). [Written alsoheckimel, hackeymal, hackmall, hagmall, and hickmall.]
A sunk fence; a fence, wall, or ditch, not visible till one isclose upon it. [Written also haw-haw.]
In a husky manner; dryly.
The epoch or time during which a deposit was made.The strata all over the earth, which were formed at the same time,are said to belong to the same geological horizon. Le Conte.
The hard substratum. Same as Hard pan, under Hard, a.

Moisture; dampness; a moderate degree of wetness, which isperceptible to the eye or touch; -- used especially of theatmosphere, or of anything which has absorbed moisture from theatmosphere, as clothing.
A small European rodent (Cricetus frumentarius). It isremarkable for having a pouch on each side of the jaw, under theskin, and for its migrations.
Made transparent by immersion in water.
Having the leaves expand after the flowers have opened.Henslow.
A coarse, blackish seaweed. See Badderlocks.
A carrier pigeon remarkable for its ability to return home froma distance.
A herdsman. [R.]
See Habile. [Obs.] Spenser.
An illustrious man, supposed to be exalted, after death, to aplace among the gods; a demigod, as Hercules.
A plane figure of eleven sides and eleven angles. [Written alsoendecagon.]
A hydrosulphide. [Archaic]
Same as Horehound.
A hag of or fit for hell. Bp. Richardson.
That part of a boltrope which is sewed to the upper edge orhead of a sail.
Having a keen eye; sharpsighted; discerning.
A fight with the hands; boxing. "Pollux loves handyfights." B.Jonson.
Having the breadth of a hair; very narrow; as, a hairbreadthescape.
Hesitating. R. North.
One of the flat, leaflike, protective zooids, covering otherzooids of certain Siphonophora.
A screw cut on a solid whose sides are arcs of the periphery ofa wheel into the teeth of which the screw is intended to work. It isnamed from the person who first used the form.
A howitzer. [Obs.]
Heteromorphic.
A practitioner of homeopathy. [Written also homoeopath.]
A Rhenish wine. [Obs.] See Hock. Hudibras.
A landlord's right, independently of stipulation, over thestocking (cattle, implements, etc.), and crops of his tenant, assecurity for payment of rent.
To shelter, as in a haven. Keats.
Having the mandible suspended by the hyomandibular, or upperpart of the hyoid arch, as in fishes, instead of directly articulatedwith the skull as in mammals; -- said of the skull.
Wanting half its due qualities. [Obs.] Spencer.
The subterraneous portion of a building, as in amphitheaters,for the service of the games; also, subterranean galleries, as thecatacombs.
A figurative construction, changing or inverting the naturalorder of words or clauses; as, "echoed the hills" for "the hillsechoed."With a violent hyperbaton to transpose the text. Milton.
The homology of parts arranged on transverse axes. Haeckel.
A childish play, in which one covers his eyes, and guesses whostrikes him or his hand placed behind him.
Humble condition or estate; humility. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A sweetmeat of boiled brown sugar or molasses made withalmonds, and flavored with orange or lemon juice, etc. Thackeray.
The business of the mistress of a family; female management ofdomestic concerns.
One of the suckerlike rootlets of such plants as the dodder andivy. R. Brown.
A mode of execution in engraving, drawing, and miniaturepainting, in which shading is produced by lines crossing each otherat angles more or less acute; -- called also crosshatching.
an ovum composed entirely of germinal matter. See Meroblast.
A diminution in the normal amount of fibrin present in theblood.
A rake for collecting hay; especially, a large rake drawn by ahorse or horses.
Rude, boisterous play.Too much given to horseplay in his raillery. Dryden.
A plant of the genus Verbascum (V. Thapsus); the commonmullein. [Also high-taper and hag-taper.]
Of or pert. to the German physicist Heinrich Hertz.
The third eyelid, or nictitating membrane. See Nictitatingmembrane, under Nictitate.
An allowance of wood to a tenant for repairing his hedges orfences; hedgebote. See Bote. Blackstone.
Containing, or pertaining to, a hemisphere; as, a hemisphericfigure or form; a hemispherical body.

Satin flower; the name of two cruciferous herbs having largeflat pods, the round shining partitions of which are more beautifulthan the blossom; -- called also lunary and moonwort. Lunaria biennisis common honesty; L. rediva is perennial honesty.
The flight of Mohammed from Mecca, September 13, A. D. 622(subsequently established as the first year of the Moslem era);hence, any flight or exodus regarded as like that of Mohammed.
Of or pertaining to homoplasty; as, homoplasticorgans;homoplastic forms.
A photographic picture copied from the negative on glass; aphotographic transparency. R. Hunt.
Them. See Hem. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Resting upon columns; constructed by means of columns; --especially applied to the great hall at Karnak.
Coarseness of features.
A space equal to the breadth of the hand; a palm. Ex. xxxvii.12.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a humorist.
Of or pertaining to hydrogen; containing hydrogen.
Lofty; haughty. [Obs.]Through support of countenance proud and hault. Spenser.
A ship's masthead. Shak.
To render obtuse; to dull; to blunt; to stupefy; as, tohebetate the intellectual faculties. Southey
To ornament at the head of a broad hem by drawing out a fewparallel threads, and fastening the cross threads in successive smallclusters; as, to hemstitch a handkerchief.
See 2d Hanse.
To higgle in trading. [Obs.] Holland.
To harden; to make hard. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A drying shed, as for unburned tile.
Of or pertaining to the Hyracoidea.-- n.
An oval lobe beneath each of the optic lobes in many fishes;one of the inferior lobes. Owen.

Larger than life size, but smaller than colossal; -- said ofthe representation of a human figure. Heroic Age, the age when theheroes, or those called the children of the gods, are supposed tohave lived.-- Heroic poetry, that which celebrates the deeds of a hero; epicpoetry.-- Heroic treatment or remedies (Med.), treatment or remedies of asevere character, suited to a desperate case.-- Heroic verse (Pros.), the verse of heroic or epic poetry, beingin English, German, and Italian the iambic of ten syllables; inFrench the iambic of twelve syllables; and in classic poetry thehexameter.
Divination by inspecting the liver of animals.
Completely crystalline; -- said of a rock like granite, all theconstituents of which are crystalline.
imp. & p. p. of Hold.
Deviating from ordinary forms or rules; irregular; anomalous;abnormal.
Alternating transparent and opaque white rings which are seenoutside the blastoderm, on the surface of the developing egg of thehen and other birds.
A frame or support for holding something in place, as journalboxes, etc.
Having a high or noble spirit; honorable. E. Everett.
Who. [Obs.] In some Chaucer MSS.
Exaggerated; excessive; hyperbolical. [Obs.]Hyperthetical or superlative . . . expression. Chapman.
Covered with a hat.
Uniformly bending or curving to one side; -- said of leaveswhich grow on several sides of a stem.
A shepherdess; a female herder. Sir P. Sidney. Chaucer.
Nearest on this side. Sir M. Hale.
One who holds a shield over another; hence, a defender. [Obs.]Chillingworth.
In a hopeful manner. Hammond.
One of the classes of echinoderms.
Composed largely of hornblende; resembling or relating tohornblende.
A member of a chapter or convent, whose week it is to officiatein the choir, and perform other services, which, on extraordinaryoccasions, are performed by the superiors.
Historical narration on a small scale; a brief recital; astory. Emerson.
One who describes organic tissues; an histologist.
Having all the teeth similar in front, as in the porpoises; --opposed to heterodont.
A harmless North American snake of the genus Heterodon, esp. H.platyrhynos; -- called also puffing adder, blowing adder, and sandviper.

A person competent to serve on a jury, in an action for land inthe hundred to which he belongs.
A hymn. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Pertaining to, or discovered by, Clopton Havers, an Englishphysician of the seventeenth century. Haversian canals (Anat.), thesmall canals through which the blood vessels ramify in bone.
Act of gaping. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A mechanical lift. See Elevator.
Destitute of honey. Shak.

An officer whose business was to denounce or proclaim war, tochallenge to battle, to proclaim peace, and to bear messages from thecommander of an army. He was invested with a sacred and inviolablecharacter.
A large basket, usually with a cover, used for the packing andcarrying of articles; as, a hamper of wine; a clothes hamper; anoyster hamper, which contains two bushels.
Resembling a hydatid.
pres. & imp. sing. & pl. of Hote, to be called. See Hote.[Obs.] Chaucer.A full perilous place, purgatory it hatte. Piers Plowman.
Up to this time; hitherto; before; in time past. Shak.
To raise; to elevate. [Obs.] Lydgate.
The act of hereticating or pronouncing heretical. London Times.
Filled with hommocks; piled in the form of hommocks; -- said ofice.
A place where hens roost.

The Limulus of horsehoe crab. Horsehoe head (Med.), an old namefor the condition of the skull in children, in which the sutures aretoo open, the coronal suture presenting the form of a horsehoe.Dunglison.-- Horsehoe magnet, an artificial magnet in the form of a horsehoe.-- Horsehoe nail. See Horsenail.-- Horsehoe nose (Zoöl.), a bat of the genus Rhinolophus, having anasal fold of skin shaped like a horsehoe.
A lifting or rising; a swell; a panting or deep sighing.Addison. Shak.
A bird of the Heron family; the umber.
A title of respect given to gentlemen in Germany, equivalent tothe English Mister.
Destitute of a home.-- Home"less*ness, n.

A nonplane curve whose tangents are all equally inclined to agiven plane. The common helix is the curve formed by the thread ofthe ordinary screw. It is distinguished from the spiral, all theconvolutions of which are in the plane.
Heathy; abounding in heather; of the nature of heath.
Same as Hæmachrome.
Native sulphide of manganese a reddish brown or brownish blackmineral.
Divination by observing the objects offered in sacrifice.
One who believes in hylopathism.
To horn; to cuckold. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.

An accumulation of liquid within the cavity of the cranium,especially within the ventricles of the brain; dropsy of the brain.It is due usually to tubercular meningitis. When it occurs ininfancy, it often enlarges the head enormously.
A term suggested by Haeckel to be instead of serial homology.See Homotype.
Sweet speaking; persuasive; seductive. Shak.
In Holland, and, until the 19th century, also in Cape Colony, acouncil to assist a local magistrate in the government of ruraldistricts; hence, also, a member of such a council.
The quality of being half; incompleteness. [R.]As soon as there is any departure from simplicity, and attempt athalfness, or good for me that is not good for him, my neighbor feelsthe wrong. Emerson.
An opening made in the interior walls of a cruciform church toafford a view of the altar to those in the transepts; -- called, inarchitecture, a squint. Hook.
The business of a housewife; female domestic economy and skill.Tusser.
Having the shape of a heart; cordate.

To listen; to hearken. [Now rare, except in the imperative formused as an interjection, Hark! listen.] Hudibras. Hark away! Harkback! Hark forward! (Sporting), cries used to incite and guide houndsin hunting.-- To hark back, to go back for a fresh start, as when one haswandered from his direct course, or made a digression.He must have overshot the mark, and must hark back. Haggard. Heharked back to the subject. W. E. Norris.
A warming cathartic medicine, made of aloes and canella bark.Dunglison.
A Hebrew exclamation of praise to the Lord, or an invocation ofblessings. "Hosanna to the Highest." Milton.Hosanna to the Son of David. Matt. xxi. 9.
One who hates.An enemy to God, and a hater of all good. Sir T. Browne.
Of or pertaining to Hibernia, now Ireland; Irish.-- n.
Same as Hybrid.

Correspondence or relation in type of structure incontradistinction to similarity of function; as, the relation instructure between the leg and arm of a man; or that between the armof a man, the fore leg of a horse, the wing of a bird, and the fin ofa fish, all these organs being modifications of one type ofstructure.
To take shelter or lodgings together; to reside in a collectivebody. Pope.
A white crystalline substance, C6H4(OH)2, obtained by thereduction of quinone. It is a diacid phenol, resembling, andmetameric with, pyrocatechin and resorcin. Called also dihydroxybenzene.
To adorn; to grace; to honor; to make becoming, appropriate, orhonorable. [Obs.] Abp. Sandys.
A real or fancied bristling of the hair of the head or body,resulting from disease, terror, chilliness, etc.
A household servant; also, one of the bodyguard of King Canute.
The roebuck in its third year. [Prov. Eng.]

Of or pertaining to history, or the record of past events; as,an historical poem; the historic page.-- His*tor"ic*al*ness, n.-- His*to*ric"i*ty, n.There warriors frowning in historic brass. Pope.Historical painting, that branch of painting which represents theevents of history.-- Historical sense, that meaning of a passage which is deduced fromthe circumstances of time, place, etc., under which it was written.-- The historic sense, the capacity to conceive and represent theunity and significance of a past era or age.
The Acalephæ; one of the classes of coelenterates, includingthe Hydroidea, Discophora, and Siphonophora.
See Hecdecane.
Halcyon; calm.
Having the spines of the dorsal fin unsymmetrical, or thickenedalternately on the right and left sides.
Same as Hæmatachometer.
Praising with hymns; singing. "The hymning choir." G. West.
In the manner of, or in accordance with, history.
A fragrant balsam obtained from Brazilian trees of the genusHumirium.
Steel containing a high percentage of carbon; high-carbonsteel.
The phenomenon of turning toward the light, seen in many leavesand flowers.
A division of bivalve shells, including the marine mussels, inwhich the two adductor muscles are very unequal. See Dreissena, andIllust. under Byssus.

Wholly or distinctively vegetable. Holophytic nutrition (, thatform of nutrition, characteristic of vegetable organisms, in whichcarbonic acid, ammonia, and nitrates are absorbed as food, indistinction from the animal mode of nutrition, by the ingestion ofalbuminous matter.
One who hopes. Swift.
To render handsome. [Obs.] Donne
Like a home or a home circle.Quiet, cheerful, homish hospital life. E. E. Hale.
See Holland.
Same as Hypoblast.
Hyacinthine. [R.]
Heliacal.
A handkerchief. [Obs. or Colloq.] Chapman (1654). Shak.

A bitter, brownish yellow, amorphous substance, extracted fromvegetable mold, and also produced by the action of acids on certainsugars and carbohydrates; -- called also humic acid, ulmin, gein,ulmic or geic acid, etc.
In a haggard manner. Dryden.
A caviler; a wrangler. [Obs.] Baret.
The state or quality of being horizontal. Kirwan.
The eucharist. [Archaic] Rom. of R. Tennyson.
Producing ivy; ivy-bearing.
Of or pertaining to the Hellenes, or inhabitants of Greece;Greek; Grecian. "The Hellenic forces." Jowett (Thucyd. ).
Originally, one of the national cavalry of Hungary and Croatia;now, one of the light cavalry of European armies.
A rake drawn by a horse.
Having little or nothing. [Obs.] Gower.
Having only the back and corners in leather, as a book.
Any North American river chub of the genus Hybopsis, esp. H.biguttatus.
Partaking of, or tending to produce, hallucination.

A case or bag. See Housewife, 2.
Impure ore; dirty ore.

A superabundance or congestion of blood in an organ or part ofthe body. Active hyperæmia, cognestion d%ue to increased flow ofblood to a part.-- Passive hyperæmia, interchange due to obstruction in the returnof blood from a part.-- Hy`per*æ"mic, a.

Of or pertaining to the parts under the skin. Hypodermicmedication, the application of remedies under the epidermis, usuallyby means of a small syringe, called the hypodermic syringe.-- Hyp`o*der"mic*al*ly, adv.
To make dry; to dry. [Obs.]
Pertaining to, or produced by, heliochromy.
A head or leading man, especially of a village community.
Same as Housling.
Same as Hemadynamometer.
A homilist.

One who plays a part; especially, one who, for the purpose ofwinning approbation of favor, puts on a fair outside seeming; one whofeigns to be other and better than he is; a false pretender to virtueor piety; one who simulates virtue or piety.The hypocrite's hope shall perish. Job viii. 13.I dare swear he is no hypocrite, but prays from his heart. Shak.
A woman who tends a herd. Sir W. Scott.
See Hæma-.
The external angle formed by the meeting of two sloping sidesor skirts of a roof, which have their wall plates running indifferent directions.
The general term for the Hebrew oral or traditional law; one oftwo branches of exposition in the Midrash. See Midrash.
To render like heaven or fit for heaven. [R.] Bp. Hall.
A colorless liquid hydrocarbon, C7H14, of the ethylene series;also, any one of its isomers. Called also heptene.
See Jurel.
Same as Hematosis.
Destitute of hoofs.
An instrument for recording automatically the variations of thehumidity of the atmosphere.

Capable of forming a hybrid, or of being subjected to ahybridizing process; capable of producing a hybrid by union withanother species or stock.Hybridizable genera are rarer than is generally supposed, even ingardens where they are so often operated upon, under circumstancesmost favorable to the production of hybrids. J. D. Hooker.
Excretion of sweat; perspiration.

A laced boot, ankle high.
Destitute of a hive. Gascoigne.

Having a dry and contracted hoof, which occasions pain andlameness.

A wild ass found in Thibet; the kiang. Darwin.
A plane figure consisting of seven sides and having sevenangles.
An alkaloid, found in the rootstock of the golden seal(Hydrastis Canadensis), and extracted as a bitter, white, crystallinesubstance. It is used as a tonic and febrifuge.
Same as Hackle.
The head. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Producing a different type of organism; developing into adifferent form of tissue, as cartilage which develops into bone.Haeckel.
Partially decked.The half-decked craft . . . used by the latter Vikings. Elton.

Boldness, united with firmness and constancy of mind; bravery;intrepidity; also, audaciousness; impudence.A bound of graceful hardihood. Wordsworth.It is the society of numbers which gives hardihood to iniquity.Buckminster.
Hardihood. [Obs.]
The dog-rose.
Growing under ground; remaining under ground; ripening itsfruit under ground. [Written also hypogæous.]

Lugged or dragged by the head. [R.] "The head-lugged bear."Shak.
= Air hole, above.

Of noble birth. Shak.

A state of exalted or morbidly increased sensibility of thebody, or of a part of it.-- Hy`per*æs*thet"ic, a.
Pertaining to, or derived from, hydrogen and sulphur; as,hydrosulphuricacid, a designation applied to the solution of hydrogensulphide in water.
Any wheel worked by hand; esp., one the rim of which serves asthe handle by which a valve, car brake, or other part is adjusted.

The act of one who, or that which, hops; a jumping, frisking,or dancing. Hopping Dick (Zoöl.), a thrush of Jamaica (Merulaleucogenys), resembling the English blackbird in its familiarmanners, agreeable song, and dark plumage.

A genus of marine univalve shells; the harp shells; -- socalled from the form of the shells, and their ornamental ribs.

An historian. [Obs.]
An order of vitreous sponges, having glassy six-rayed,siliceous spicules; -- called also Hexactinellinæ.
A Cossack headman or general. The title of chief hetman is nowheld by the heir to the throne of Russia.
The spore-bearing surface of certain fungi, as that on thegills of a mushroom.
Historical. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An officer charged with the duty of executing the regulationsrespecting the use of a harbor.
Having a valence of six; -- said of hexads.
One who, or that which, haunts.

A small, slender, branching plant (Campanula rotundifolia),having blue bell-shaped flowers; also, Scilla nutans, which hassimilar flowers; -- called also bluebell. [Written also hairbell.]E'en the light harebell raised its head. Sir W. Scott .

Between the hyoid bone and the lower jaw, pertaining to them;suprahyoid; submaxillary; as, the hyomental region of the front ofthe neck.

Having a resemblance in structure, due to descent from a commonprogenitor with subsequent modification; homogenetic; -- applied bothto animals and plants. See Homoplastic.

The floor of a furnace, on which the material to be heatedlies, or the lowest part of a melting furnace, into which the meltedmaterial settles. Hearth ends (Metal.), fragments of lead ore ejectedfrom the furnace by the blast.-- Hearth money, Hearth penny Etym: [AS. heoredhpening], a taxformerly laid in England on hearths, each hearth (in all housespaying the church and poor rates) being taxed at two shillings; --called also chimney money, etc.He had been importuned by the common people to relieve them from the. . . burden of the hearth money. Macaulay.

A European plant of the genus Cerinthe, whose flowers are veryattractive to bees. Loudon.

A chemical substance formed in one organ and carried in thecirculation to another organ on which it exerts a stimulating effect;thus, according to Starling, the gastric glands are stimulated by ahormone from the pyloric mucous membrane.

Relating to harmony, -- as melodic relates to melody;harmonious; esp., relating to the accessory sounds or overtones whichaccompany the predominant and apparent single tone of any string orsonorous body.
Clumsy; awkward.
