Same as Hematotherma.
Guidance; direction. [R.]
Belonging to the Hexactinellinæ, a group of sponges, havingsix-rayed siliceous spicules.
A woman who rides on horseback.
Formed by hydrogen and tellurium; as, hydrotelluric acid, orhydrogen telluride.
Like or pertaining to the butterflies of the genus Heliconius.
An obsolete wind instrument with a keyboard, in which thesound, which resembled the oboe, was produced by the vibration ofthin metallic plates, acted upon by blowing through a tube.
Same as Hæma-.
To cover, as a roof, with tiles, slate, lead, or the like.[Obs.]
One versed in horoscopy; an astrologer.
A screen of boards inclosing a house and materials whilebuilders are at work. [Eng.]Posted on every dead wall and hoarding. London Graphic.
A knot or noose in a rope which can be readily undone; --intended for a temporary fastening; as, a half hitch; a clove hitch;a timber hitch, etc.
Relating to hæmatogenesis.

To subject, as property, to liability for a debt or engagementwithout delivery of possession or transfer of title; to pledgewithout delivery of possession; to mortgage, as ships, or otherpersonal property; to make a contract by bottomry. See Hypothecation,Bottomry.He had found the treasury empty and the pay of the navy in arrear. Hehad no power to hypothecate any part of the public revenue. Those wholent him money lent it on no security but his bare word. Macaulay.
Fit for a garden. [Obs.] Evelyn.
The Enaliosauria.
A hammerer; a forgeman.
The act or process of heaping or drawing earth around plants.
The evening preceding Allhallows or All Saints' Day. [Scot.]Burns.
Same as Hemadrometer.
A city hall or townhouse.
Rankling in, or swelling, the heart. "Heartswelling hate."Spenser.
A measure of half a sextary. Arbuthnot.
A treatise on sleep; the doctrine of sleep.
A half. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An increase in, or excessive growth of, the normal elements ofany part.
An artificial division of insects, including all those with asucking proboscis.
A name given to several different grasses, especially to theRoltböllia incurvata, and to the species of Ægilops, from one ofwhich it is contended that wheat has been derived.
The lesser third. Busby.

A verse of six feet, the first four of which may be eitherdactyls or spondees, the fifth must regularly be a dactyl, and thesixth always a spondee. In this species of verse are composed theIliad of Homer and the Æneid of Virgil. In English hexameters accenttakes the place of quantity.Leaped like the | roe when he | hears in the | woodland the | voiceof the | huntsman. Longfellow.Strongly it | bears us a- | long on | swelling and | limitless |billows, Nothing be- | fore and | nothing be- | hind but the | skyand the | ocean. Coleridge.
The endmost plank of a strake which reaches the stem or stern.
Excessively developed; characterized by hypertrophy.
Unequal development of the tail lobes of fishes; the possessionof a heterocercal tail.
Not sensible to the bit; not easily governed; as, a hard-mouthed horse.
In an hexagonal manner.
A mineral of the Zeolite family, often occurring in amygdaloid,in foliated masses, and also in monoclinic crystals with pearlyluster on the cleavage face. It is a hydrous silicate of alumina andlime.
A board or boarding which marks or forms the head of anything;as, the headboard of a bed; the headboard of a grave.
That part of a fungus which is covered with the hymenium.
A device for raising water by the direct action of steam; apulsometer.
A maker or vender of clocks and watches; one skilled inhorology.
A hexagon. [Obs.] Bramhall.

A trussed frame extending fore and aft, usually above deck, andintended to increase the longitudinal strength and stiffness. Usedchiefly in American river and lake steamers. Called also hoggingframe, and hogback.
The Hartford grape, a variety of grape first raised atHartford, Connecticut, from the Northern fox grape. Its large dark-colored berries ripen earlier than those of most other kinds.
One of the plastids composing the idorgan of Haeckel; -- alsocalled homoörgan.
An expression of frolic and exultation, and sometimes ofwonder. B. Jonson.
Of or pertaining to divination by water.
An aquatic plant (Ceratophyllum), with finely divided leaves.
A wretch; a rascal. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A genus of Silurian fossil corals; the chain corals. See Chaincoral, under Chain.
A West Indian tree (Calliandra latifolia) with showy, crimsonblossoms.

A disappearing gun carriage in which the recoil is checked bycylinders containing liquid and air, the air when compressedfurnishing the power for restoring the gun to the firing position. Itis used with some English and European heavy guns.
A stalk of hay.
Belonging to the same category of individuality; -- amorphological term applied to organisms so related.

Any animal of the genus Hyrax, of which about four species areknown. They constitute the order Hyracoidea. The best known speciesare the daman (H. Syriacus) of Palestine, and the klipdas (H.capensis) of South Africa. Other species are H. arboreus and H.Sylvestris, the former from Southern, and the latter from Western,Africa. See Daman.
To have; have. [Obs.] Piers Plowman.Him thanken all, and thus they han an end. Chaucer.
See Haut pas.
A conical pile or hear of hay in the field.The tanned haycock in the mead. Milton.
Of or pertaining to hydrometallurgy; involving the use ofliquid reagents in the treatment or reduction of ores.-- Hy`dro*met`al*lur"gic*al*ly, adv.
To utter with hesitation or to intimate by a reluctant manner.[Poetic & R.]Just hint a fault, and hesitate dislike. Pope.
Tending to impair or damage; injurious; mischievous;occasioning loss or injury; as, hurtful words or conduct.
A wife; a helpmate.The Lord God created Adam, . . . and afterwards, on his finding thewant of a helpmeet, caused him to sleep, and took one of his ribs andthence made woman. J. H. Newman.
A salt of hyponitrous acid.
Any one of family (Uroceridæ) of large hyminopterous insects,allied to the sawflies. The larvæ bore in the wood of trees. Socalled from the long, stout ovipositors of the females.
Having a fierly spirit; hot-headed.
Abounding in hummocks.
In a hostile manner.
A form of hemoglobinometer.

An ode or song of praise or adoration; especially, a religiousode, a sacred lyric; a song of praise or thankgiving intended to beused in religious service; as, the Homeric hymns; Watts' hymns.Admonishing one another in psalms and hymns. Col. iii. 16.Where angels first should practice hymns, and string Their tunefulharps. Dryden.Hymn book, a book containing a collection of hymns, as for use inchurches; a hymnal.
That branch of meteorology which relates to, or treats of,water in the atmosphere, or its phenomena, as rain, clouds, snow,hail, storms, etc.
A cell larger than the others, and of different appearance,occurring in certain algæ related to nostoc.
Broken or strained so as to have an upward curve between theends. See Hog, v. i.
A receptacle for sacred objects.
Twin composition in crystals.
Swill. Arbuthnot.
In hieroglyphics.

An individual which has the attributes of both male and female,or which unites in itself the two sexes; an animal or plant havingthe parts of generation of both sexes, as when a flower contains boththe stamens and pistil within the same calyx, or on the samereceptacle. In some cases reproduction may take place without theunion of the distinct individuals. In the animal kingdom truehermaphrodites are found only among the invertebrates. See Illust. inAppendix, under Helminths.
See the Note under Her, pr.
The principles of the high-church party.
State of being heathen or like the heathen.
Afield adjacent to its owner's home. Hawthorne.
One who harasses.
A fossil cephalopod of the genus Hamites, related to theammonites, but having the last whorl bent into a hooklike form.
Manufactured by hand; as, handmade shoes.
The stem of an aftershaft or hypoptilum. [Written alsohyporachis.]
A liquid hydrocarbon, C7H10, of the valylene series.
Hung. Chaucer.
A genus of plants which includes the witch-hazel (HamamelisVirginica), a preparation of which is used medicinally.
Wounded to the heart with love or grief. Pope.
A covetous, sordid man; a miser; a niggard.Pray make your bargain with all the prudence and selfishness of anold hunks. Gray.
A possessor; a holder. Shak.
The rootstock or decumbent stem by which a hydroid is attachedto other objects. See Illust. under Hydroidea.
A dog of hell; an agent of hell.A hellhound, that doth hunt us all to death. Shak.
To haul; to hoist. [Obs.]

One of a series of compounds, derived from hydrogen sulphide bythe replacement of half its hydrogen by a base or basic radical; as,potassium hydrosulphide, KSH. The hydrosulphides are analogous to thehydrates and include the mercaptans.
A herbalist.
Having all the flowers alike; -- said of such composite plantsas Eupatorium, and the thistels.
Having seven seeds.
See Unciform.
An instrument for measuring the harmonic relations of sounds.It is often a monochord furnished with movable bridges.
A treatise on sacred things; especially, the science whichtreats of the ancient writings and inscriptions of the Egyptians, ora treatise on that science.
The homology of metameres. See Metamere. Gegenbaur.
Wanting food; starved. [Obs.] Shak.
A single particle of ice falling from a cloud; a frozenraindrop; a pellet of hail.
One who cultivates a garden.
The doctrine that matter possesses a species of life andsensation, or that matter and life are inseparable. [R.] Cudworth.
A loud, boisterous laugh; a guffaw. Pope.
Anatomy of the horse.
Heathendom. [Obs.] Chaucer. Sir W. Scott.
Bearing herbs or vegetation.
A body similar to, or identical with, cerebrin.
A suborder of Hemiptera, in which both pairs of wings aresimilar in texture, and do not overlap when folded, as in the cicada.See Hemiptera.
The operation or work of cutting grass and curing it for hay.

A mark or short dash, thus [-], placed at the end of a linewhich terminates with a syllable of a word, the remainder of which iscarried to the next line; or between the parts of many a compoundword; as in fine-leaved, clear-headed. It is also sometimes used toseparate the syllables of words.
Same as Acton. [Obs.]
A hydrous carbonate of magnesia occurring in white, early,amorphous masses.
Same as Hypochondriac, 2.-- Hy`po*chon"dri*a*cal*ly, adv.
Howsoever. [Obs.]
A chemical process involving the addition of the elements ofwater.
Frugal; thrifty. [R.] Tusser.
An inn of court.
A figure in which several things are mentioned that seem tomake against the argument, or in favor of the opposite side, each ofthem being refuted in order.
Divination by inspection of entrails of victims offered insacrifice.
Having but one series of stamens, and that equal in number tothe proper number of petals; isostemonous.
A woman who hunts or follows the chase; as, the huntress Diana.Shak.
Characterized by heterocarpism.
Produced by, or like, breath; vaporous. Boyle.
See Homogeny.
Without a hand. Shak.
To act; to represent on the stage, or theatrically. Urquhart.
A hood. See Houve. [Obs.]
Pertaining to the Hanse towns, or to their confederacy.Hanseatic league. See under 2d Hanse.
The act or practice of lying on the ground. [Obs.] Abp.Bramhall.
The state or quality of being heathenish. "The . . .heathenishness and profaneness of most playbooks." Prynne.
A hair of a horse, especially one from the mane or tail; thehairs of the mane or tail taken collectively; a fabric or tuft madeof such hairs. Horsehair worm (Zoöl.), the hair worm or gordius.
Of or pertaining to Hudson's Bay or to the Hudson River; as,the Hudsonian curlew.
To apply to, in conjunction with mechanical pressure, for thepurpose of giving a smooth and glosay surface, or to express oil,etc.; as, to hotpress paper, linen, etc.
In a hurrying manner.
pl. of Half. By halves, by one half at once; halfway;fragmentarily; partially; incompletely.I can not believe by halves; either I have faith, or I have it not.J. H. Newman.To go halves. See under Go.
Homogeneousness.
A combining form from Gr. "h`lios the sun.
Pertaining to the segment between the basibranchial and theceratobranchial in a branchial arch.-- n.
To divide along the mesial plane.
A cart drawn or pushed by hand.
Of or pertaining to the Hellespont. Mitford.
See Horned pout, under Horned.
The deepsea fishing for cod, ling, and tusk, off the ShetlandIsles.
Anterior in age to the lowest rocks which contain organicremains. Lyell.
Having the form, or nearly the form, of an hyperbola.
A species of fern (Lomaria borealis), growing in Europe andNorthwestern America.
of Hote.
One versed in, or whostudies, hierology.

An instrument for measuring time, especially the interval of anhour. It consists of a glass vessel having two compartments, from theuppermost of which a quantity of sand, water, or mercury occupies anhour in running through a small aperture unto the lower.
Dipped in the gall of the fabulous hydra; poisonous; deadly.Cowper.
Lying in heaps. Gay.

Pertaining to, or like, the spine of a herring; especially,characterized by an arrangement of work in rows of parallel lines,which in the alternate rows slope in different directions.Herringbone stitch, a kind of cross-stitch in needlework, chieflyused in flannel. Simmonds.

Characterized by heterology; consisting of different elements,or of like elements in different proportions; different; -- opposedto homologous; as, heterologous organs. Heterologous stimulus.(Physiol.) See under Stimulus.-- Heterologous tumor (Med.), a tumor differing in structure fromthe normal tissues of the body.
Any bird of the genus Turnix. Various species inhabit Asia,Africa, and Australia.

That heats or imparts heat; promoting warmth or heat; excitingaction; stimulating; as, heating medicines or applications. Heatingsurface (Steam Boilers), the aggregate surface exposed to fire or tothe heated products of combustion, esp. of all the plates or sheetsthat are exposed to water on their opposite surfaces; -- called alsofire surface.
Pertaining to homicide; tending to homicide; murderous.
A metrical line of eleven syllables. J. Warton.

Pertaining to, or proceeding from, the humors; as, a humoralfever. Humoral pathology (Med.), the pathology, or doctrine of thenature of diseases, which attributes all morbid phenomena to thedisordered condition of the fluids or humors of the body.
Hand. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A compound radical, or unsaturated group, HO, consisting of oneatom of hydrogen and one of oxygen. It is a characteristic part ofthe hydrates, the alcohols, the oxygen acids, etc.
One who favors the humoral pathology or believes in humoralism.
Any species of property that may be inherited; lands,tenements, anything corporeal or incorporeal, real, personal, ormixed, that may descend to an heir. Blackstone.
A process, or other element, of a vertebra developed from theventral side of the centrum, as hæmal spines, and chevron bones.-- Hy`pa*po*phys"i*al, a.
A cotquean; a man who intermeddles with women's concerns.
A discourse on history. Cockeram.
A median process on the furculum, or merrythought, of manybirds, where it is connected with the sternum.

The official stamp of the Goldsmiths' Company and other assayoffices, in the United Kingdom, on gold and silver articles,attesting their purity. Also used figuratively; -- as, a word orphrase lacks the hall-mark of the best writers.
A fee for keeping goods in a house. [R.] Chambers.
A slender bony or cartilaginous process developed from the heelbone of bats. It helps to support the wing membranes. See Illust. ofCheiropter.
To hydrogenize.
A port or small haven; -- used in composition; as, Lambhithe,now Lambeth. Pennant.
The pilgrimage to Mecca, performed by Mohammedans.
One who attributes diseases of the state of the humors.

A slender outgrowth from the chitinous cuticle of insects,spiders, crustaceans, and other invertebrates. Such hairs are totallyunlike those of vertebrates in structure, composition, and mode ofgrowth.
Of or pertaining to herbs. Quarles.
An abbreviation of hypochonaria; -- usually in plural.[Colloq.]Heaven send thou hast not got the hyps. Swift.

A disease resembling hysteria in its nature, and characterizedby the occurrence of epileptiform convulsions, which can often becontrolled or excited by pressure on the ovaries, and upon otherdefinite points in the body.-- Hys`ter*o*ep`i*lep"tic, a.
Relating to, or obtained by, heliotypy.
A harpsichord. [Obs.]
Firmly twisted in spinning.
The medical philosophy or system of Hippocrates.
A compound of hydrochloric acid with a base; -- distinguishedfrom a chloride, where only chlorine unites with the base.
A series of six numbers.
A small coaster vessel, usually sloop-rigged, used in conveyingpassengers and goods from place to place, or as a tender to largervessels in port.The hoy went to London every week. Cowper.

Pertaining to the Hellenists. Hellenistic language, dialect, oridiom, the Greek spoken or used by the Jews who lived in countrieswhere the Greek language prevailed; the Jewish-Greek dialect or idiomof the Septuagint.
An appliance for the destruction of insects, consisting of ashallow iron box, containing kerosene or coated with tar or othersticky substance, which may be mounted on wheels.
Of the nature of a halogen.
See under Hunt. [Obs.] Chaucer.
See Hockey.

A New Zealand lizard, which, in anatomical character, differswidely from all other existing lizards. It is the only livingrepresentative of the order Rhynchocephala, of which many Mesozoicfossil species are known; -- called also Sphenodon, and Tuatera.
To hasten; to go in haste; -- also often with the reciprocalpronoun. [Rare, except in poetry] "My husband hies him home." Shak.The youth, returning to his mistress, hies. Dryden.

A member or follower of the "liberal" party, headed by EliasHicks, which, because of a change of views respecting the divinity ofChrist and the Atonement, seceded from the conservative portion ofthe Society of Friends in the United States, in 1827.
The unconscious saying, in speech or in writing, of that whichone does not intend to say; -- frequently the very reverse of thethought which is present to consciousness. R. G. White.
A species of Althæa (A. rosea), bearing flowers of variouscolors; -- called also rose mallow.
A frightful goblin; an imp; a bugaboo; also, a name formerlygiven to the household spirit, Robin Goodfellow. Macaulay.
The hollow stem of a hydroid, either simple or branched. SeeIllust. of Gymnoblastea and Hydroidea.
One who hoards.
A binary compound of hydrogen; a hydride. [Obs.]
Having six leaves or leaflets.
Same as Heartseed.
A genus of American shrubs containing several species, calledsnowdrop trees, or silver-bell trees. They have showy, white flowers,drooping on slender pedicels.
A large conical brick structure around which the firing kilnsare grouped. Knight.
One who is critical beyond measure or reason; a carping critic;a captious censor. "Hypercritics in English poetry." Dryden.

Formed or crystallized at depths the earth's surface; -- saidof granite, gneiss, and other rocks, whose crystallization isbelieved of have taken place beneath a great thickness of overlyingrocks. Opposed to epigene.

A large, amphibious, herbivorous mammal (Hippopotamusamphibius), common in the rivers of Africa. It is allied to the hogs,and has a very thick, naked skin, a thick and square head, a verylarge muzzle, small eyes and ears, thick and heavy body, and shortlegs. It is supposed to be the behemoth of the Bible. Called alsozeekoe, and river horse. A smaller species (H. Liberiencis) inhabitsWestern Africa.
A follower of Heracleon of Alexandria, a Judaizing Gnostic, inthe early history of the Christian church.
To hasten; to hurry. [Archaic]I 'll haste the writer. Shak.They were troubled and hasted away. Ps. xlviii. 5.
See Hawser. Pope.
Same as Hemastatics.
A plant, like the fungus, which lives on dead or living organicmatter.-- Hys`ter*oph"y*tal, a.
A climbing plant (Humulus Lupulus), having a long, twining,annual stalk. It is cultivated for its fruit (hops).

An exclamation denoting surprise, joy, or grief. Both asuttered and as written, it expresses a great variety of emotions,determined by the tone or the context. When repeated, ha, ha, it isan expression of laughter, satisfaction, or triumph, sometimes ofderisive laughter; or sometimes it is equivalent to "Well, it is so."Ha-has, and inarticulate hootings of satirical rebuke. Carlyle.

Resembling salt; -- said of certain binary compounds consistingof a metal united to a negative element or radical, and now chieflyapplied to the chlorides, bromides, iodides, and sometimes also tothe fluorides and cyanides.-- n.
Hypochondriasis; melancholy; the blues.
The production of artificial membranes by contact of twofluids, as albumin and fat, by which the globules of the latter aresurrounded by a thin film of the former.
Having the surface roughly shaped or faced with thestonecutter's hammer; -- said of building stone.
A theory which regards matter as the original principle ofevil.
, Pertaining to the hagiographa, or to sacred writings.
In a hospitable manner.
A vomiting of blood.
A little case or bag for materials used in sewing, and forother articles of female work; -- called also hussy. [Written alsohuswife.] P. Skelton.
A thin, pointed nail, with a heavy flaring head, for securing ahorsehoe to the hoof; a horsehoe nail.
The brains. [Scot.]

To raise; to lift; to elevate; esp., to raise or lift to adesired elevation, by means of tackle, as a sail, a flag, a heavypackage or weight.They land my goods, and hoist my flying sails. Pope.Hoisting him into his father's throne. South.Hoisting engine, a steam engine for operating a hoist.
A peculiar starchy matter contained in barley. It is complexmixture. [R.]
An inhabitant of highlands, especially of the Highlands ofScotland.
See Usher. B. Jonson.
Tiles laid at the eaves of a house. Knight.

A plant of the genus Nasturtium (N. Armoracia), allied toscurvy grass, having a root of a pungent taste, much used, whengrated, as a condiment and in medicine. Gray. Horse-radish tree.(Bot.) See Moringa.
Doomed to hell. Milton.
One who hires.
Showing only part of the face; wretched looking; meager. Shak.
See Ivorytype.
The essential radical, C16H33, of hecdecane.
An extensive order of insects, including the bees, ants,ichneumons, sawflies, etc.
A collection of serous fluid in the areolar texture of thescrotum or in the coverings, especially in the serous sac, investingthe testicle or the spermatic cord; dropsy of the testicle.
One of the grand divisions or branches of the animal kingdom.It is a large group including a vast number of species, most of whichare parasitic. Called also Enthelminthes, Enthelmintha.

A division of Hydroidea, including those genera that secrete astony coral, as Millepora and Stylaster. Two forms of zooids in lifeproject from small pores in the coral and resemble those of otherhydroids. See Millepora.
An inn; a lodging house. [Archaic] Chaucer. "Homely brought upin a rude hostelry." B. Jonson.Come with me to the hostelry. Longfellow.
One versed in the Hebrew language and learning.
An albuminous substance formed in gastric digestion, and by theaction of boiling dilute acids on albumin. It is readily convertibleinto hemipeptone. Called also hemialbumin.
A stag; the male of the red deer. See the Note under Buck.Goodliest of all the forest, hart and hind. Milton.
See Army organization, above.
With the head foremost.
Having the thoughts and affections placed on, or suitable for,heaven and heavenly objects; devout; godly; pious. Milner.-- Heav"en*ly*mind`ed*ness, n.

A harp-shaped instrument of music set horizontally on legs,like the grand piano, with strings of wire, played by the fingers, bymeans of keys provided with quills, instead of hammers, for strikingthe strings. It is now superseded by the piano.
Same as Ha.
The character or personality of a hero. "Three years ofheroship." Cowper.
The art of preaching; that branch of theology which treats ofhomilies or sermons, and the best method of preparing and deliveringthem.
Unto this; up to this time; hereto.
The apart or practice of measuring the diameters of heavenlybodies, their relative distances, etc. See Heliometer.
Same as Holometabolic.
The act of hybridizing, or the state of being hybridized.
As tight as can be made by the hand. Totten.
Exposed to hazard; dangerous; risky.To enterprise so hazardous and high! Milton.
In India, a running footman; a messenger. [Written alsohurkaroo.]
A product of the gastric and pancreatic digestion of albuminousmatter.
In hurry and confusion; without definite purpose; irregularly.[Colloq.]Helter-skelter have I rode to thee. Shak.A wistaria vine running helter-skelter across the roof. J. C. Harris.

A large estate where work of any kind is done, as agriculture,manufacturing, mining, or raising of animals; a cultivated farm, witha good house, in distinction from a farming establishment with rudehuts for herdsmen, etc.; -- a word used in Spanish-American regions.1.
A mountain in Boeotia, in Greece, supposed by the Greeks to bethe residence of Apollo and the Muses.From Helicon's harmonious springs A thousand rills their mazyprogress take. Gray.
hypocraterimorphous; salver-shaped. Wood.
The chipmunk; also, the chickaree or red squirrel. [U.S.]
An instrument which shows whether there is more or lessmoisture in the atmosphere, without indicating its amount.
Hippophagy. Lowell.

A thorny shrub or tree (the Cratægus oxyacantha), having deeplylobed, shining leaves, small, roselike, fragrant flowers, and a fruitcalled haw. It is much used in Europe for hedges, and for standardsin gardens. The American hawthorn is Cratægus cordata, which has theleaves but little lobed.Gives not the hawthorn bush a sweeter shade To shepherds Shak.
A butterfly of the genus Thecla; as, the green hairstreak (T.rubi).
A genus of plants, some species of which are cultivated fortheir beautiful flowers; day lily.
Hard-featured; ill-looking; as, Vulcan was hard-favored.Dryden.
Be it as it may; nevertheless; notwithstanding; although;albeit; yet; but; however.The Moor -- howbeit that I endure him not -Is of a constant, loving,noble nature. Shak.
An accessory plume arising from the posterior side of the stemof the contour feathers of many birds; -- called also aftershaft. SeeIllust. of Feather.
Ho there; stop; attend; hence, a loud cry or a call to attractattention; a halloo.And every day, for food or play, Came to the mariner's hollo.Coleridge.
A yearling; a bird of the year.
Of or pertaining to heralds or heraldry; as, heraldicblazoning; heraldic language. T. Warton.
One who, or that which, blows a horn.
Wearing a helmet; furnished with or having a helmet or helmet-shaped part; galeate.
An instrument for registering the velocity of the blood.
Abounding with husks; consisting of husks. Dryden.
The female of the red deer, of which the male is the stag.

A coat of mail; especially, the long coat of mail of theEuropean Middle Ages, as contrasted with the habergeon, which isshorter and sometimes sleeveless. By old writers it is often usedsynonymously with habergeon. See Habergeon. [Written variouslyhauberg, hauberque, hawberk, etc.] Chaucer.Helm, nor hawberk's twisted mail. Gray.

Pertaining to, or containing, phosphorus in a lower state ofoxidation than in phosphoric compounds; as, hypophosphorous acid.Hypophosphorous acid (Chem.) , an acid, H3PO2, whose salts areproduced by the action of barium hygrate on phosphorus. It may beobtained from its water solution, by exaporation and freezing, as awhite crystalline substance. It is a powerful reducing agent.
Relating to what is now called the Plutonic theory of theearth, first advanced by Dr. James Hutton. Lyell.
Unyielding; insensible to argument; uncompromising; strict.[Collog., U.S.]
Capable of being handled.
A breaking up of the blood corpuscles, as by pressure, indistinction from solution of the corpuscles, or hæmcytolysis.
A yarn measure of six hundred yards or of a spindle. SeeSpindle.
The science which treats of the blood.
A remarkable South American bird (Opisthocomus cristatus); thecrested touraco. By some zoölogists it is made the type of a distinctorder (Opisthocomi).
The Hydroidea.
The state or quality of being heavy in its various senses;weight; sadness; sluggishness; oppression; thickness.
One who writes in hexameters. "The Christian hexametrists."Milman.

The cross as the symbol of Christ's crucifixion. Congregationof the Holy Cross (R. C. Ch.), a community of lay brothers andpriests, in France and the United States, engaged chiefly in teachingand manual Labor. Originally called Brethren of St. Joseph. TheSisters of the Holy Cross engage in similar work. Addis & Arnold.-- Holy-cross day, the fourteenth of September, observed as a churchfestival, in memory of the exaltation of our Savior's cross.
An unexplained epithet used by Chaucer in reference to ships.By some it is defined as "dancing (on the wave)"; by others as"opposing," "warlike." T. R. Lounsbury.
Higher than, or beyond the sphere of, the organic. Sir W.Hamilton.
A handicraftsman.
One who puts rings into the snouts of hogs.
Same as Hematoidin.
Of or pertaining to the Heteropoda.
A lamp with lenses or reflectors to collect the rays of lightand throw them in a given direction; -- used in lighthouses.
The branch of science which relates to the pressure andequilibrium of nonelastic fluids, as water, mercury, etc.; theprinciples of statics applied to water and other liquids.
To assail with contemptuous cries or shouts; to follow withderisive shouts.Partridge and his clan may hoot me for a cheat. Swift.
A professional tramp; one who spends his life traveling fromplace to place, esp. by stealing rides on trains, and begging for aliving. [U. S.] -- Ho"bo*ism (#), n.
Having spirals of changing direction. Gray.
That portion of the soil formed by the decomposition of animalor vegetable matter. It is a valuable constituent of soils. Graham.

One of the Moravians; -- so called from the settlement ofHerrnhut (the Lord's watch) made, about 1722, by the Moravians at theinvitation of Nicholas Lewis, count of Zinzendorf, upon his estate inthe circle of Bautzen.
Bloodforming; as, the hæmapoietic function of the spleen.
Hoar. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A division of Lepidoptera, including the moths, and hawk moths,which have the antennæ variable in form.
To stand, depend, hang, or turn, as on a hinge; to dependchiefly for a result or decision or for force and validity; --usually with on or upon; as, the argument hinges on this point. I.Taylor
Whole. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Holly, an evergreen shrub or tree.
A variant of Height.
An alkaloid associated with cocaine in coca leaves(Erythroxylon coca), and extracted as a thick, yellow oil, having apungent taste and odor.
To harlot. [Obs.] Warner.
The lower part of the abdomen.
A fetter for horses, or cattle, when turned out to graze; --chiefly used in the plural.
Sheltered in a haven.Blissful havened both from joy and pain. Keats.

Any one of a series of nitrogenous bases, resembling the aminesand produced by the reduction of certain nitroso and diazo compounds;as, methyl hydrazine, phenyl hydrazine, etc. They are derivatives ofhydrazine proper, H2N.NH2, which is a doubled amido group, recently(1887) isolated as a stable, colorless gas, with a peculiar,irritating odor. As a base it forms distinct salts. Called alsodiamide, amidogen, (or more properly diamidogen), etc.
A builder of houses.
Having haunches.
Hair. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Subject to the payment of a heriot. Burn.
Leadership; preponderant influence or authority; -- usuallyapplied to the relation of a government or state to its neighbors orconfederates. Lieber.
Toward this place; hither.Marching hitherward in proud array. Shak.
A hero, fabled to have been the son of Jupiter and Alcmena, andcelebrated for great strength, esp. for the accomplishment of histwelve great tasks or "labors."
The long jump, with weights in the hands, -- the most importantof the exercises of the Pentathlon.
Destitute of the shelter of a house; shelterless; homeless; as,a houseless wanderer.
The formation of homologous tissues.
A hydro-aëroplane having two supporting planes.
See Homelyn.
A mixture of two malt liquors, esp. porter and ale, in aboutequal parts. Dickens.
Same as Hæmatoblast.
Rays (chiefly cathode rays) developed by the electric dischargein Hittorf tubes.
A kite of infernal breed. Shak.
Of or pertaining to health or hygiene; sanitary.
Act of hauling; as, the haulage of cars by an engine; chargefor hauling.
A little man; a dwarf; a manikin. Sterne.
The mallow.
A compound of hydrocyanic acid with a base; -- distinguishedfrom a cyanide, in which only the cyanogen so combines.
The quality of being highminded; nobleness; magnanimity.
That branch of physics which treats of the mechanics ofliquids, or of their laws of equilibrium and of motion.
Driven to the end, as a nail; driven close.
Belonging to a garden. [Obs.] Evelyn.
Of a clear tint of brown, resembling brown human hair. It iscomposed of equal proportions of red and green.
A beam or bar armed with iron spikes, and turning on a pivot; -- used to block up a passage.
A genus of decapod Crustacea, including the common lobsters.-- Hom"a*roid, a.
Discovered or described by John Hunter, an English surgeon; as,the Hunterian chancre. See Chancre.
Without a hinge or joint.
One of the Hemiptera; an hemipter.
Of or pertaining to a holethnos or parent race.The holethnic history of the Arians. London Academy.
A rash, hot-headed man. Holinshed.
Manifesting homoeomorphism.
In a heliacal manner. De Quincey.
A gaseous element found in the atmospheres of the sun and earthand in some rare minerals.
Same as Hamele.
A liquid hydrocarbon, C6H8, of the valylene series, obtainedfrom distillation products of certain fats and gums.
Any discharge of blood from the blood vessels.
Produced in hell. Spenser.

A part (usually separate from the bed or frame) for supportingsome of the principal working parts of a machine; as:(a) The part of a lathe that holds the revolving spindle and itsattachments; -- also called poppet head, the opposite correspondingpart being called a tailstock.(b) The part of a planing machine that supports the cutter, etc.
A coop or cage for hens.
Hematin. [R.]

Small roundish masses of ice precipitated from the clouds,where they are formed by the congelation of vapor. The separatemasses or grains are called hailstones.Thunder mixed with hail, Hail mixed with fire, must rend the Egyptiansky. Milton.
A garden of herbs; a cottage garden. T. Warton.

Very large; enormous; immense; excessive; -- used esp. ofmaterial bulk, but often of qualities, extent, etc.; as, a huge ox; ahuge space; a huge difference. "The huge confusion." Chapman. "A hugefilly." Jer. Taylor.-- Huge"ly, adv.-- Huge"ness, n.Doth it not flow as hugely as the sea. Shak.
Herring-shaped.

Liver of sulphur; a substance of a liver-brown color, sometimesused in medicine. It is formed by fusing sulphur with carbonates ofthe alkalies (esp. potassium), and consists essentially of alkalinesulphides. Called also hepar sulphuris (.

A quadruped of the genus Sus, and allied genera of Suidæ; esp.,the domesticated varieties of S. scrofa, kept for their fat and meat,called, respectively, lard and pork; swine; porker; specifically, acastrated boar; a barrow.
Hooked; bent at the end into a hook; hamous.
With a limping step.
A female hermit. Coleridge.
The quality or state of being hasty; haste; precipitation;rashness; quickness of temper.
With this.
Coarseness of features.
Endearing; diminutive; as, the hypocoristic form of a name.The hypocoristic or pet form of William. Dr. Murray.
See Haslet.
The state of being health
See Jeniquen.

A membranous sac or bladder filled with a pellucid fluid, foundin various parts of the bodies of animals, but unconnected with thetissues. It is usually formed by parasitic worms, esp. by larvaltapeworms, as Echinococcus and Coenurus. See these words in theVocabulary. Hydatid of Morgagni (Anat.), one of the smallpedunculated bodies found between the testicle and the head of theepididymis, and supposed to be a remnant of the Müllerian duct.
Excessive dicrotic; as, a hyperdicrotic pulse.
A tax formerly paid to the kings of England for every hide ofland. [Written also hydage.]
A vitiated condition of the body, due to long confinement in ahospital, or the morbid condition of the atmosphere of a hospital.
Pertaining or tending to a flux o
On or upon this; hereupon.
Full of courage or nobleness; high-souled.-- High"-heart`ed*ness, n.
The science which treats of the fluids of the body.

Differing in kind; having unlike qualities; possessed ofdifferent characteristics; dissimilar; -- opposed to homogeneous, andsaid of two or more connected objects, or of a conglomerate mass,considered in respect to the parts of which it is made up.-- Het`er*o*ge"ne*ous*ly, adv.-- Het`er*o*ge"ne*ous*ness, n. Heterogeneous nouns (Gram.), nounshaving different genders in the singular and plural numbers; as, hiclocus, of the masculine gender in the singular, and hi loci and hæcloca, both masculine and neuter in the plural; hoc cælum, neuter inthe singular; hi cæli, masculine in the plural.-- Heterogeneous quantities (Math.), such quantities as areincapable of being compared together in respect to magnitude, andsurfaces and solids.-- Heterogeneous surds (Math.), surds having different radicalsigns.
See Hæmatoin.
To hedge, cover, make, or inclose with hurdles. Milton.
The dissection of organic tissues.
In a hypostatic manner.
An opinion opposed to some accepted standard. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
A genus of pretty spring flowers closely related to Anemone;squirrel cup.
Same as Haft, n. [Obs.] Waller.
A grass with very slender leaves or branches; as the Agrostisscabra, and several species of Aira or Deschampsia.
An instrument for measuring the forms and angles of salts andcrystals; a goniometer.
Relating to a horologe, or to horology.
The sulphate of iodoquinine, a substance crystallizing in thinplates remarkable for their effects in polarizing light.
Heterogenesis.
The mode of using the pencil or brush, etc.; style of touch.Fairholt.
Has. [Archaic.]
Careful; wary. [Obs.] Stapleton.
One who deals in hose or stocking, or in goods knit or wovenlike hose.
The part of a mast below the hounds and above the deck.
Neat; fit; comfortable. [Obs.]
The name given by Europeans to that form of the Hindustanilanguage which is chiefly spoken by native Hindoos. In employs theDevanagari character, in which Sanskrit is written. Whitworth.

A relation between two figures, such that to any point of theone corresponds one and but one point in the other, and vise versa.Thus, a tangent line rolling on a circle cuts two fixed tangents ofthe circle in two sets of points that are homographic.
One who, or that which, hulls; especially, an agriculturalmachine for removing the hulls from grain; a hulling machine.
One who huddles things together.
To make an inarticulate sound, like h'm, through the nose inthe process of speaking, from embarrassment or a affectation; to hem.
Same as Hyperæsthesia.

A protrusion, consisting of an organ or part which has escapedfrom its natural cavity, and projects through some natural oraccidental opening in the walls of the latter; as, hernia of thebrain, of the lung, or of the bowels. Hernia of the abdominal viscerain most common. Called also rupture. Strangulated hernia, a hernia sotightly compressed in some part of the channel through which it hasbeen protruded as to arrest its circulation, and produce swelling ofthe protruded part. It may occur in recent or chronic hernia, but ismore common in the latter.
To remove from the board (the piece which could have capturedan opposing piece). See Huff, v. i., 3.
A judge or umpire in games or combats.

A substance, in the form of reddish brown, microscopic,prismatic crystals, formed from dried blood by the action of strongacetic acid and common salt; -- called also Teichmann's crystals.Chemically, it is a hydrochloride of hematin.
Good for the heart. [Obs.]
A blow with the hand.

The act or contract by which property is hypothecated; a rightwhich a creditor has in or to the property of his debtor, in virtueof which he may cause it to be sold and the price appropriated inpayment of his debt. This is a right in the thing, or jus in re.Pothier. B. R. Curtis.There are but few cases, if any, in our law, where an hypothecation,in the strict sense of the Roman law, exists; that is a pledgewithout possession by the pledgee. Story.
Merry; cheerful; lively. [Scot.]
Any member of a group of sugars containing six carbon atoms inthe molecule. Some are widely distributed in nature, esp. in ripefruits.
A near similarity of crystalline forms between unlike chemicalcompounds. See Isomorphism.
One of the Heteropoda.-- a.
A leafless plant, with hollow and rushlike stems. It is of thegenus Equisetum, and is allied to the ferns. See Illust. ofEquisetum.

A poisonous glucoside found in several species of hellebore,and extracted as a white crystalline substance with a sharp tinglingtaste. It possesses the essential virtues of the plant; -- calledalso elleborin.

A gaseous element, colorless, tasteless, and odorless, thelightest known substance, being fourteen and a half times lighterthan air (hence its use in filling balloons), and over eleventhousand times lighter than water. It is very abundant, being aningredient of water and of many other substances, especially those ofanimal or vegetable origin. It may by produced in many ways, but ischiefly obtained by the action of acids (as sulphuric) on metals, aszinc, iron, etc. It is very inflammable, and is an ingredient of coalgas and water gas. It is standard of chemical equivalents orcombining weights, and also of valence, being the typical monad.Symbol H. Atomic weight 1.
A narrow strait between Europe and Asia, now called theDaradanelles. It connects the Ægean Sea and the sea of Marmora.

The home and appurtenant land and buildings owned by the headof a family, and occupied by him and his family. Homestead law. (a) Alaw conferring special privileges or exemptions upon owners ofhomesteads; esp., a law exempting a homestead from attachment or saleunder execution for general debts. Such laws, with limitations as tothe extent or value of the property, exist in most of the States.Called also homestead exemption law. (b) Also, a designation of anAct of Congress authorizing and regulating the sale of public lands,in parcels of 160 acres each, to actual settlers. [U.S.]
Hircic acid. See Hircic. [R.]
One liable to the fault of heterophemy.
Formerly, a mercenary foot soldier in Hungary, now, ahalberdier of a Hungarian noble, or an attendant in German orHungarian courts. [Written also hayduck, heiduc, heiduck, andheyduk.]
Most advanced; most forward; as, the headmost ship in a fleet.
A white, crystalline benzene derivative, C8H10O2, obtained bythe reduction of phlorone.

An instrument for measuring heights by observation ofbarometric pressure; esp., one for determining heights byascertaining the boiling point of water. It consists of a vessel forwater, with a lamp for heating it, and an inclosed thermometer forshowing the temperature of ebullition.
Same as Dugong.
Pertaining to the blood or blood vessels; also, ventral. SeeHemal.
The first seven books of the Testament.
A name given by soldiers and sailors to a kind of hard biscuitor sea bread.
See Haik, and Huke.
A small herb. Shak.

That method of reproduction in which the successive generationsare alike, the offspring, either animal or plant, running through thesame cycle of existence as the parent; gamogenesis; -- opposed toheterogenesis.
Of or pertaining to herbs; having the nature, texture, orcharacteristics, of an herb; as, herbaceous plants; an herbaceousstem.
A perchlorate. [Obs.]
The Helots, collectively; slaves; bondsmen. "The Helotry ofMammon." Macaulay.
Somewhat hard.
A dark brown powder containing iron, prepared by the action ofzinc dust as a reducing agent upon the coloring matter of the blood,used medicinally as a hematinic.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Hold, contr. from holdeth. [Obs.]Chaucer.
A prefix or combining form, used to denote six, sixth, etc.;as, hexatomic, hexabasic.
Highest. [Obs.] Shak.
An iron alum occurring in silky fibrous aggregates of ayellowish white color.

A buffoon, dressed in party-colored clothes, who plays tricks,often without speaking, to divert the bystanders or an audience; amerry-andrew; originally, a droll rogue of Italian comedy. PercySmith.As dumb harlequin is exhibited in our theaters. Johnson.Harlequin bat (Zoöl.), an Indian bat (Scotophilus ornatus), curiouslyvariegated with white spots.-- Harlequin beetle (Zoöl.), a very large South American beetle(Acrocinus longimanus) having very long legs and antennæ. The elytraare curiously marked with red, black, and gray.-- Harlequin cabbage bug. (Zoöl.) See Calicoback.-- Harlequin caterpillar. (Zoöl.), the larva of an American bombycidmoth (Euchætes egle) which is covered with black, white, yellow, andorange tufts of hair.-- Harlequin duck (Zoöl.), a North American duck (Histrionicushistrionicus). The male is dark ash, curiously streaked with white.-- Harlequin moth. (Zoöl.) See Magpie Moth.-- Harlequin opal. See Opal.-- Harlequin snake (Zoöl.), a small, poisonous snake (Elapsfulvius), ringed with red and black, found in the Southern UnitedStates.
The office, dignity, or position of a high priest.
An herb. [Obs.] Spenser.
Without harvest; lacking in crops; barren. "Harvestlessautumns." Tennyson.
Downward convexity, or convexity of the inferior surface.
An administrative subdivision of a fu, or department, or of anindependent chow; also, the seat of government of such a district.
A wandering troop or gang; especially, a clan or tribe of anomadic people migrating from place to place for the sake ofpasturage, plunder, etc.; a predatory multitude. Thomson.
See Allelomorph.
Full of hooks; pertaining to hooks.
Having six capsules or seed vessels.
An exclamation of surprise, joy, dejection, uneasiness,weariness, etc. Shak.
Iowa; -- a nickname of obscure origin.
An order of Anthozoa; the Actinaria.
Honesty; honorableness. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who collects bees into a hive.
Warm-blooded; homoiothermal.
Balancers; the rudimentary hind wings of Diptera.
To cry out; to whoop. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The quality of being haughty; disdain; arrogance.
Turning or bending towards moisture, as roots.
One who sells wares by crying them in the street; hence, apeddler or a packman.
Undergoing complete segmentation; composed entirely of germinalmatter, the whole of the yolk undergoing fission; -- opposed tomeroblastic.
All the zooids of a hydroid colony collectively, including thenutritive and reproductive zooids, and often other kinds.
Proceeding from, or indicating, a quick temper.Take no unkindness of his hasty words. Shak
Of or pertaining to the liver and kidneys; as, the hepatorenalligament.
Same as Hypotenuse.
Heterogenous. [Obs.]
Pertaining to, or suggestive of, a horse, or of horse racing;as, horsy manners; garments of fantastically horsy fashions.[Colloq.]
Work after manner of a hurdle.
A consecrateo place; esp., a temple.
One of the Holostomata.
A conical or branching body, by which a seaweed is attached toits support, and differing from a root in that it is not speciallyabsorbent of moisture.

That part of a gunlock which strikes the percussion cap, orfiring pin; the cock; formerly, however, a piece of steel coveringthe pan of a flintlock musket and struck by the flint of the cock toignite the priming.(e) Also, a person of thing that smites or shatters; as, St.Augustine was the hammer of heresies.He met the stern legionaries [of Rome] who had been the "massive ironhammers" of the whole earth. J. H. Newman.Atmospheric hammer, a dead-stroke hammer in which the spring isformed by confined air.-- Drop hammer, Face hammer, etc. See under Drop, Face, etc.-- Hammer fish. See Hammerhead.-- Hammer hardening, the process of hardening metal by hammering itwhen cold.-- Hammer shell (Zoöl.), any species of Malleus, a genus of marinebivalve shells, allied to the pearl oysters, having the wings narrowand elongated, so as to give them a hammer-shaped outline; -- calledalso hammer oyster.-- To bring to the hammer, to put up at auction.
A small eminence of a conical form, of land or of ice; a knoll;a hillock. See Hummock. Bartram.

the eighth letter of the English alphabet, is classed among theconsonants, and is formed with the mouth organs in the same positionas that of the succeeding vowel. It is used with certain consonantsto form digraphs representing sounds which are not found in thealphabet, as sh, th, th, as in shall, thing, thine (for zh see §274);also, to modify the sounds of some other letters, as when placedafter c and p, with the former of which it represents a compoundsound like that of tsh, as in charm (written also tch as in catch),with the latter, the sound of f, as in phase, phantom. In some words,mostly derived or introduced from foreign languages, h following cand g indicates that those consonants have the hard sound before e,i, and y, as in chemistry, chiromancy, chyle, Ghent, Ghibelline,etc.; in some others, ch has the sound of sh, as in chicane. SeeGuide to Pronunciation, §§ 153, 179, 181-3, 237-8.
Easily managed; obedient to the helm; -- said of a vessel.
See Race, a water course.
Criticism which includes the study of the contents, literarycharacter, date, authorship, etc., of any writing; as, the highercriticism of the Pentateuch. Called also historical criticism.
Pertaining to, or derived from, vegetable mold; as, humic acid.See Humin.
A heddle. Ure.
See Homologue.
A hook, or hooklike process.
A garden; a pleasure garden. [Obs.] "Into an herber green."Chaucer.
A moistening. [Obs.] Bacon.
One of the Heteroptera.
An outwork composed of two demibastions joined by a curtain. Itis connected with the works in rear by long wings.
To clothe; to wrap.The surgeon happed her up carefully. Dr. J. Brown.
To approve; to allow; to confirm; as, the court homologates aproceeding. Wheaton.
The coltsfoot.
Informed by insufficient reading; superficial; shallow. Dryden.
A hyacinth. [Obs.] Spenser.
A player on the hautboy.
Of a harsh or stern countenance; hard-featured. Burke.
Having different essential qualities; of a different nature.

A New Zealand starling (Heteralocha acutirostris), remarkablefor the great difference in the form and length of the bill in thetwo sexes, that of the male being sharp and straight, that of thefemale much longer and strongly curved.
Quality of being humorsome.
A plant (Hyssopus officinalis). The leaves have an aromaticsmell, and a warm, pungent taste.
A follower of John Huss, the Bohemian reformer, who wasadjudged a heretic and burnt alive in 1415.
A carriage hung on poles, and borne by and between two horses.Milton.
A large ship of burden, in ancient Greece. Mitford.
Same as Homomorphy.

A musical instrument, resembling a small organ and especiallydesigned for church music, in which the tones are produced by forcingair by means of a bellows so as to cause the vibration of freemetallic reeds. It is now made with one or two keyboards, and haspedals and stops.
Boisterous mirth; merriment; jollity. Goldsmith.
A division of ciliated Infusoria, having fine cilia all overthe body, and a circle of larger ones around the anterior end.
A digestive gland in Crustacea, Mollusca, etc., usually calledthe liver, but different from the liver of vertebrates.
To this; hereunto. Hooker.
A hautboy or oboe. [Obs.]
The European sand ray (Raia maculata); -- called also home,mirror ray, and rough ray.
A pond for watering horses.
The business of making hats; also, stuff for hats.
A document, as a letter, deed, or will, wholly in thehandwriting of the person from whom it proceeds and whose act itpurports to be.
One who harnesses.
To hearten; to encourage; to incite. [Obs.] Spenser.
Hypermetropia.-- Hy`per*op"tic, a.

A female servant employed to do housework, esp. to take care ofthe rooms. Housemaid's knee (Med.), a swelling over the knee, due toan enlargement of the bursa in the front of the kneepan; -- so calledbecause frequently occurring in servant girls who work upon theirknees.
Leading to sleep; -- applied to the illusions of one who ishalf asleep.
A salt of hypophosphorous acid.
A genus of rodents, including the porcupine.
To draw; to drag; to carry off by vio [Obs.] Chaucer.
False optics. Spectator.
One who habitually frequents a place; as, an habitué of atheater.
One who shoes horses.
The hypochondriac regions. See Hypochondrium.

Formerly, a payment or tribute of arms or militaryaccouterments, or the best beast, or chattel, due to the lord on thedeath of a tenant; in modern use, a customary tribute of goods orchattels to the lord of the fee, paid on the decease of a tenant.Blackstone. Bouvier. Heriot custom, a heriot depending on usage.-- Heriot service (Law), a heriot due by reservation in a grant orlease of lands. Spelman. Blackstone.
See Hematoidin.
A piece of woodland; a small wood. [Obs.] See Holt.
Sorrow; anguish of mind; mental pang. Shak.
An instrument for exhibition or illustration of the phenomenaof halos, parhelia, and the like.
One who writes about or describes the sea.
Hermaphrodism. B. Jonson.
Moderately heavy. [Colloq. U. S.]
See Haytian.
A vivid, picturesque description of scenes or events.
Giving exhortation; advisory; exhortative. Bullokar.
To laugh boisterously. [Colloq. U. S.]We haw-haw'd, I tell you, for more than half an hour. Major JackDowning.
A young salmon; a parr.

An order of marsipobranchs, including the Myxine or hagfish andthe genus Bdellostoma. They have barbels around the mouth, one toothon the plate, and a communication between tionnasal aperture and thethroat. See Hagfish. [Written also Hyperotreti.]
Same as Hæmadromograph.
To narrate or record. [Obs.] Shak.
. A kind of pillow lace, remarkable for the beauty of itsfigures; -- so called because chiefly made in Honiton, England.

A denomination of weight, containing 100, 112, or 120 poundsavoirdupois, according to differing laws or customs. By the legalstandard of England it is 112 pounds. In most of the United States,both in practice and by law, it is 100 pounds avoirdupois, thecorresponding ton of 2,000 pounds, sometimes called the short ton,beingthe legal ton.
Causing a discharge of water; expelling serum effused into anypart of the body, as in dropsy.-- n.
Of or pertaining to the Hellenes, or Greeks.
Of or pertaining to Havana, in Cuba.-- n. sing. & pl.

A compound containing only hydrogen and carbon, as methane,benzene, etc.; also, by extension, any of their derivatives.Hydrocarbon burner, furnace, stove, a burner, furnace, or stove withwhich liquid fuel, as petroleum, is used.
An instrument for determining and recording the quantity ofwater discharged from a pipe, orifice, etc., in a given time.
Of or pertaining to heterogenesis; heterogenetic.
Harborous. [Obs.]A bishop must be faultless, the husband of one wife, honestlyappareled, harberous. Tyndale (1 Tim. iii. 2)

The frame or body of a vessel, exclusive of her masts, yards,sails, and rigging.Deep in their hulls our deadly bullets light. Dryden.Hull down, said of a ship so distant that her hull is concealed bythe convexity of the sea.
The presiding priest who initiated candidates at the Eleusinianmysteries; hence, one who teaches the mysteries and duties ofreligion. Abp Potter.
See Haze, v. t.

One who having made a profession of Christian belief,deliberately and pertinaciously refuses to believe one or more of thearticles of faith "determined by the authority of the universalchurch." Addis & Arnold.
Belonging to Hawaii or the Sandwich Islands, or to the peopleof Hawaii.-- n.
Producing fruit below the ground.
Having six processes. Gray.
A short pike, sometimes carried by officers of infantry,sometimes used in boarding ships; a spontoon. Tatler.
A waterspout; a hurricane. [Obs.] Drayton. "You cataracts andhurricanoes, spout." Shak.
The study of human nature. [R.] T. W. Collins.
See Whirlbat. [Obs.] Holland.
The receptacle for honey in a honeybee. Shak. Grew.
An aëroplane with a boatlike or other understructure thatenables it to travel on, or to rise from the surface of, a body ofwater by its own motive power.

A sacrifice of a hundred oxen or cattle at the same time;hence, the sacrifice or slaughter of any large number of victims.Slaughtered hecatombs around them bleed. Addison.More than a human hecatomb. Byron.
To affect at heart; to shock. [R.] "The seek to heartstrikeus." B. Jonson.
Of or pertaining to Havana, the capital of the island of Cuba;as, an Havana cigar; -- formerly sometimes written Havannah.-- n.
Having styles of two or more distinct forms or lengths. Darwin.

A furnace, esp. one connected with a series of small chambersand flues of tiles or other masonry through which the heat of a firewas distributed to rooms above. This contrivance, first used in bath,was afterwards adopted in private houses.
An order of freshwater fishes, including the true pikes,cyprinodonts, and blindfishes.
Heronshaw. [Obs.] Spenser.
Same as Hock, a joint.
One who hurries or urges.
Same as Hemochromometer.
An instrument out of tune or rudely constructed; music badlyplayed.
Furnished with hinges.
The state or title of a hag. Middleton.
Direct, forcible, and effective speaking. Milton.
A Linnæan class of plants having seven stamens.

Any carnivorous mammal of the family Hyænidæ, of which threeliving species are known. They are large and strong, but cowardly.They feed chiefly on carrion, and are nocturnal in their habits.[Written also hyæna.]
Of or pertaining to a hilum.
Of the same tenor or tone; equable; without variation.
The frogfish.
Hypochondriasis. [R.]
A heavy-armed infantry soldier. Milford.
A collection of hymns; a hymn book.
Having the hip dislocated; hence, having one hip lower than theother. L'Estrange.
A nerve or tendon, supposed to brace and sustain the heart.Shak.Sobbing, as if a hearstring broke. Moore.
Deprived of the hulls. Hulled corn, kernels of maize preparedfor food by removing the hulls.
An English coin of the value of half a penny; also, the valueof half a penny.

One of the arms of the male of most kinds of cephalopods, whichis specially modified in various ways to effect the fertilization ofthe eggs. In a special sense, the greatly modified arm of Argonautaand allied genera, which, after receiving the spermatophores, becomesdetached from the male, and attaches itself to the female forreproductive purposes.
Keeping at home.
Unrelated in chemical composition, though similar or indenticalin certain other respects; as, borax and augite are homoemorphous,but heteromerous.
The condition of having an unusual intensity of color.
